story:
Just 4 days left!

We’re very grateful for all your support! Because of you, USD3,849 has been raised, almost 40% of our target. This includes a S$400 cheque donation we just received.

All funds will go to TOUCH-PREP to benefit children from poor families and empower young students to serve. Our campaign target is to help 60 needy children and 120 students from 3 schools. However, due to insufficient funding, we are unable to bring the programme to all of them. We will continue to seek funding from other donors.

***TOUCH-PREP with Northland Primary School starts in July! Stay tuned as we’ll post updates here.***

Thanks again for believing in our cause.

---------------------------------------

Who are we? What do we do?

 

Hi, my name is Lydia Fong. I work at TOUCH Community Services, a non-profit organisation in Singapore. My passion is working with children and teenagers and my role at TOUCH is to develop them to be community leaders of tomorrow. I strongly believe that teaching lessons close to my heart will touch hearts and transform the lives of young people. Instilling positive values in young people are critical for them to grow in character, confidence and competence. Positive values are building blocks in their lives; they ensure that they are on the right path to true success in life.

I’d like to share with you one of our programmes which helps needy children in a meaningful and innovative way. It’s called TOUCH-PREP (“Primary 1 Readiness Programme”).

What is TOUCH-PREP?

Through TOUCH-PREP, we aim to give 5-6 year olds from less privileged backgrounds the opportunity to learn basic reading skills before they enter Primary 1 (or equivalent to first grade in elementary school). This is done over 5 weeks (2.5 hours per session) in a fun and interactive way, conducted by student leaders in the participating school. The 5-6 year olds will also learn social skills as he or she interacts with other students, and builds self-confidence.

Quiet and withdrawn, six-year-old Rahiezwan was a tough nut to crack for his 10-year-old mentors, Nicole Lau and Chan Cheuk Mun. But the two prefects from Paya Lebar Methodist Girls' School (Primary) - tasked with introducing the boy to phonics to prepare him for Primary 1 next year – persevered. Rahiezwan can now read and spell simple words such as “cat”, using phonics skills he picked up from his two “teachers”.

[Source: The Straits Times © Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Permission required for reproduction.]

TOUCH-PREP is also a unique leadership development programme to nurture student leaders as they learn decision making, time management, empathy and social skills, as well as creative ways in engaging and motivating young children. To prepare them for their role, a special training session is conducted by TOUCH where they learn about the various socio-economic backgrounds of families in Singapore and the needs of disadvantaged families. They are also taught how to use the multimedia educational activity kits consisting of CD-ROMs and activity books. The student leaders will teach the children in a computer lab at the participating school.

A principal of a TOUCH-PREP participating school said she believed this programme gave her pupils “a head start to real-life situations”, and “They must realise that children come from different backgrounds, and may not be exposed to books and computers." 

Why TOUCH-PREP?

TOUCH believes that every child deserves a good start in life. Disadvantaged children would need more help with this start in life. The first year of school can be stressful and discouraging for kids from less fortunate backgrounds.

Hence, TOUCH-PREP has a two-pronged approach; it is a community service project that offers early learning opportunities for needy children; at the same time, it is a leadership development project that gives aspiring student leaders a platform to develop their capacity for leadership roles.

Pavanni and Samantha, both 10, are more used to sitting behind desks in classrooms than being teachers. But for five Fridays…the pair and 35 of their Primary 4 schoolmates at Paya Lebar Methodist Girls’ School (PLMGS) (Primary) taught simple English to 15 six-year-old children. Of course, they did so in a fun way – with picture matching, guided readings and lots of high fives.

Samantha recalled how she used various techniques to win over her “pupil”, six-year-old Dharani: “I would use actions for every word… I’d swing my body when she read ‘swing’, and give a thumbs up when she read ‘like’.”

Dharani also spoke too softly to be heard. Pavanni, who also coached her, realised later that whenever she lowered her voice, Dharani would raise hers. Henceforth, Pavanni would purposely lower her voice to make Dharani speak up. Pavanni said that after five weeks, “she’s getting better at reading now”. Her schoolmates would also give their “pupils” high fives if they answered questions correctly.

[Source: Little Red Dot, The Straits Times © Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Permission required for reproduction.]

How do needy kids participate?

TOUCH-PREP is offered to families who are on the participating school’s Financial Assistance Scheme. This programme is also available to children from low-income families from kindergartens located near the participating schools.

What we need & what you get

With your support, we are looking to run TOUCH-PREP trainings at 3 schools:

  • 3 schools x 5 sessions = 15 sessions
  • 60 needy kids aged 5-6 years old (estimated 20 beneficiaries per school)
  • 120 student leaders aged 10-12 years old (estimated 40 student leaders per school)

Our funding wish list is broken down as follows:

  • Book & Stationary vouchers for needy kids
  • Supplies for TOUCH-PREP programme 
  • Training conducted by TOUCH Community Services
  • Transport (2-way) for needy kids from their neighbourhood to the school
  • Graduation party (Includes: Prizes, Food & Certificates for kids and student leaders)
  • Light refreshments for kids and students each session
  • Volunteer allowance which covers transport
  • Fees by Indiegogo/PayPal

Total S$13,365 (or USD 9,725)

Our work in TOUCH Community Services is sustained through donations and fund-raising efforts. We strive to use less than 20% of funds to cover fund-raising and administrative costs, and have been successful each year. With Indiegogo supporters like you, we hope to reduce this percentage much further!

We are able to issue tax-deduction receipts of 300% for those residing in Singapore (minimum contribution of S$50). For eg., for every S$100 donated, S$300 will be deducted from taxable income in Singapore for the year. Please provide your IC/FIN number and home address for us to process your tax deduction receipt within 3 working days.

By contributing, you'll receive heartwarming stories of the people we've helped and been inspired by, in our 88-page book "Listen to My Heart - Rediscovering Life's Overcoming Spirit" published by Write Editions.

"Listen to My Heart celebrates life's overcoming spirit. It tells the compelling life stories of a brave group of individuals, subtly woven into a tapestry of extraordinary inspiration. Despite being plagued by unfathomable adversity, these individuals are able to harness the quiet strength within them, rise up each time they fall, and persevere for a better tomorrow."

The coffee-table book is an inspiring read, and a wonderful gift for friends and loved ones!

Here's how the book cover (26cm by 26cm) and inside pages look like:

Our Story

Touched by the obvious need of low-income and single-parent families with difficulties making ends meet, much less raising their children in a positive environment, a group of volunteers in their 20s organised activities to help the children. This small attempt since 1986 has today become TOUCH Community Services. Over the last 23 years, our passion and mission at TOUCH is to strengthen families.

We are an award-winning charity registered in Singapore with an Institution of a Public Character (IPC) status. We are also a member of the National Council of Social Service.

We reach out to some 29,000 clients and 155,000 service users in a year. They include at-risk children and youths, needy families, people with intellectual or hearing disabilities, those with healthcare needs, as well as the frail elderly.

Risks & Challenges

TOUCH-PREP is recognised by schools as a worthy and beneficial project for both the needy children as well as their student leaders. Over the last 4 years, TOUCH-PREP was run 13 times in 4 participating schools, through which 195 needy children benefited from the coaching by 293 student leaders.

This was made possible through funding support from a corporation, for which we are truly grateful! However, this funding has already run out. Without funding, we are unable to bring TOUCH-PREP to any children from low-income families and in schools this year. We now need fresh funding to take this project to some 60 beneficiaries and 120 student leaders this year. We would like to give the Indiegogo community an opportunity to help our children!

While we value funding from corporations, we hope to partner them in other projects where we can also engage their employees’ time and expertise. We find that corporations generally prefer not to simply give money to programmes without more employee involvement as part of the partnership.

If our campaign doesn’t receive sufficient funding, we may pitch to local government-linked agencies for funding. We hope not to go that route as time taken to pitch to these agencies can be long-drawn and uncertain; and funding, if finally approved, covers only part of the project cost.

We really hope to utilise limited staff time and resources in engaging beneficiaries and partners for our various works and in developing innovative ideas to meet more needs in the community. Any funds that come in after the goal is met will be channelled to our work supporting needy children and families.

Everything Helps!

If you aren’t able to help financially, we would truly appreciate your help in passing this campaign on to people you know. Use the Indiegogo share tools on the top left corner of this page. Forward the link TOUCH PREP to your friends. Together, we can make a difference in children's lives!

If you’re a pre-school or primary school teacher in Singapore, you could bring TOUCH-PREP to your children/students. To find out how, please contact me either at Email: lydia.fong@touch.org.sg or click on any of the names listed in the Campaign Team - Camilla Loh, Lydia Fong, Stella Teo.

Be updated on the work of TOUCH Community Services on Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, Website (see links below). We currently do not have dedicated TOUCH-PREP sites.

Thank you for everything you do!

Lydia and the team at TOUCH Community Services

needs of disadvantaged families. They are also taught how to use the multimedia
educational activity kits consisting of CD-ROMs and activity books. The student
leaders will teach the children in a computer lab at the participating school.
A principal of a TOUCH-PREP participating school said she believed this programme gave her pupils “a head start to real-life situations”, and “They must realise that children come from different backgrounds, and may not be exposed to books and computers." 

Why TOUCH-PREP?
TOUCH believes that every child deserves a good start in life. Disadvantaged children would need more help with this start in life. The first year of school can be stressful and discouraging for kids from less fortunate backgrounds.
Hence, TOUCH-PREP has a two-pronged approach; it is a community service project that offers early learning opportunities for needy children; at the same time, it is a leadership development project that gives aspiring student leaders a platform to develop their capacity for leadership roles.




Pavanni and Samantha, both 10, are more used to sitting behind desks in classrooms than being teachers. But for five Fridays…the pair and 35 of their Primary 4 schoolmates at Paya Lebar Methodist Girls’ School (PLMGS) (Primary) taught simple English to 15 six-year-old children. Of course, they did so in a fun way – with picture matching, guided readings and lots of high fives.
Samantha recalled how she used various techniques to win over her “pupil”, six-year-old Dharani: “I would use actions for every word… I’d swing my body when she read ‘swing’, and give a thumbs up when she read ‘like’.”
Dharani also spoke too softly to be heard. Pavanni, who also coached her, realised later that whenever she lowered her voice, Dharani would raise hers. Henceforth, Pavanni would purposely lower her voice to make Dharani speak up. Pavanni said that after five weeks, “she’s getting better at reading now”. Her schoolmates would also give their “pupils” high fives if they answered questions correctly.
[Source: Little Red Dot, The Straits Times © Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Permission required for reproduction.]
How do needy kids participate?
TOUCH-PREP is offered to families who are on the participating school’s Financial Assistance Scheme. This programme is also available to children from low-income families from kindergartens located near the participating schools.



What we
need & what you get

With your support, we are looking to run TOUCH-PREP trainings at 3 schools:

3 schools x 5 sessions = 15 sessions


60 needy kids aged 5-6 years old (estimated 20 beneficiaries per school)


120 student leaders aged 10-12 years old (estimated 40 student leaders per school)

Our funding wish list is broken down as follows:


Book & Stationary vouchers for needy kids


Supplies for TOUCH-PREP programme 


Training conducted by TOUCH Community Services


Transport (2-way) for needy kids from their neighbourhood to the school


Graduation party (Includes: Prizes, Food & Certificates for kids and student leaders)


Light refreshments for kids and students each session


Volunteer allowance which covers transport


Fees by Indiegogo/PayPal


Total S$13,365 (or USD 9,725)
Our work in TOUCH Community Services is sustained through donations and fund-raising efforts. We strive to use less than 20% of funds to cover fund-raising and administrative costs, and have been successful each year. With Indiegogo supporters like you, we hope to reduce this percentage much further!
We are able to issue tax-deduction receipts of 300% for those residing in Singapore (minimum contribution of S$50). For eg., for every S$100 donated, S$300 will be deducted from taxable income in Singapore for the year. Please provide your IC/FIN number and home address for us to process your tax deduction receipt within 3 working days.
By contributing, you'll receive heartwarming stories of the people we've helped and been inspired by, in our 88-page book "Listen to My Heart - Rediscovering Life's Overcoming Spirit" published by Write Editions.
"Listen to My Heart celebrates life's overcoming spirit. It tells the compelling life stories of a brave group of individuals, subtly woven into a tapestry of extraordinary inspiration. Despite being plagued by unfathomable adversity, these individuals are able to harness the quiet strength within them, rise up each time they fall, and persevere for a better tomorrow."
The coffee-table book is an inspiring read, and a wonderful gift for friends and loved ones!
Here's how the book cover (26cm by 26cm) and inside pages look like:








Our Story
Touched by the obvious need of low-income and single-parent families
with difficulties making ends meet, much less raising their children in a
positive environment, a group of volunteers in their 20s organised activities
to help the children. This small attempt since 1986 has today become TOUCH
Community Services. Over the last 23 years, our passion and mission at TOUCH is to strengthen families.
We are an award-winning charity registered in Singapore with an Institution of a Public
Character (IPC) status. We are also a member of the National Council of Social
Service.

We reach out to some 29,000 clients and 155,000 service users in a year. They include at-risk children and youths, needy families, people with intellectual or hearing disabilities, those with healthcare needs, as well as the frail elderly.

Risks & Challenges  
TOUCH-PREP
is recognised by schools as a worthy and beneficial project for both the needy
children as well as their student leaders. Over the last 4 years, TOUCH-PREP
was run 13 times in 4 participating schools, through which 195 needy children
benefited from the coaching by 293 student leaders. 
This was
made possible through funding support from a corporation, for which
we are truly grateful! However, this
funding has already run out. Without funding, we are unable to bring TOUCH-PREP to any children from low-income families and in schools this year. We now need fresh funding to take this project to some 60
beneficiaries and 120 student leaders this year. We would like to give the Indiegogo
community an opportunity to help our children!

While we value funding from corporations, we hope to partner them in other projects where we can also engage their employees’ time and expertise. We find that corporations generally prefer not to simply give money to programmes without more employee involvement as part of the partnership.
If our campaign doesn’t receive sufficient funding, we may pitch to local government-linked agencies for funding. We hope
not to go that route as time taken to pitch to these agencies can be
long-drawn and uncertain; and funding, if finally approved, covers only part of
the project cost.
We really hope to utilise limited staff
time and resources in engaging beneficiaries and partners for our various works
and in developing innovative ideas to meet more needs in the community. Any funds that come in after the
goal is met will be channelled to our work supporting needy children and families.

Everything Helps!
If you aren’t able to help financially, we would truly
appreciate your help in passing this campaign on to people you know. Use the Indiegogo share tools on the top left corner of this page. Forward the link TOUCH PREP to your friends. Together, we can make a difference in children's lives!

If you’re a pre-school or primary school teacher in Singapore, you could bring
TOUCH-PREP to your children/students. To find out how, please contact me either at Email: lydia.fong@touch.org.sg or click on any of the names listed in the Campaign Team - Camilla Loh, Lydia Fong, Stella Teo.
Be updated on the work of TOUCH Community Services on Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, Website (see links below). We currently do not have dedicated TOUCH-PREP sites.

Thank you for everything you do!
Lydia and the team at TOUCH Community Services

story:
Thank you Aden Suchak for the video!


Why do we want to start a scholarship for refugee students?

  For those who don’t know me, my name is Brian Huskie. I’m a teacher in an urban district and as of this writing I’ve been there for eight years, five of which I’ve taught English Language Learners. Before teaching I was in the Army, and in 2004 I was in Iraq. Here I am just over a decade ago:

  I was with one other soldier at a traffic control point when two Iraqi kids came over to talk to us. Here they are:

  They wanted to go buy kabobs for us and charge us triple for them. They also wanted our bullets so they could scrape the bullet off and light the gun powder. We teased them for a few minutes, haggling over kabobs and lighting matches. The older one tried to get us to give him a grenade for a couple kabobs. The soldier who was with me, in the picture above, pretended to throw the grenade. He didn’t even have it in his hand…it was in good fun…but the younger one ran (stumbled, really) into the weeds and started crying. He was bawling. He wouldn’t let anyone near him. I took off my helmet and gave up my gun and brought the kid a Gatorade. He whirled around and hugged me, and we hugged in the weeds for a long time. When I hug my four year old I sometimes feel that little Iraqi boy’s ribs. Then he showed me the scars on his leg. He had been burned from his ankle to his thigh. He was covered in scars. He made a machine gun noise, pointed to his leg, and said “Amerikee!” That was eleven years ago. If the kid is still alive, he’d be 18 or so.  

  Like a bad movie, fireworks on the Fourth of July made my heart race something fierce, at least the first few years after I came back. Then, with time, it faded, and I moved on. Until last Fourth of July. I was with my family on Montauk beach watching the fireworks and my youngest, 2 years old, was terrified. He tried to run away high up on a sand dune so I ran after him, caught him, picked him up and tried to console him. The kid just went limp. My son didn’t move, didn’t make a sound, and just fell asleep, almost instantly. All of a sudden I was back, kicking in doors and raiding homes. In one, there stood a man, he might have been affiliated with Al Qaeda, who knows…but he had a son under the age of five in the upstairs room. There was shooting and yelling, and the kid just slept. I picked him up and brought him to his mother, and although he was unhurt he wouldn’t wake up. He just went limp.

  There is one nightmare I have. We took over a hospital and, after a day of fighting, a man brought his son in. The son was obviously dead…maybe 7 or 8 years old. He was flopping around in his dad’s arms. The father was laughing uncontrollably – maniacally. I never forgot it.

  Refugees are close to my heart. I have students now who are teenagers who were in Iraq when I was there eleven years ago. When I see my students I see the crowds of little kids who begged for pencils and candy; I see the kids who walked to school until they canceled school so we could fight. I broke their desks to burn to keep warm in December, and our sniper took a position in an elementary classroom. I see the boy whose leg was burned, and the little limp sleeper who had guns pointed at him, and the laughing dad. I see them in my own kids, somehow. It haunts me.

  These kids from Iraq, as well as refugees from other places in the Middle East, Africa, Burma, and Nepal, didn’t choose to have war or persecution happen to them. They didn’t choose the actions of their countries or of ours. They all have their own stories, but somehow, they made it here. They have an obligation to make the most out of their lives, and they know it. It’s a second chance many don’t get. What are they going to do with this new life they were given?

We want this scholarship fund to help refugees pay for college, and we are asking for your help. We need a minimum of $25,000 for an endowment, which would give a small scholarship every single year, forever. I would like to reach $100,000…that’s our goal. Any little bit helps. Thank you for reading, and if you have any questions please don’t hesitate to leave a comment. Thank you again!


Scholarship Details

An endowment has been set up through SUNY Albany. If the goal is reached, then a percentage of the principal will be given as a scholarship to a capital district refugee student every year, forever. If the goal is not reached, the money still goes as a single scholarship, but there will be no endowment and the money will only be given once. This is a 501c3 project and so there are tax benefits to donating!


Refugee Students from Albany High

Ayat

My name is Ayat.  I’m 19 years old and from Iraq. I lived and studied in Iraq until 2005. I went to Ebn Majid School in Baghdad. And like almost every other student, I tried very hard to get good grades and make my parents proud.

After the war in 2003 everything I knew changed. I rarely went to school; it was closed most of the times in the beginning. My school was next to three targeted places: a mosque for Sunni people, Husainia (where Shea people pray), and a police station. I still remember most of the explosions happened and I still remember how we prayed for the student’s and friends that we lost. One day that I will never forget was when they bombed the police station and the windows broke upon our heads. Everyone was running and screaming. It’s both funny and scary how everything you said you would do to protect your home becomes nothing when it comes to your life. However, I couldn’t run further than the school’s wall because I was looking my younger sister. I thought I lost her. I cried and asked for help but everyone was busy saving their lives because usually one explosion is not enough. My sister is way stronger than me. She came laughing and asking why I didn’t run home. I think she was taking it like a game. I took her hand and we ran home like everyone did.

They stopped closing the schools when people got use to the sound of explosions and many kids already knew how dead bodies look like. Sometimes, when something explodes in the morning, we just wait until noon to go to school and hear the principle’s speech. She always mentions how brave and strong we are and how the future of the country depends on us. I think it always worked because every kid likes to feel like a superhero. I left Iraq two years after. And never went back.

My dad took us to the United Arab Emirates. We found peace in there but as refugees we couldn’t have the rights that other people had. Many refugees couldn’t stay long because no one wanted us there. They made every day harder than the one before and it was also expensive to live there. I went to night school with my sister and my dad had to work three jobs to pay for it. Soon we found that there is no way we can live there.

So we moved to Jordan in 2009. And as almost everyone who lived there can say, it is expensive and there were no jobs. We had to live in a small place in the attic of some building. But at least we didn’t have to pay for our education. The schools there were dirty, so cold in winter, and as I remember most of the classes had 45 students in it. Sometimes you can’t breathe. Students, including me, lived what I like to call “psychological war”. They keep repeating that their life will end if they didn’t get an average above 90. And for some it did end. It’s hard when your future is decided by a single percentage point like it did for students in Jordan.

When I reached the 12th grade I had to drop high school. It wasn’t free anymore and my dad couldn’t afford it or the books. I think that’s the point when I started hating anyone who doesn’t respect a book because I’ve always felt that books should be in reach of every human’s hand. I still remember how much I cried and prayed to get a chance to finish high school. After all, I was raised with the idea that education is the only way to get a good, respectful life. My dad always used to say to me and my two sisters “If I can’t give you money and a life like princesses have, I will try my best to educate you to get it for yourselves, and that is my inheritance for you “. He did his best and still does.

When I struggled in both UAE and Jordan, I couldn’t always feel it because I calmed myself with saying I’ve seen worse. My Family and I were blessed and lucky because America accepted us. I will never forget the moment we arrived the JFK Airport. All the fire, pain and chaos in my heart stopped; finally we found a place that we can call a second home.

I want to study Aerospace Engineering. And I want to have the chance to make up all the bad years that my family been through. This is just a small sample of what refugees face in their lives. I want to say that life isn’t easy to all of us, but if you have a home, and a chance to educate yourself, then love it, appreciate it and try your best to protect it. Because somewhere on this planet there are many people who just want to reach their home in one piece, and many other people who need a little money, not to buy a pair of shoes, but to buy books. And believe it or not I’m certain that all of them wish to have the life that you have. Because I once did.

Bhim

My name is Bhim. I was born in Bhutan, but my earliest memories are from a refugee camp in eastern Nepal. The Camp was a city made of plastic and tin huts built with ever present mud and bamboo stems. I spent 15 years of my life there. I have many memories there with my beautiful family and parents.

I also faced a lot of obstacles during my time in the refugee camp. We lived in a hut made of bamboo and sun dried molded bricks; the roof was made of plastic and bamboo sticks. Our bathroom was a hole on the ground right outside of the house. There was not much privacy. Other family members could easily see you bare parts. My house was not that strong either. The slightest wind or rain used to wreak havoc on our existence. It used to rain for months during the summer.

In the refugee camp, we had limited access to health care, and although what we had was free, there used to be a long line to see a doctor. Many people with fevers and other deadly diseases needed to wait for days before they could be seen by the doctor. He was a medically trained person, but we used to call him “doctor” because he was the only one we had seen around there prescribing medicine to patients.

One day we learned that the United States was letting people in the camp apply for immigration to the United States. My parents were in doubt, initially, but once we heard about the better life in the USA, they jumped at the chance to move and applied for immigration. Moving to a new country with a new language, culture, and lifestyle was not easy. We knew very little and were a bit afraid. It made us very nervous and concerned. We knew we would be starting a life from scratch in another country.

We were driven from Bhutan for being of an ethnicity and religion that was different from that of the King, even though my family had lived in Bhutan for four generations and long before the collapse of the British Empire. After living in Nepal as a refugee, as a nationless being, we embarked on the journey to a destination with hope, but nothing else. We heard about terrible stories from people who had arrived in the U.S. before us. They were facing a very difficult life. My family still had nightmarish memories of dragging little kids out of Bhutan, leaving the land and life they had built. We thought we were repeating the same saga once again. Along with the decision to immigrate to the U.S., we also gave up any hope of returning to our land and house in Bhutan.

Even after I got to the U.S.A. I was scared. I do not know what I was scared of, but it took years before that fear went away. I knew no rules and regulations. I was struggling at school with all new subject matter, language, and style. At the same time, I was amazed when I saw so many different kinds of people. I quickly learned diversity was not unique to my home town, but true of every city in U.S. I became more comfortable with the language, culture, and rules. I started to make friends. Life suddenly felt much better; my parents and teachers played a critical role in making this happen. I am really thankful to them. I am extremely happy with what I have achieved, but I know that I have just started my journey.

Malak

My name is Malak, I’m 18 years old student in Albany high, and I’m originally from Iraq. I left my country in 2006 and I didn’t go back, not even for a visit.

Me and people from my country have been through a lot since the war started. Life wasn’t easy at all. I still remember my friend, Rania, who went to shop for school supplies with her father when all of a sudden a bomb exploded next to them and turned them into pieces. That was a horrible thing to see and live with for anybody, especially to a 7 years old girl like me.

We were deprived of our basic rights, we spent long days and nights without stepping outside from my house because we were afraid of the explosions that were happening, and we also stopped going to school for months because of the battles that happened in Baghdad. There were two strategic places next to my school, a mosque and a police station, which were always bombed. And sometimes in the days that an explosion happens, we do go to school, but delayed for 2 hours.

So after all these events, we were forced to leave Baghdad and go to UAE. We faced many obstacles in the 5 years that we lived there. The high cost of visa, lodging, and school, we were simply unwelcomed as refugees to stay and live there, so we moved to Jordan only for one reason, to come to America. We lived there for 5 years, and because we were not citizens, we couldn’t work and if we did, we would go to jail or be sent back to Iraq, which was a certain fate of death.

We’ve been through a harsh circumstances, we couldn’t afford the expensive life there; luckily the schools were free, except for the 12th grade which we have to pay. We couldn’t afford that so we had to leave school for a year. Until the day we all waited for, the refugees organization (IOM) called us and said: your flight to Albany, New York will be in April 8, does this date works for you?  We couldn’t agree more, or be happier. It was the best moment of my life.
So here I am, I’m here for almost a year, and I’m so grateful to be alive, to come to this great country, with my ambition to be a pharmacist one day. But I know that whatever happens, my family and I will be safe and have opportunities that we wouldn’t otherwise have, opportunities that are still just a beautiful dream to a lot of people, just like it was to us.

Saw

Hi! My name is Saw Pre Pre…ok! I was born in Burma, Mon state (not Karen state). Because of the war my parents were worried if I was born in Karen state that there would not be a nurse to help. Also, my mother might not have had time to give birth because of running from Burmese soldiers. I think you can already picture it in your head. Look…when I was young my life wasn’t fulfilled and I didn’t get what I wanted – basically food, education, clothes. If I were to compare American kids and refugee kids they are oil and water.

I didn’t live in a refugee camp, but that doesn’t mean I’m not a refugee…I’m a REFUGEE from BURMA!!! Who has run from the Burmese military, who has attacked the Karen people.  My school was like a living room, a tiny tiny living room. You know when I lived there I saw many students in school buses with their beautiful uniforms, but I had the unlucky curse of being a refugee, and they didn’t allow us to attend a citizen’s school. Because of the education I’m so upset, I feel down, all the time when my parents look at me their sympathy goes out to me.

At that time we are registered to come to America but my mom is scared because of the new strange STRANGE STRANGE place. In the US, there are different living styles, food, culture, etc…OK!!! Let me ask you, have you ever thought of going to a strange place to live? How does that feel? Because my mom was nervous! Finally, I can go to school without any sadness, because here in Albany High School we can learn along with the citizens, and everyone is equal in speech and freedoms.

Sara

My name is Sara Mohamed. I am 16 years old and I am Libyan Sudanese. My parents are from Sudan and me and my siblings were born in Libya. I have one sister and two brothers, and I am the youngest. One of my brothers is in Egypt and my sister and other brother…I don’t know where they are.

Life in Libya was so easy and everything was cheap. School is so different in my country. I really love school so it was so easy for me to be good. For me when I was first going to school I felt like I was going to an amusement park. But for some other kids it’s like going to war and that’s true because if you are going to war and you know how to use your brain or your gun then you’ll definitely die. School was the same because if you didn’t study hard and score high then you’ll get beaten by a wire and sometimes a stick. So you always compete with your classmates and your best friends to be the best of the best.

Back in Libya we didn’t have medical insurance. You pay for yourself from your own pocket, but for other injuries it’s free, all you have to do is buy your medicine. In February 2011 Libyan started their violent protest against the president. At that time my dad was in another country and my brothers and sister went to visit my aunt. So it was only me and my mom. Living in a house with an open ceiling living room so when they fight outside we can hear them right in front of the house. We slept in on room and locked the door on us during the night and when we open the door in the morning there were hundreds of bullets everywhere, every day for two months. For two months we only went shopping twice. I use to dress like a boy so nobody asks me something because during that time they kidnapped hundreds of kids, women, and even little girls, and rape them and kill them. That’s why I even cut my hair like a boy – no one could recognize me. It was really risky going out alone but if I didn’t we could have died from starving. After that the atmosphere calmed down a little bit so my dad came and decided to go to Egypt, but we couldn’t contact my siblings so we just went to Egypt and stayed at a refugee camp located between Libya and Egypt’s border. We stayed there for almost 4 years.

We lived in a house that was made of sand, blankets, plastic, and wood. We made them by ourselves. We had three meals a day for each and a bottle of water. I use to keep all the water and sell it so I could buy us good food to eat. Finally after 4 years I came here to the US. I was really happy that I left that scary place, but it was really different from my country. My country is so loud. When in the streets you see a lot of kids playing, people walking, you hear loud music from stores and car horns. Everything was loud, but here is so quiet.

When I first came I didn’t really speak English very well. I only knew how to say “My name is Sara”, “help me”, and a few words. Sometimes I feel bad because when I ask people walking on the street about the time or to give me directions they would walk away from me. I didn’t know why, I thought maybe because of how I dressed. Other times people were really curious – they asked me about my hijab and my country and sometimes about my religion. I didn’t really feel homesick then.

The school here is really good. You have the opportunity to choose your classes and teachers are very good – and of course, there are no beatings! I didn’t have any problems at school, everyone is so nice.

After I graduate from High School I want to go to college and study even harder than now and become a good doctor. It has been my dream since I was a little girl because I really like helping others, it makes me so happy. But sometimes I feel like being a lawyer to help seek justice because in so many places in the world there is a lot of unfairness. After all, all I really want to do is help people.

to a capital district refugee student every year, forever. If the goal is not
reached, the money still goes as a single scholarship, but there will be no
endowment and the money will only be given once. This is a 501c3 project and so
there are tax benefits to donating!
Refugee Students from Albany HighAyatMy name is Ayat.  I’m 19 years old and from Iraq. I lived and studied in Iraq until 2005. I went to Ebn Majid School in Baghdad. And like almost every other student, I tried very hard to get good grades and make my parents proud.After the war in 2003 everything I knew changed. I rarely went to school; it was closed most of the times in the beginning. My school was next to three targeted places: a mosque for Sunni people, Husainia (where Shea people pray), and a police station. I still remember most of the explosions happened and I still remember how we prayed for the student’s and friends that we lost. One day that I will never forget was when they bombed the police station and the windows broke upon our heads. Everyone was running and screaming. It’s both funny and scary how everything you said you would do to protect your home becomes nothing when it comes to your life. However, I couldn’t run further than the school’s wall because I was looking my younger sister. I thought I lost her. I cried and asked for help but everyone was busy saving their lives because usually one explosion is not enough. My sister is way stronger than me. She came laughing and asking why I didn’t run home. I think she was taking it like a game. I took her hand and we ran home like everyone did.They stopped closing the schools when people got use to the sound of explosions and many kids already knew how dead bodies look like. Sometimes, when something explodes in the morning, we just wait until noon to go to school and hear the principle’s speech. She always mentions how brave and strong we are and how the future of the country depends on us. I think it always worked because every kid likes to feel like a superhero. I left Iraq two years after. And never went back.My dad took us to the United Arab Emirates. We found peace in there but as refugees we couldn’t have the rights that other people had. Many refugees couldn’t stay long because no one wanted us there. They made every day harder than the one before and it was also expensive to live there. I went to night school with my sister and my dad had to work three jobs to pay for it. Soon we found that there is no way we can live there.So we moved to Jordan in 2009. And as almost everyone who lived there can say, it is expensive and there were no jobs. We had to live in a small place in the attic of some building. But at least we didn’t have to pay for our education. The schools there were dirty, so cold in winter, and as I remember most of the classes had 45 students in it. Sometimes you can’t breathe. Students, including me, lived what I like to call “psychological war”. They keep repeating that their life will end if they didn’t get an average above 90. And for some it did end. It’s hard when your future is decided by a single percentage point like it did for students in Jordan.When I reached the 12th grade I had to drop high school. It wasn’t free anymore and my dad couldn’t afford it or the books. I think that’s the point when I started hating anyone who doesn’t respect a book because I’ve always felt that books should be in reach of every human’s hand. I still remember how much I cried and prayed to get a chance to finish high school. After all, I was raised with the idea that education is the only way to get a good, respectful life. My dad always used to say to me and my two sisters “If I can’t give you money and a life like princesses have, I will try my best to educate you to get it for yourselves, and that is my inheritance for you “. He did his best and still does.When I struggled in both UAE and Jordan, I couldn’t always feel it because I calmed myself with saying I’ve seen worse. My Family and I were blessed and lucky because America accepted us. I will never forget the moment we arrived the JFK Airport. All the fire, pain and chaos in my heart stopped; finally we found a place that we can call a second home.I want to study Aerospace Engineering. And I want to have the chance to make up all the bad years that my family been through. This is just a small sample of what refugees face in their lives. I want to say that life isn’t easy to all of us, but if you have a home, and a chance to educate yourself, then love it, appreciate it and try your best to protect it. Because somewhere on this planet there are many people who just want to reach their home in one piece, and many other people who need a little money, not to buy a pair of shoes, but to buy books. And believe it or not I’m certain that all of them wish to have the life that you have. Because I once did.BhimMy name is Bhim. I was born in Bhutan, but my earliest memories are from a refugee camp in eastern Nepal. The Camp was a city made of plastic and tin huts built with ever present mud and bamboo stems. I spent 15 years of my life there. I have many memories there with my beautiful family and parents.I also faced a lot of obstacles during my time in the refugee camp. We lived in a hut made of bamboo and sun dried molded bricks; the roof was made of plastic and bamboo sticks. Our bathroom was a hole on the ground right outside of the house. There was not much privacy. Other family members could easily see you bare parts. My house was not that strong either. The slightest wind or rain used to wreak havoc on our existence. It used to rain for months during the summer.In the refugee camp, we had limited access to health care, and although what we had was free, there used to be a long line to see a doctor. Many people with fevers and other deadly diseases needed to wait for days before they could be seen by the doctor. He was a medically trained person, but we used to call him “doctor” because he was the only one we had seen around there prescribing medicine to patients.One day we learned that the United States was letting people in the camp apply for immigration to the United States. My parents were in doubt, initially, but once we heard about the better life in the USA, they jumped at the chance to move and applied for immigration. Moving to a new country with a new language, culture, and lifestyle was not easy. We knew very little and were a bit afraid. It made us very nervous and concerned. We knew we would be starting a life from scratch in another country.We were driven from Bhutan for being of an ethnicity and religion that was different from that of the King, even though my family had lived in Bhutan for four generations and long before the collapse of the British Empire. After living in Nepal as a refugee, as a nationless being, we embarked on the journey to a destination with hope, but nothing else. We heard about terrible stories from people who had arrived in the U.S. before us. They were facing a very difficult life. My family still had nightmarish memories of dragging little kids out of Bhutan, leaving the land and life they had built. We thought we were repeating the same saga once again. Along with the decision to immigrate to the U.S., we also gave up any hope of returning to our land and house in Bhutan.Even after I got to the U.S.A. I was scared. I do not know what I was scared of, but it took years before that fear went away. I knew no rules and regulations. I was struggling at school with all new subject matter, language, and style. At the same time, I was amazed when I saw so many different kinds of people. I quickly learned diversity was not unique to my home town, but true of every city in U.S. I became more comfortable with the language, culture, and rules. I started to make friends. Life suddenly felt much better; my parents and teachers played a critical role in making this happen. I am really thankful to them. I am extremely happy with what I have achieved, but I know that I have just started my journey.MalakMy name is Malak, I’m 18 years old student in Albany high, and I’m originally from Iraq. I left my country in 2006 and I didn’t go back, not even for a visit.Me and people from my country have been through a lot since the war started. Life wasn’t easy at all. I still remember my friend, Rania, who went to shop for school supplies with her father when all of a sudden a bomb exploded next to them and turned them into pieces. That was a horrible thing to see and live with for anybody, especially to a 7 years old girl like me.We were deprived of our basic rights, we spent long days and nights without stepping outside from my house because we were afraid of the explosions that were happening, and we also stopped going to school for months because of the battles that happened in Baghdad. There were two strategic places next to my school, a mosque and a police station, which were always bombed. And sometimes in the days that an explosion happens, we do go to school, but delayed for 2 hours.So after all these events, we were forced to leave Baghdad and go to UAE. We faced many obstacles in the 5 years that we lived there. The high cost of visa, lodging, and school, we were simply unwelcomed as refugees to stay and live there, so we moved to Jordan only for one reason, to come to America. We lived there for 5 years, and because we were not citizens, we couldn’t work and if we did, we would go to jail or be sent back to Iraq, which was a certain fate of death.We’ve been through a harsh circumstances, we couldn’t afford the expensive life there; luckily the schools were free, except for the 12th grade which we have to pay. We couldn’t afford that so we had to leave school for a year. Until the day we all waited for, the refugees organization (IOM) called us and said: your flight to Albany, New York will be in April 8, does this date works for you?  We couldn’t agree more, or be happier. It was the best moment of my life.So here I am, I’m here for almost a year, and I’m so grateful to be alive, to come to this great country, with my ambition to be a pharmacist one day. But I know that whatever happens, my family and I will be safe and have opportunities that we wouldn’t otherwise have, opportunities that are still just a beautiful dream to a lot of people, just like it was to us.
Saw
Hi! My name is Saw Pre Pre…ok! I was born in Burma, Mon
state (not Karen state). Because of the war my parents were worried if I was
born in Karen state that there would not be a nurse to help. Also, my mother
might not have had time to give birth because of running from Burmese soldiers.
I think you can already picture it in your head. Look…when I was young my life
wasn’t fulfilled and I didn’t get what I wanted – basically food, education,
clothes. If I were to compare American kids and refugee kids they are oil and
water. 
I didn’t live in a refugee camp, but that doesn’t mean I’m
not a refugee…I’m a REFUGEE from BURMA!!! Who has run from the Burmese
military, who has attacked the Karen people. 
My school was like a living room, a tiny tiny living room. You know when
I lived there I saw many students in school buses with their beautiful uniforms,
but I had the unlucky curse of being a refugee, and they didn’t allow us to
attend a citizen’s school. Because of the education I’m so upset, I feel down,
all the time when my parents look at me their sympathy goes out to me. 
At that time we are registered to come to America but my mom
is scared because of the new strange STRANGE STRANGE place. In the US, there
are different living styles, food, culture, etc…OK!!! Let me ask you, have you
ever thought of going to a strange place to live? How does that feel? Because
my mom was nervous! Finally, I can go to school without any sadness, because
here in Albany High School we can learn along with the citizens, and everyone
is equal in speech and freedoms. 
Sara
My name is Sara Mohamed. I am 16 years old and I am Libyan
Sudanese. My parents are from Sudan and me and my siblings were born in Libya.
I have one sister and two brothers, and I am the youngest. One of my brothers
is in Egypt and my sister and other brother…I don’t know where they are.
Life in Libya was so easy and everything was cheap. School
is so different in my country. I really love school so it was so easy for me to
be good. For me when I was first going to school I felt like I was going to an
amusement park. But for some other kids it’s like going to war and that’s true
because if you are going to war and you know how to use your brain or your gun
then you’ll definitely die. School was the same because if you didn’t study hard
and score high then you’ll get beaten by a wire and sometimes a stick. So you
always compete with your classmates and your best friends to be the best of the
best.
Back in Libya we didn’t have medical insurance. You pay for
yourself from your own pocket, but for other injuries it’s free, all you have
to do is buy your medicine. In February 2011 Libyan started their violent
protest against the president. At that time my dad was in another country and
my brothers and sister went to visit my aunt. So it was only me and my mom. Living
in a house with an open ceiling living room so when they fight outside we can
hear them right in front of the house. We slept in on room and locked the door
on us during the night and when we open the door in the morning there were
hundreds of bullets everywhere, every day for two months. For two months we
only went shopping twice. I use to dress like a boy so nobody asks me something
because during that time they kidnapped hundreds of kids, women, and even
little girls, and rape them and kill them. That’s why I even cut my hair like a
boy – no one could recognize me. It was really risky going out alone but if I
didn’t we could have died from starving. After that the atmosphere calmed down
a little bit so my dad came and decided to go to Egypt, but we couldn’t contact
my siblings so we just went to Egypt and stayed at a refugee camp located
between Libya and Egypt’s border. We stayed there for almost 4 years.
We lived in a house that was made of sand, blankets,
plastic, and wood. We made them by ourselves. We had three meals a day for each
and a bottle of water. I use to keep all the water and sell it so I could buy
us good food to eat. Finally after 4 years I came here to the US. I was really
happy that I left that scary place, but it was really different from my country.
My country is so loud. When in the streets you see a lot of kids playing,
people walking, you hear loud music from stores and car horns. Everything was
loud, but here is so quiet. 
When I first came I didn’t really speak English very well. I
only knew how to say “My name is Sara”, “help me”, and a few words. Sometimes I
feel bad because when I ask people walking on the street about the time or to
give me directions they would walk away from me. I didn’t know why, I thought
maybe because of how I dressed. Other times people were really curious – they asked
me about my hijab and my country and sometimes about my religion. I didn’t
really feel homesick then.
The school here is really good. You have the opportunity to
choose your classes and teachers are very good – and of course, there are no
beatings! I didn’t have any problems at school, everyone is so nice.
After I graduate from High School I want to go to college
and study even harder than now and become a good doctor. It has been my dream
since I was a little girl because I really like helping others, it makes me so
happy. But sometimes I feel like being a lawyer to help seek justice because in
so many places in the world there is a lot of unfairness. After all, all I
really want to do is help people.

story:
The Wandering Cheesemonger: An Education in Cheese 


My name is Grace Mooney, and I grew up in Madison, Wisconsin. I began working with and selling goat milk cheese (fromage de chèvre) with Anne Topham at Fantome Farm at the Madison Downtown Farmers Market in 2002. I quickly became passionate about artisanal cheese production, and wanted to learn much more. In 2012, I applied for a job at Fromagination, a remarkable local cheese store in downtown Madison. I have continued to work and learn at Fromagination throughout the years, and Ken Monteleone, the owner of Fromagination, has inspired and supported me in my love of all things cheese, as Annie Topham continues to mentor me in the cheese world.

In the summer of 2013, I found an internship working on a farm called Chèvrerie de la Baie in northern France. I had the opportunity to learn about and participate in their goat milk cheese production, while the owner, Marisa Thomas, focused her energy on their new venture; buffalo mozzarella. I then moved on to spend a semester in Paris studying at the Sorbonne and interning at a small cheese store called La Fermerie. 

Although I have had some incredibly rewarding and educational experiences working with cheese, I know I have only scraped the surface of what I can learn. I want to begin to develop and hone my cheese knowledge so that I can use it to pursue a career with cheese. I am creating my own 'cheese education', traveling to the some of the most important cheese production sites in the world to learn the things that I will need to know to successfully work with cheese.

This summer, after I graduate from Vassar College, I plan to return to France to begin the next phase of my cheese education. I will first spend two months at the Chèvrerie de la Baie, this time both continuing to work with the fromage de chèvre, and working with the production of their buffalo mozzarella. For the second part of my trip, I will then return to Paris to work again at La Fermerie 3 days a week as an intern, learning more about French cheeses and developing relationships with producers. I also will take biweekly trips to visit important cheese producers as well as small farms to expand my base of knowledge.

My Blog: The Wandering Cheesemonger

Each week, I will post on my blog, thewanderingcheesemonger.tumblr.com, detailing the tasting notes and production style of a cheese I have experienced, a farm I have visited, or a part of my cheese story. This will help both to solidify my  'cheese education' and to disseminate the information that I gather on my travels. Through the blog, you can follow my adventures and learn about my experiences working at the farm, the cheeses I taste and help to sell in Paris, and the farms and dairies that I visit throughout Europe.

Funding Challenges

Unfortunately, due to the almost impossible nature of obtaining a French work visa, I will be working as an unpaid intern at both the farm and the cheese store. My room and board are covered while on the farm, but transportation, lodging in Paris, and food will add up quickly, particularly with the current exchange rate between dollars and the Euro ($1 is approximately equal to .87 euros).

My approximate costs for the trip is as follows:

Travel to and from France: $2000

Transportation to and from the Chevrerie de la Baie: $250

Lodging in Paris at $750/month: $2250

Food/Expenses in Paris: $3,000

Educational Cheese Travels from Paris: $2,500*

*I set the cost of traveling to visit different cheese production centers around Europe at $2,500 because I believe that I can visit different important cheese locations about every two weeks with this budget. However, if I raise money beyond my goal, I will be able to visit, learn about, and blog about more cheeses! 

Why Help?

I think of this trip as my 'education in cheese', an opportunity to learn everything I need to pursue my dreams. Some day, I hope to follow in the steps of Ken at Fromagination and own my own cheese store--but that is going to require a lot of work. The first step, though, is to build the base of knowledge that will allow me to select and care for the best cheeses, just like Fromagination does. 
This educational experience is extremely important to me, and to succeed in this venture, the wonderful Ken Monteleone at Fromagination has offered to advise, collaborate with, and support me in funding the trip. When you donate to support me here, you will receive one of our exclusive gifts from Fromagination, which Ken and I have collaborated to create specifically for the Wandering Cheesemonger campaign. The opportunity to learn about cheese and cement the education I have recieved at Fromagination over the years is the dream of a lifetime, and your donation will be truly appreciated.

If you want to learn more about Fromagination, Fantome Farm, Chèvrerie de la Baie, or The Wandering Cheesemonger, check out our websites:

www.fromagination.com

www.thewanderingcheesemonger.tumblr.com

www.chevrerie-delabaie.com

http://www.fantomefarm.com/index.htm

story:
(español abajo) 

The local interest in our projects is increasing every year, last year we constructed 3 parks in Chiapas and this year we have already completed four, have one underway and 2 more in the works! As interest grows so does our need for materials, we need your help to keep building! Although the construction is fun, it is not always easy. We constantly deal with electricity problems, broken tools, overheated drills, finding and transporting tires and of course working in the heat of southern Mexico´s dry season.Thankfully none of these challenges have stopped us yet! 

Building creative playgrounds using recycled tires is an effective way to expand awareness and implementation of sustainable practices throughout the world. We believe, and educators agree, that by focusing on cognitive development through play, we are giving kids the best tools possible to solve the complicated economical, environmental and humanitarian challenges facing their communities, and all of us, in our interconnected world today. Playgrounds are a first, simple step in fostering the strong, creative and effective leaders of tomorrow that we need.

In what ways do our playgrounds affect local communities?

  • Community: We don't build playgrounds for communities, we help communities build playgrounds for themselves.  Through the planning and building of the park, community members gain confidence, build connections and see first-hand what collective work can accomplish.  With the building of a park, the communities secure a safe public space for generations to come. making a lasting symbol of deep respect for the children and sustaining the needs of their growing minds. 
  • Education: Research shows that free and creative play is essential to early childhood development, particularly cognitive abilities. Children who are provided safe spaces to play, explore, experiment and be kids are shown to have improved school attendance, perform better in classes, and adapt more easily to the challenges of life. 
  • Health: Discarded tires serve as mosquito breeding grounds and the Malaria, Dengue fever and diseases they carry.  When we repurpose tires for playgrounds we ensure that the tires drain properly, helping to reduce mosquito populations.
  • Environment: Around the world there are rapidly growing mountains of discarded used tires.  Recycling programs do not exist in many places and tires last for hundreds, perhaps thousands, of years.  Our program looks at this problem as an opportunity. Tires make a great building material, especially for playgrounds, being strong, waterproof, and soft. 

In addition to providing a fun learning environment for children, these projects also provide an incredible culturally rich service experience for volunteers. This year RISE Now´s playground builders are a diverse group ranging from ages 17 to 65 who come from the United States, Canada, Mexico, and Spain.  Some are first time travelers and others seasoned globe trotters. No matter the age or background all of us share a unique travel experience that differs drastically from that of a backpacking tourist. Sharing home cooked meals with local families, conversing with a hundred excited children at the same time, explaining to the taxi driver why you're covered in paint and carrying a shovel, the adventures are endless and the service experience truly fulfilling.

¨Dedicating so much time and hard work for the benefit of others has been extremely rewarding, especially to see the uncertainty and skepticism of the children and their parents transform into excitement and gratitude.¨
-Chad Pickett, USA

-Nuria, Spain


"Every piece of this experience has been a gift, especially working with so many wonderful people to transform spaces into concentrated pockets of light."
-Audrey Stewart, USA

 "Being part of these projects has showed me what we can do for children when we work together. It has brought me great joy and much gratitude for what we have. The smiles on the children's faces are priceless."


-Yves Parent, B.C. Canada

100% of the funds raised through this campaign will be used to:

Buy nuts, bolts, chain, paint, wood, other construction supplies, provide small stipends to local workers and cover some basic travel expenses for our site director.  Each playground costs around a thousand dollars in materials.  We hope to build six this winter. 



RISE Now is a volunteer-run 501c3 nonprofit organization dedicated  to working for the advancement of sustainable communities around the world. We aim to research, teach and practice sustainable techniques and technologies that address human needs in consideration of the whole ecosystem and the finite resources of our planet. We believe now is the time to rise to the challenges facing people and societies in order to assure a sustainable future for generations to come. It will take all of us and we need your help!

This year RISE Now´s playground builders are a diverse group ranging from ages 17 to 65 who come from the United States, Canada, Mexico, and Spain.  Some are first time travelers and others seasoned globe trotters. No matter the age or background all of us share a unique travel experience that differs drastically from that of a backpacking tourist. Sharing home cooked meals with local families, conversing with a hundred excited children at the same time, explaining to the taxi driver why you're covered in paint and carrying a shovel, the adventures are endless and the service experience truly fulfilling.
¨Dedicating so much time and hard work for the benefit of others has been extremely rewarding, especially to see the uncertainty and skepticism of the children and their parents transform into excitement and gratitude.¨-Chad Pickett, USA

-Nuria, Spain

"Every piece of this experience has been a gift, especially working with so many wonderful people to transform spaces into concentrated pockets of light."-Audrey Stewart, USA

 "Being part of these projects has showed me what we can do for children when we work together. It has brought me great joy and much gratitude for what we have. The smiles on the children's faces are priceless."
-Yves Parent, B.C. Canada

 100% of the funds raised through this campaign will be used to:
Buy nuts, bolts, chain, paint, wood, other construction supplies, provide small stipends to local workers and cover some basic travel expenses for our site director.  Each playground costs around a thousand 
dollars in materials.  We hope to build six this winter. 


RISE Now is a volunteer-run 501c3 nonprofit organization dedicated  to working for the advancement of sustainable communities around the world. We aim to research, teach and practice sustainable techniques and technologies that address human needs in consideration of the whole ecosystem and the finite resources of our planet. We believe now is the time to rise to the challenges facing people and societies in order to assure a sustainable future for generations to come. It will take all of us and we need your help!

story:
Chi siamo: 

Siamo un gruppo di giovani studenti e ricercatori appassionati di Scienza e pensiamo sia necessario renderla accessibile a tutti, superando il muro dei tecnicismi. 

Per questo abbiamo fondato l'Associazione di volontari RagionevolMente. Promuoviamo la corretta informazione scientifica, favoriamo lo scambio di idee e conoscenze e ci impegnamo a contrastare la disinformazione tramite conferenze, dibattiti e workshop aperti a tutti.

RagionevolMente è un'associazione no-profit: Se le donazioni dovessero superare le spese, contribuirai a sostenere i nostri progetti futuri.

Cosa vogliamo fare: 

Stiamo organizzando il nostro primo evento in Trentino Alto Adige, nelle città di Bolzano e Trento. L'iniziativa fa parte del progetto nazionale "CapiAmo il Pianeta" promosso dal movimento culturale Italia Unita per la Scienza: una serie di conferenze, incontri e campagne di sensibilizzazione che, per il terzo anno consecutivo, avrà luogo in tutta Italia dal 18 al 23 Maggio. 

A Bolzano coinvolgeremo la cittadinanza con due eventi divulgativi:

  • "Vita agli estremi: la natura insegna": una conferenza serale per avventurarsi nel mondo di piante, animali e batteri che sopravvivono dove sembrerebbe impossibile sopravvivere.
    • Adattamento e vita negli ambienti acquatici - Dr.ssa Roberta Bottarin (Vicedirettore Istituto per l'Ambiente Alpino, EURAC)

    • Vita oltre l'atmosfera: viaggio nell'astrobiologia - Dr. Luigi Borruso (Ricercatore in Microbiologia ambientale, Libera Università di Bolzano)

  • "Baby-Batteri": un workshop rivolto ai genitori in cui analizzeremo il ruolo dei micro-organismi nei primi anni di vita del bambino.

A Trento, in collaborazione con il gruppo locale, proporremo:

  • un conferenza pomeridiana aperta a tutti, in cui cercheremo di capire cosa sono gli organismi geneticamente modificati, i loro utilizzi attuali e potenziali e il loro impatto sulla società;
  • diversi piccoli eventi-satellite - alcuni rivolti ai bambini, altri ad un pubblico più adulto - che toccheranno argomenti di interesse scientifico.

Come puoi aiutarci:

  • Puoi aiutarci a coprire le spese per sale, stampa di volantini e manifesti; ci piacerebbe anche offrire un rinfresco durante gli eventi. Il tuo sostegno economico metterà le ali al progetto!
  • Puoi diffondere la nostra campagna di crowdfunding invitando amici e colleghi a cliccare su: http://igg.me/at/ragionevolmente
  • Puoi seguire la nostra pagina Facebook, rimanendo sempre aggiornato sulle nostre attività!
  • Puoi inviarci idee e commenti a idee@ragionevolmente.it

story:
Wer wir sind und was wir tun

Wir sind ARES, eine kleine Non-Profit-Organisation in Maputo, der Hauptstadt Mosambiks im südlichen Afrika. Boia, der Direktor und Psychologe, Fatima, eine Psychologin und Dino der Projektleiter, sind das Leitungsteam. Colette und Nicole helfen aus der Schweiz beim Spenden sammeln und haben diese Crowd Funding-Kampagne lanciert.

Wir setzten uns in Mosambik für den Schutz von Kindern vor sexueller Ausbeutung ein und kämpfen damit gegen eine der grausamsten Formen von Gewalt.

Wie tun wir das?

1. Mit Hilfe einer interaktiven Erlebnisausstellung arbeiten wir mit Primarschulklassen. Wir klären die Kinder altersgerecht über ihren Körper auf, bringen ihnen bei, ihrem Gefühl zu vertrauen, Nein zu sagen und Hilfe zu holen. Kurz: wir stärken ihr Selbstwertgefühl und ihre Abwehrstrategien.

2. Wir informieren die Eltern und Lehrer, wie sie selbst die Prävention im Erziehungsalltag integrieren können und stärken sie so in ihrer Erziehungsfunktion. Mit Hilfe eines pädagogischen Manuals können Lehrer die präventive Arbeit im Unterricht fortsetzen.

3. Wir sensibilisieren und vernetzen die lokalen Schlüsselpersonen (Polizei, Schulleiter, Elternvertreter, Quartierchefs, Beratungsstellen etc.) untereinander und mit den Eltern. So stärken wir  das Schutzsystem nachhaltig. Denn: Wissen und starke Strukturen sind der beste Kinderschutz.   

4. Wir bieten Opfern pychologische und juristische Beratung, damit ihnen bestmöglichst geholfen werden kann. Das Projekt konnte schon viele Fälle von sexueller Gewalt ans Tageslicht bringen.

Mehrere freiwillige und erfahrene Projekthelfer sorgen für eine sorgfältige Durchführung des Projekts. Speziell ausgebildete Animatorinnen arbeiten mit den Kindern, Eltern und Lehrpersonen. Kinderschutzexperten arbeiten mit den Schlüsselpersonen in der lokalen Community.

Das Projekt konnte seit 2011 mit Erfolg in vielen Schulen Maputo's durchgeführt werden. Es hat aus einem Tabuthema ein Gesprächsthema gemacht. Doch noch viele Schulklassen warten darauf, auch teilnehmen zu dürfen.

Mit deiner Hilfe können wir mit dem Projekt in weitere Schulen gehen!

Warum Prävention sexueller Gewalt wichtig ist

Täglich werden Kinder in Mosambik Opfer von sexueller Gewalt - für die Betroffenen eine einschneidende Erfahrung mit oftmals langfristigen Folgen. Doch die meisten Fälle kommen nicht ans Tageslicht, weil die Opfer aufgrund von Angst und Scham schweigen, oder niemand ihnen Glauben schenkt. Verschiedene Mythen fördern den Missbrauch in Mosambik, etwa dass AIDS durch Sex mit einer Jungfrau geheilt werden könne. Auch verlangen Lehrpersonen von den Schülerinnen und Schülern Sex als Gegenleistung für gute Noten. Schliesslich kommt es häufig vor, dass minderjährige Mädchen an erwachsene Männer verheiratet werden. Erschwerend kommt hinzu, dass Sexualität und sexuelle Gewalt in Mosambik Tabu-Themen sind und die Kinder deshalb kaum über ihre Rechte und über Sexualität aufgeklärt werden. 

Was du uns gibst & was du bekommst

Je mehr Geld wir sammeln, desto mehr Schulen können am Projekt teilnehmen. Pro Schulklasse brauchen wir nur 130 USD. Unser Kampagnenziel sind Mittel für mindestens 100 Schulklassen, also 13'000 USD.

Wenn du das Projekt unterstützt, geben wir dir etwas zurück:

  • bei 10 USD: ein riesiges Dankeschön und Dankbarkeit von den Kindern in Maputo
  • bei 30 USD: Ein typisch mosambikanisches Kunsthandwerk: mit modernen farbigen Mustern bemalte Hülle der Massalafrucht als Dekoobjekt 
  • bei 130 USD: ein mosambikanischer Abend mit typischen Speisen
  • bei 500 USD: ein Skype-Gespräch mit Boia, dem Gründer und Geschäftsleiter von ARES. Er ist Mosambikaner und spricht fliessend Deutsch
  • bei 4'000 USD: ein Projektbesuch vor Ort inkl. Unterkunft (ohne Übernahme der Reisekosten)

Was dein Beitrag bewirkt

ARES ist jederzeit bereit: Ausstellung, geschulte Animatoren, Transporter, Lehrermanual - alles ist vorhanden. Damit das Projekt in weitere Schulen gehen kann, braucht es deinen Beitrag. Denn so kann ARES die Löhne der Mitarbeitenden, Fotokopien der Arbeitsblätter für den Unterricht und das Benzin für den Transport bezahlen. Pro Klasse braucht es wie gesagt nur 130 USD.

Mit wenig Aufwand können wir viel bewirken. Eine unabhängige Evaluation hat dem Projekt gute Noten ausgestellt. Deine Spende trägt dazu bei, dass Kinder gestärkt werden, Eltern und Lehrer aufgeklärt und zur präventiven Erziehung befähigt werden, Opfern geholfen wird und das lokale Schutzsystem gestärkt werden kann.  sodass die Kinder in Mosambik nicht Opfer von sexueller Gewalt werden.

    Andere Wege, wie du helfen kannst

    Wenn du keine Möglicheit hast, das Projekt mit einem Geldbeitrag zu unterstützen, bist du uns auch eine grosse Hilfe, wenn du:

    •  mit deiner Familie, deinen Freunden und Bekannten über unser Projekt sprichst und sie zur Unterstützung der Kampagne motivierst.
    • diese Seite per Email, Facebook, Twitter oder andere deiner Kanäle verbreitest mit einem Spendenaufruf versiehst.

      Wir danken dir schon jetzt für deine wertvolle Unterstützung!


      Video: Der Beitrag im mosambikanischen Fernsehen (auf Portugiesisch) vermittelt Eindrücke des Projekts.

      Erprobt und weit gereist: von Deutschland über die Schweiz nach Mosambik

      Das Ausstellungsprojekt wurde ursprünglich in Deutschland beim Präventionsbüro Petze in Kiel entwickelt (Echt Klasse!) und geht seither mit Erfolg an Deutsche Schulen.
      Danach hat es die Stiftung Kinderschutz Schweiz in die Schweiz geholt und bietet es seit bald zehn Jahren an Schweizer Primarschulen an. Mit grossem Erfolg. Viele Kantone haben das Projekt "Mein Körper gehört mir!" bereits in ihr ständiges Programm aufgenommen.
      Im 2010 hat der Verein ARES das Projekt nach Mosambik geholt. Es wurde kulturell adaptiert, sodass es für den mosambikanischen Kontext funktioniert. Und es funktioniert tatsächlich. Eine unabhängige Evaluation hat dem Projekt sehr gute Noten ausgestellt. Aufgrund seines niederschwelligen Ansatzes schafft es das Projekt, ein Tabuthema wie sexuelle Gewalt in Mosambik auf's Tapet zu bringen. Statt Berührungsängsten begegnen wir Neugier und Lernfreude. Die beste Voraussetzung, dass die Botschaften nachhaltige Wirkung entfalten können.

story:
Ian Curtis Museum

Hi, my name is Zak Davies and I've been a Joy Division fan for a good chunk of my life! The way anyone can connect with their lyrics and how the tunes can't help but get stuck in your head has made them a major part of my life.  As important as every member of Joy Division was to the band, one member that made the difference was Ian Curtis. The troubled yet gifted singer and lead guitarist has impacted upon so many peoples lives.

Recently his final home and the place where he spent his final moments has gone up for sale in Macclesfield and rather than it be taken by developers or sold for development, we feel a place with such cultural significance with such an important man attached deserves to be made into a museum and somewhere that Joy Division fans from around the world can come to pay respects and learn about Ian Curtis.

By donating you would help keep Joy Division and Ian Curtis alive through further generations and help provide somewhere for their millions of fans to meet and discover more.

What We Need & What You Get

For the museum we need a minimum of £150,000. This breaks down as so:

  • £115,000 on the purchase of the historic property
  • £30,000 on the renovation of the property to its original interior
  • £5,000 on any legal costs and just incase something goes wrong
Any extra funds made will go to doing the renovation to a higher standard and generally making the project easier and better for all people!
For your donation you get the good feeling of knowing you helped towards the first ever museum towards the legend of Ian Curtis. Also, the more you donate, the better the perk you get so please dig as deep as you possibly can!

The Impact

The project can and will make such a difference

  • It will raise awareness and educate future generations on the music and life of Ian Curtis and allow existing fans the experience to walk the same floorboards as the man himself.
  • It will also bring tourism to the area of Macclesfield.
  • Its a project that has never been attempted before and you can be there to start it off!

Risks & Challenges

Along the way we're going to have some hurdles to overcome but with your support we can overcome these with ease! These are:

  • Purchasing the house may be of difficulty as we are limited to the amount given to us through you guys and it may sell before then
  • The council may refuse the planning needed for renovation
  • Any planning permission may be fought by local residents
We can overcome these fairly easily with your help. The purchasing of the house will definitely happen with lots of support so thats down to you guys. The council will definitely agree to the project if we can put forward enough evidence that it will help the local area which it will as Joy Division fans from around the world will bring the tourism to us. If the council approve the renovation the local residents shouldn't be a problem as we then have the legal authority to do so. Also, after the build there should be no disruption to their day to day lives.

Other Ways You Can Help

We get that not everyone can donate but that doesn't mean you can't help! You can always:

  • Tell everyone you know about our project. The more noise, the more likely we are to get this done
  • And share our project with the share tool. The internet is such an amazing way to help us start sharing Ian Curtis and his museum
