story:
Short Summary

When I was a child most all the images I saw of black people in history were subservient and negative. Everything from Pigmies running around obeying Tarzan to Step-n-Fetchit characters who resembled the buffoon-like tattletale from Harriet Beecher Stowe’s ‘Uncle Tom’s Cabin.’ I saw very few images and heard even fewer stories of the positive exploits of enslaved Africans or those formerly enslaved.

I was never told that the real McCoy’s family escaped from slavery in Kentucky to Ontario Canada where Elijah McCoy was born free; that he returned to the U.S. and that his genius for invention would make his name synonymous with all things authentic. I was never taught that the REAL McCOY was a black man.

I wasn’t told that the very first commodity ever traded on Wall Street were black people. I was never properly introduced to the fact that black people provided the impetus for this country from its inception. I never knew that people of color provided the brains and the brawn that made this country so great.

Diamonds From Coal is an educational tool that brings truth to light and focuses its beams on those upon whose shoulders we stand. It shines on the likes of United States Marshall ‘Bass Reeves’ who was the “First” Lone Ranger, Louis Latimer without whom there would be no light bulb and Granville T. Woods who holds more than 50 patents at the U.S. Patent and Trademark office and who is almost singularly responsible for the use of electricity as we know it today.

Ancestors Remembered/Diamonds From Coal brings the stories I was never told to life.

It builds character in young people of color and raises self esteem. 


What We Need & What You Get

Help Us Raise Self Esteem among African Americans and throughout the African Diaspora

● With your help we will expand the Diamonds From Coal Interactive Learning Series into a full-fledged curriculum that meets all common core standards

● We need $10,000 to pay for artist, print production, studio production, duplication and initial distribution fees.

● In addition, your funds will allow the Ancestors Remembered/Diamonds From Coal Series to expand to radio and ip/TV distribution. It is our intention to convert the program into a series of staged productions that tour the United States.

● We need funds to help with marketing and travel expenses to pitch the product, through demonstration, to high schools, colleges and churches across the country.

● Your initial funding will help us eventually expand our marketing base beyond the borders of North America and allow us to impact the entire globe.


The Impact

The Ancestors Remembered/Diamonds From Coal Interactive Listening Learning Project is a series of short-story books with accompanying CD/MP3 soundtracks, a lesson plan plus an action plan that motivates African Americans and people of color to learn more about themselves. It infuses them with an emotional attachment to success.

Volume 1 has seven (7) narrative stories with relevant poetry that grasp the listener/reader and encourages them to do better socially, educationally and economically. The narrative stories are performed theatrically in the vernacular of those 18th, 19th and 20th century African Americans who shaped and molded the direction of this country. The stories are a blend of factual data and fiction that make for lively discussion and healthy research projects which help raise the self-esteem of each participant.

In keeping with the Amistad Commission’s mandate this project has a performance art component with an innovative educational process that is challenging, engaging and inspiring. It has the clinical support of several academicians who tested the project with their students. The seven volume series will be a major instrument in strengthening and enriching the lives of those in marginalized African American communities by using a cutting-edge modality that shifts the thinking of the black population while fostering ingenuity and productivity.

The project involves further research and development of the 49 written stories, including they’re subsequent publication and distribution. It will also involve project promotion that would include attending conferences and conventions in major cities with large concentrations of African Americans. This innovative public-education project uses the arts to educate as a cultural enrichment medium to affect positive social change.

Purpose

The purpose of the Ancestors Remembered-Diamonds From Coal Interactive Listening Series is to raise self-esteem among African American students from 13 to 26 years old, from middle school through graduate courses.  The focal point of the series is to abate the high levels of crime, violence, sexual promiscuity, extreme incarceration rates and toxic levels of substance abuse found in the African American community. 

We accomplish this goal by providing an educational program that incorporates ancient African wisdom, poetry, modern hip-hop culture, creative writing, theatrical interpretation and 21st century internet technology. This will develop positive and productive young American citizens.  The program has also been tested with incarcerated youth age 13 to 26 with highly favorable results.

There is a national need for more positive images of African American ancestry, particularly as it applies to youth and young adults in America’s inner cities and some rural areas.  Low test scores, high dropout rates, escalating substance abuse, mounting reports of irresponsible sexual behavior, soaring incidents of crime and violence, and disproportionately high incarceration rates have become almost common place within many African American communities. These self-destructive behaviors can be directly associated with low self-esteem and little-to-no interest in educational advancement. This program addresses those needs at the cognitive level and is a conduit for social change.


Risks & Challenges

Every black child, whether born in America or migrated from somewhere else, is at risk. One need only listen to any evening news story located in any major city and see horror played out in the streets. The risk is of losing one more precious soul to senseless crime and violence because of self hate and low self esteem.

The challenge is use every social network and media outlet possible to reverse the fatal disease brought on by miss-education. The challenge lies in getting people concerned enough to do something about it. Far too long our apathy has made us complicit in our own destruction and the time is now to make some drastic course corrections. We must place a higher value on our own culture, our own customs and our own traditions.  


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to support this financially, I understand. Believe me, one of the side effects of miss-education is poverty. Indeed we have been trained away from wealth and prosperity. So if you are not able to contribute monetarily, then please pass this campaign on to those you believe will be supportive. Your genuine goodwill and support can be just as rewarding as a ten dollar contribution. I thank you in advance for your time and attention.
story_txt:
Short Summary 

When I was a
child most all the images I saw of black people in history were subservient and
negative. Everything from Pigmies running around obeying Tarzan to
Step-n-Fetchit characters who resembled the buffoon-like tattletale from
Harriet Beecher Stowe’s ‘Uncle Tom’s Cabin.’ I saw very few images and heard
even fewer stories of the positive exploits of enslaved Africans or those
formerly enslaved. 
I was never
told that the real McCoy’s family escaped from slavery in Kentucky to Ontario
Canada where Elijah McCoy was born free; that he returned to the U.S. and that
his genius for invention would make his name synonymous with all things
authentic. I was never taught that the REAL McCOY was a black man.
I wasn’t
told that the very first commodity ever traded on Wall Street were black
people. I was never properly introduced to the fact that black people provided
the impetus for this country from its inception. I never knew that people of
color provided the brains and the brawn that made this country so great.

story:
YOUR SUPPORT WILL GO TO MEDICATION, FOOD and EDUCATION for ORPHANS of the 2014-15 EBOLA OUTBREAK

Hello! My name is Joseph Hindogbae Kposowa, but most people call me Hindo. I am a youth leader in my community (Bumpe Ngao Chiefdom in Southern Sierra Leone), where I lead a team of youngsters and teachers developing grassroots strategies for confronting local challenges. My primary focus is to ensure quality education and health, and to foster community mobilization for development.

Bumpe Ngao Chiefdom had 47 confirmed Ebola cases and 20 deaths -- leaving a lot of young orphans from 1-14 years of age. Children were less impacted by Ebola and had greater chances of survival. As a result, many of these children lost their fathers, who were bread winners and pillars for their families. Relatives cannot provide well for these children to go to school, receive medication, or even receive the food they need to thrive. Many women lost their husbands, and they are seriously traumatized and struggling to raise their children under these extreme circumstances.

These children are leaders of tomorrow. Meeting their need for food, medication and education will improve the lives of these orphans significantly. They have survived the infection and know the bitterness of the outbreak! Your support will help them grow up to be leaders who face community challenges with solutions for their people, and who give back to those who cared for them during their moments of struggle.

Be part of these emerging leaders' growth! We will keep you updated on how these children are doing in their education through our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Global-Education-and-Justice Network/303984359807190?ref=aymt_homepage_panel

READ THE ORPHANS' STORY:

1.  Charlie (3 years old) and Solomon Abdulai Jr (6 years old) lost both parents to Ebola in Kaniya Village. Their late parents, Gbessay Abdulai (25) and Father (36) died in the Ebola struggle after their mother Gbessay contracted the disease. Charlie and Solomon are now staying with their grandfather, Solomon Abdulai (68) who struggles to provide and care for Charlie and Solomon. Charlie and Solomon are most times left alone because everyone in the community still attaches stigmas to their condition, so they won't carry the boys or allow their kids to play with them.

2.  Aruna (5), Baindu (8), Umaru (12) and Duada Mansaray (14) lost their mother and father three years ago before the Ebola outbreak. Their grandmother Bintu Mansaray (60) who was caring for them, died of Ebola after washing someone who died of Ebola in Baomahun village. In Baomahun village, 20 people were infected, with 12 deaths and 8 survivors.  Aruna, Baindu, Umaru and Duada are now staying with their uncle, Brima Mansaray (35), a farmer who already has a family of 11 to support.  

3.  Jennifer (2), Jamah (9), and Matilda Williams (12) lost their mother, Gloria Williams, to Ebola in Kaniya Village where 12 people were infected. Their father, Solomon Williams (48) is a farmer. At two years of age, Jennifer needs nutritional help to grow. She needs toys to replace her mom's lost presence. Her father Solomon is struggling to care for her whilst the farm work doubles for him at this particular season.

4.  Jolly (5) and Lamin (9) lost their father, John Williams (50) to Ebola in Bunimbu Village. Their late father was a driver and the bread winner of the home. Jolly and Lamin's mother, Martha (45) is finding it very difficult to afford feeding them as she struggles with the psychological trauma of losing her husband.

5.  Regina (14), John (12), Martin (9) lost their mother, Bumpe-Nya Kindo (52) who was a single parent. Regina, John and Martin are presently struggling on their own since their mom separated from their father five years before her death. Their father is yet to accept them.

6.  Edna Ngaoja (7) lost her mother, Edna Ngaoja (53) to Ebola. Edna was a single parent caring for her daughter Edna. Edna (the daughter) is now staying with her uncle, Mohamed Ngaoja (42), a farmer.

7.  Jeneba -(1) and Sammah (5) lost their father Lahai Sam (a farmer) to Ebola in Baomahun Village. Jeneba, a year old baby, needs support with a nutritional diet and medication to grow well. Their mother separated with their lost father few months ago, leaving Jeneba and Sammah with their paternal aunt, Jeneba Sammah (42).

8.  Madiana (4) and Alieu (7) lost their father Mohamed Kamara (27) to Ebola in Baomahun village. Their mother left their lost father and disowned Madiana and Alieu two years ago. Madiana is presently malnourished, as she is not getting enough food. They are staying with their uncle Alusine Gbondo (32) who has 8 children of his own. Please support Madiana and Alieu.

9.  John (8) and Mikailu (11) lost their mother, Musu Kamanda (55) to Ebola in Baomahun village. The late Musu, John and Mikailu were deserted by their father 5 years ago. Their elder sister, Fatmata (35) is a single parent caring for John, Mikailu and 10 others.

10.  Jillo (2) lost her father, Munda Moriba (28) to Ebola in Kamarun village where 5 people were infected with 4 deaths. Jillo's mother is presently 7 months pregnant.

11.  Aminata (1) lost her father, Mohamed Bangura to Ebola in Yoni Village. Aminata is care for by her grandmother, Yeawa Ernest.

12.  Nancy Mansaray (12) lost her father, Lansana Mansaray to Ebola in Kpetema village. Nancy's mother deserted the late Lansana two years before Lansana's death. Nancy is staying with her grandmother, Mary Musa.

13.  Alusine Momoh (10) lost his father Musa Momoh (50) who was a farmer. The widow, Asatu Momoh, is 38.

14.  Adama (1), Sheku (6), Duada (7) and Safiatu (10) lost their father, Steven Mattia (29) to Ebola in Baomahun Village. Their mother Fatamata, is 35.

OUR NEEDS

A donation of $10 contributes to purchasing learning materials

A donation of $25  contributes to medication

A donation of $50 contributes to purchasing food

A donation of $500 purchases a gari processing machine to sustain support for the orphans

All donations will go to filling a wide array of needs for the well-being of the orphans. Food, toys, medication and learning materials shall be given to guardians of these orphans.

Half of the project donation goal will support the orphans with food and medication.

IMPACTS

This support will encourage and save orphans and their surviving parents or new caregivers from psychological stress. We will also ensure proper growth for orphans under 5 who lost their mothers in the Ebola crisis in Bumpe Ngao Chiefdom.

We will also ensure sustainable support to educate the orphans.

HOW YOU CAN HELP

Please help to support the orphans by donating money or in kind support. No contribution is too small! Help us meet the need for food, medication and education for these orphans.

Please also help us share this page and connect with organizations or charities that may be interested in helping to support these children.

You can also keep us posted via email: itsjhindo@gmail.com or Jennifer@principledlearning.org.  We are grateful for your support.

story:
Our school meets the unique needs of children with learning disabilities. We have designed a classroom setting ideal for individualized learning. This is accomplished with a maximum class size of 10 students, class placement based on skill level rather than grade level, and non-traditional teaching approaches. Our school environment is markedly different from that of any other school. Public schools, for example, do not have the manpower, resources, or flexibility to truly implement the services outlined in the child’s IEP (Individual Education Plan.) Although providing these services is required by law, students are not receiving their due assistance. Without accommodations to compensate for the disability, the child is set up for failure. Such conditions forced the majority of our parents to seek other education options, no matter what the cost.

With an enrollment of close to 60 students, we have outgrown our current facility. We have already interviewed over 30 families who would like to place their children in our school. Our only option, however, is to place them on a waiting list. The need for this specialized learning environment continues to grow each day. As parents learn about our personalized approach to education, they feel a sense of hope; this could be the answer to their prayers. Turning away families in need is truly heartbreaking. For this reason, we are pursuing every possible avenue to find funding for a larger facility.

story:
LRN.FM is the best liberty-oriented audio streamed 24/7 online and via satellite, for free.  Our current satellite coverage includes North America and Central America.  Until recently, we were also on over much of Africa.  More about what happened to our signal in a moment.  

In many parts of the world, cable TV installations are non-existent or uncommon due to their high up-front and ongoing cost.  Satellite is the most common form of audio/video entertainment in these areas.  It's common for homes to already have the Ku-band dish and "Free-to-Air" receiver.  For many of the 4 billion people in the world who have no internet (over 50% of the world's population), Free-to-Air is a lifeline to the world, uncensored by the state.

Free-to-Air means that no subscription is needed to receive the channels.  They are TV or radio channels broadcast "in-the-clear", direct-to-home.  Some satellites, like Galaxy 19 over North and Central America (where LRN.FM has been heard since 2009) have hundreds of Free-to-Air channels.

Meet Ako:


Ako lives in Cameroon, Africa, where LRN.FM was available on satellite from 2012 until February of this year, at no cost to us.  Unfortunately our satellite provider ended the free ride.  Now, to continue broadcasting the message of liberty to much of Africa, we need your help.   

Ako says everyone has Ku-band dishes in Cameroon.  He has personally introduced at least two hundred of his friends to our programs and says they listen and meet regularly to discuss the topics they hear on LRN.FM.  You can listen to one of our interviews with Ako here.

Ako tells us the press is heavily restricted there, which is why many people in the country (who don't even have access to the internet) use Free-to-Air satellite receivers - to get unfiltered information and ideas from many global sources.  LRN.FM is the only channel on Free-to-Air advocating the ideas of liberty 24/7, and these ideas are inspiring people like Ako to take action. 

Who is broadcasting?
I am Ian Freeman, the creator and program director of LRN.FM.  I also host Free Talk Live, heard seven days a week live on the network.  LRN.FM features dozens of liberty-oriented shows, both in live and podcast form, uncensored.  LRN.FM was founded in 2009 for two reasons.  First, to introduce existing liberty-minded people to new shows.  Second, to provide programming to free radio stations.  Both of those things have been and continue to be accomplished.  Our new goal is to expand the availability of the satellite feed  to reach new ears globally with our ideas.

In addition to getting our signal direct-to-homes globally, We have been contacted by more than one underground FM radio station operator in North America who is taking their audio feed from our satellite channel.  Obviously given their clandestine nature, if a small number are contacting us, it's reasonable to presume there are many more who do not want to be "on the radar", and certainly not listed on our website as a radio affiliate.  These heroic activists are broadcasting the ideas of liberty into their communities 24/7.  That's great activism, made possible by our Ku-band "Free-to-Air" feed.


What's possible?

Between people around the world like Ako tuning LRN.FM in on their in-home satellite systems, to people listening in their car thanks to an AM/FM rebroadcast of our signal, there are already thousands of people in North and Central America that are hearing the ideas of liberty - many for the very first time!  It would be great to get on Free-to-Air satellite in other parts of the world, but first, we need to get back on in Africa.

Sure, anyone worldwide can listen anytime at LRN.FM, but in order to do that, they'd need to have access to the internet and know to look for us.  The internet is likely something you take for granted.  However, billions of people on Earth have no internet.  Direct-to-home satellite reaches those people, affordably.  New ears will find the message of liberty, as people are frequently "scanning the band" and sampling new channels.  That's how Ako found us.  Then, he spread the word to his friends.

It's really exciting that the ideas of freedom are reaching some of the poorest, most oppressed places on earth.  We at LRN.FM are even more excited by the idea that we could be reaching more people around the globe via satellite, with your assistance.  Here's a map showing the internet access of different countries - darker means more people have access:

and here's a map of the AMOS-5 Ku band East West beam that we were on up until February of this year:



How much will it cost?

The satellite we were on over Africa is called AMOS-5.  Getting LRN.FM back on there is best, because that's where the listeners dishes are already pointed. 

To get on AMOS-5 will cost about $22,000 for a three year agreement.


    What You Get

    The satisfaction of knowing your dollars are helping reach people worldwide with the ideas of liberty.  If you'd prefer more recognition, check out the perks like naming a satellite channel or getting an exclusive Platinum AMP pin.


    What if we raise more than is necessary?

    There are two reasons why we may end up raising more than is necessary to fund an AMOS-5 channel for three years.  First, we may be able to negotiate a better price on the channel than the quote I was given, once we can demonstrate to the satellite provider that we're ready to buy time and have the money to do so.  Plus, we may go to another provider if they don't give us a great price.  Second, we may raise more than the goal, which would be awesome.  In either case, some of the extra funds will go to fund more FTA satellite system installs in Africa.  Plus, we may be able to negotiate a discount group rate to get us more coverage over other parts of Africa not serviced by the East-West beam.


    What if we raise less than is necessary?

    We may be able to negotiate a higher monthly rate to get a yearlong agreement, to get the ball rolling and then we can fundraise further for more years.


    Are contributions tax-deductible?

    I'm no attorney, but it's my understanding that at least with the United States, donations to churches are tax-deductible even if the church is not 501-c3 status with the IRS.  Here's what the IRS says on their own website:  "You can deduct your contributions only if you make them to a qualified organization. Most organizations, other than churches and governments, must apply to the IRS to become a qualified organization."  LRN.FM is a project of the Shire Free Church, so you should be fine deducting your donation.  Don't take my word for it, though.  If you pay taxes, which I don't personally recommend, you may want do your own research.  


    What are alternative methods to contribute?

    Check or money order made out to "Free Talk Live" at 63 Emerald St. #610, Keene, NH 03431

    Bitcoin: 1AkZUyVHtVsU6ZmAu1iSDhYiXbqFgKqzbt


    Can't afford to give?

    Please share this fundraiser on your favorite social media and also share LRN.FM!

      Thanks for your consideration!
      Ian Freeman
      Program Director, LRN.FM
story_txt:
LRN.FM is the best liberty-oriented audio streamed 24/7 online and via satellite, for free.  Our current satellite coverage includes North America and Central America.  Until recently, we were also on over much of Africa.  More about what happened to our signal in a moment.  
In many parts of the world, cable TV installations are non-existent or uncommon due to their high up-front and ongoing cost.  Satellite is the most common form of audio/video entertainment in these areas.  It's common for homes to already have the Ku-band dish and "Free-to-Air" receiver.  For many of the 4 billion people in the world who have no internet (over 50% of the world's population), Free-to-Air is a lifeline to the world, uncensored by the state.
Free-to-Air means that no subscription is needed to receive the channels.  They are TV or radio channels broadcast "in-the-clear", direct-to-home.  Some satellites, like Galaxy 19 over North and Central America (where LRN.FM has been heard since 2009) have hundreds of Free-to-Air channels.
Meet Ako:




Ako lives in Cameroon, Africa, where LRN.FM was available on satellite from 2012 until February of this year, at no cost to us.  Unfortunately our satellite provider ended the free ride.  Now, to continue broadcasting the message of liberty to much of Africa, we need your help.   

Ako says everyone has Ku-band dishes in Cameroon.  He has personally introduced at least two hundred of his friends to our programs and says they listen and meet regularly to discuss the topics they hear on LRN.FM.  You can listen to one of our interviews with Ako here.


Ako tells us the press is heavily restricted there, which is why many people in the country (who don't even have access to the internet) use Free-to-Air satellite receivers - to get unfiltered information and ideas from many global sources.  LRN.FM is the only channel on Free-to-Air advocating the ideas of liberty 24/7, and these ideas are inspiring people like Ako to take action.

            and governments, must apply to the IRS to become a qualified organization."  LRN.FM is a project of the Shire Free Church, so you should be fine deducting your donation.  Don't take my word for it, though.  If you pay taxes, which I don't personally recommend, you may want do your own research.

story:
GIVING TODAY HELPS TOMORROW!

Decide how much you would like to donate to StarShine to join our XPRIZE GLEE TEAM! $1000 or more will be considered a sponsor  and included in all of our promotions for the duration of the project: 1-3 years

We have put together several "thank-you perks" to let you know how much we appreciate your tax-deductible donation. You can choose the perk per your donation amount. 

Watch our video above with Peter Diamandis explaining  the Global Learning XPRIZE !

250 million children in the world  (some in the United States) can't read, write, and perform arithmetic. We are here to change that, with you.

The Global Learning XPRIZE is a competition to build Open Source software to teach a child to read, write, and perform arithmetic, by themselves, without a teacher. Teams will compete to win $15 million in awards to build this revolutionary technology. We are building our own team, StarShine GLEE to win. Our team will include StarShine students in Phoenix, Mexico, Santa Fe, and Liberia with others from around the world, to learn how to build a real STEAM project that works!!! (STEAM = Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts and Math)

But this is not enough. We want to bring this technology to more kids in more villages, to test and improve it, to build a global community committed to eradicating illiteracy and create a world more peaceful and more prosperous.

You can be a part of this amazing moment, by contributing what you can and by joining our movement.

When you put information into your profile to contribute--if you are a sponsor ($1000 or more), use your company name as it will appear that way for the next several months for a lot of press! You can see muffintoppled.com in the funder list.


This is the only place where you can get an opportunity to have EARLY ACCESS TO THIS REVOLUTIONARY SOFTWARE  over 18 months before anyone else. See the perks.


The Impact

"[This XPRIZE] is amazing and it is putting power in the hands of people who need it the most."

– CNN

"If XPRIZE were to achieve such an ambitious goal, it wouldn’t be the first time."

– WIRED

"It could go a long, long way toward tackling the chronic shortages of schools and teachers that ultimately hurt kids' futures."

– Engadget

"If this new prize competition lives up to its early promise, we could be talking about a radically new approach to education within our lifetime."

– Washington Post


    

HERE IS YOUR BEST WAY TO PARTICIPATE:

Imagine a world where every child has the opportunity to grow and prosper, where education, technology, and knowledge are open to them, to grow them be the best they can be. For thirteen years, StarShine has had this focus in a living laboratory, K-12 campus in Phoenix, Arizona. We are now excited to spread this to the rest of the world. Without reading, writing, and arithmetic skills, this world is locked away. Books...the Internet...Wikipedia...wider education...it's time to unlock imagination through literacy and discovery.

Creating the Movement

We have created a movement, a global community of scientists, developers, advocates, designers, translators, artists, and more. We want you to be part of this movement and to put your brick in the wall in eradicating illiteracy and unlocking those minds.
We have an awesome range of perks available for you, including getting EARLY ACCESS TO THE SOFTWARE 18 months before anyone. Be able to vote on, view, or attend StarShine  with a side trip to ASU SkySong Innovation Center, where it all started; be able to be a part of the team that changed everything forever!

Can you imagine what it would have been like to have been a part of the 1st Internet team? You have a chance to be even MORE world changing!

We don't just want you to back the campaign though, we want you to join our community and be a part of making history.

We have a referral contest where you can win an all-expense paid trip to StarShine in Phoenix and help us to create the future :) You might even be invited to stay in one of our own beautiful brand-new residential teacher cottages on the StarShine Creative Community campus and experience firsthand why Phoenix is called one of America's most innovative cities!

We have built a global family to work together to support the prize and campaign, and we have 12 awesome ways in which you can join our campaign today!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help with funding at this time, you can help by being one of our on the ground cheerleaders:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

WIN A TRIP TO STARSHINE VISIONEERING

StarShine Visioneering is an annual event that is based on XPRIZE Visioneering, but instead is in Phoenix. It brings together experts, business leaders, celebrities, politicians and more to discuss our StarShine grand challenge, now of winning the Global Learning XPRIZE and how best to solve it.

It is an eclectic, exclusive group and we want to add your name to this list.

We have an awesome opportunity for you to win an expenses-paid trip to StarShine Visioneering at Carefree Resort in Carefree, Arizona, USA. Not only can you win this fantastic prize, but you can also help spread awareness of the campaign and our efforts to combat illiteracy!

The winner will also receive an exclusive limited-edition STARSHINE XPRIZE jacket, t-shirt, and cap! 

How To Participate

To win, we are running a referral competition in which the person who raises the most awareness of this crowdfunding campaign and gets the most people to visit this Indiegogo page will win the trip.

The runner-up will get the exclusive STARSHINE XPRIZE jacket, t-shirt, and cap.

Participating is simple:

  1. If you don't have an Indiegogo account, go and register one by clicking here. When you are finished, come back to this page.
  2. At the top of this page use the share buttons to share this campaign with others. You can use the social media buttons, but also the Link button to generate your unique web link that points to this page. This link helps us to ensure that we register, that you referred the person to this page. Be sure to use these links...they include the information needed for us to register your referrals!
  3. Each time you share the campaign with these links we will track them in a running tally. We will regularly update everyone with the current rankings each week in our campaign updates.
  4. Importantly, we are awarding the prize to the person who gets the most people visiting this page, so try to spread the word as far and wide as you can! Every person who clicks on your link gets you a step closer to coming to StarShine Visioneering and helps raise awareness about a truly valuable campaign!

This is how our friend Jono, Director of Global Learning XPRIZE explained their original Indiegogo link---you should read BEFORE you create your account, otherwise it won’t track right. IT SHOWS THE LINK AT THE TOP OF OUR PAGE WHICH YOU MUST PUT INTO YOUR PAGE TO TRACK CORRECTLY!!

FIND OUT MORE DETAILS OF HOW TO PARTICIPATE AND SOME TIPS AND TRICKS!

In addition to this, the top 5 people who raise money for the campaign will also get EARLY ACCESS to the software for their schools!

story:
Through Local Giving, We're Half Way to Our Goal;

This Online Effort Will Help Secure the Remainder.


Interactive Neighborhood for Kids

INK is a 501c3  non-profit agency currently located in an industrial area of Gainesville, Georgia.  The mission of INK, a unique children's museum, is to encourage children of all ages to develop their full potential through exciting hands-on learning.  INK strives through interactive exhibits, to create unique environment in which children of all ages, abilities and experiences can feel free to imagine, create and explore beyond their dreams.

For over 12 years, INK continues to provide fun, hands-on educational resources for thousands of parents, caregivers, educators and children of all ages.  In 2014, we reached over 70,000 visitors. Our exhibits and programming enable children to use their imagination and creativity in a friendly and safe environment.  Additionally, our exhibits are designed to stimulate curiosity and motivate learning.  INK provides the perfect atmosphere where children and families can have fun and learn together.

Since inception, INK has established itself as a vital educational institution in the North Georgia area.  With rapidly and consistently growing attendance, INK has become very crowded in its current space.  The physical need for expansion is clear, but it is only part of the story.  The most significant motivation for expansion is that young children in our area are not reaching their full potential during early childhood, impacting their chances for success in school and life, and their ability to contribute to the community and country. 

THE NEED:  There continues to be a growing demand for effective learning opportunities for young children and evidence proves that Children's Museums provide those opportunities.   INK has outgrown its current space.  The children of our area need a museum that can continue to serve their expanding educational and developmental needs now, and well into the future.  It's time for INK to grow, and the first step toward that goal is securing a new location for expansion. 

A NEW LOCATION:  A donor is willing to donate 3.5 acres located in the middle of our market IF we can raise $2,000,000 by the Summer of 2015 and begin construction.  We have researched many properties and this property fits all of our current and future needs.  Now is the perfect time to update, expand and have a building that the children of North Georgia can call our own.  By moving to this new more populated location, we have the potential to increase our reach to over 420,000 visitors annually.  

What We Need & What You Get

The total cost of our building project is 4.3 million dollars.  Our immediate need is 2 million dollars by August 2015 in order to have the property donated to us.  The full 2 million will go directly into the bricks and mortar of the building.  INK has already received $1 million in commitments. 
For the last five years, INK has been self sufficient with our day to day operations.  We have created means of revenue through a small admission fee, birthday party income, memberships, field trips, gift shop and pottery studio in order to cover our cost of rent, utilities, salaries and other costs.  We will be able to continue to cover those costs in the new facility.  In fact, if we can raise enough funds to pay for the total cost of the new building, the funds we were applying to our rent (1/3 of income) will be able to be used for more programming for our visitors. 
If we do not reach our goal of 2 million dollars for this location, we will continue to reserve these funds until a new location is found.

The Impact

Your contribution will make a huge difference on each child that visits our museum. Children are able to experience and learn real life skills each time they walk through our doors at INK.  Our exhibits are set up to be mock businesses that are scaled down to a  child's size.  Each child no matter their ability has the opportunity to step into the world of many different careers that are located in our community and experience what it is like to be that person.  Great examples of roles the children can become are a doctor, pilot, fireman, policeman, grocery store clerk, dairy farmers and much more.  We focus on children ages 2-12 however we find that any age has a great time at INK. 

INK supports North Georgia's youngest learners by building essential early learning skills, teaching math, science and literacy concepts, fostering creativity, innovation and critical thinking, promoting good health and active play.  Many of the activities in each room line up with curriculum from the State of Georgia and Career Clusters that are used in many states across our nation.  

INK's positive creative learning concept helps create a love for life-long learning.  We also promote growing up to do what you love and have passion for your career. This can make a huge impact in everyone's future.  

INK is now beginning our 13th year of business.  We have had an average annual growth of 10%+.  In the beginning, INK was reaching just a few families in our community and now our reach spreads over 26+ counties and has become a great destination for visitors from all over the world!  Organized field trips have come from as far as 3+ hours away to experience our learning concept.  With serving 70,000+ visitors annually, we have reached our maximum capacity at our current location.  We need more space and a location closer to a more populated location in order to reach more children eager to learn and explore.  We have people calling very often wanting to know how to create a model in their community to make this concept available to needy children in their area.  As you can see, the need is there.  We need your help to make this project happen!

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize that not everyone can contribute financially, but EVERYONE can help us make a difference.  Please spread the word about INK's Campaign to everyone you know.  Share this information on your social media pages and your contacts.  Just a click of a button can help to change a child's life.  Commit day to help us reach our goal!

This Online Effort Will Help Secure the Remainder.

Interactive Neighborhood for Kids  INK is a 501c3  non-profit agency currently located in an industrial area of Gainesville, Georgia.  The mission of INK, a unique children's museum, is to encourage children of all ages to develop their full potential through exciting hands-on learning.  INK strives through interactive exhibits, to create unique environment in which children of all ages, abilities and experiences can feel free to imagine, create and explore beyond their dreams.
For over 12 years, INK continues to provide fun, hands-on educational resources for thousands of parents, caregivers, educators and children of all ages.  In 2014, we reached over 70,000 visitors. Our exhibits and programming enable children to use their imagination and creativity in a friendly and safe environment.  Additionally, our exhibits are designed to stimulate curiosity and motivate learning.  INK provides the perfect atmosphere where children and families can have fun and learn together.
Since inception, INK has established itself as a vital educational institution in the North Georgia area.  With rapidly and consistently growing attendance, INK has become very crowded in its current space.  The physical need for expansion is clear, but it is only part of the story.  The most significant motivation for expansion is that young children in our area are not reaching their full potential during early childhood, impacting their chances for success in school and life, and their ability to contribute to the community and country.  
THE NEED:  There continues to be a growing demand for effective learning opportunities for young children and evidence proves that Children's Museums provide those opportunities.   INK has outgrown its current space.  The children of our area need a museum that can continue to serve their expanding educational and developmental needs now, and well into the future.  It's time for INK to grow, and the first step toward that goal is securing a new location for expansion. 
A NEW LOCATION:  A donor is willing to donate 3.5 acres located in the middle of our market IF we can raise $2,000,000 by the Summer of 2015 and begin construction.  We have researched many properties and this property fits all of our current and future needs.  Now is the perfect time to update, expand and have a building that the children of North Georgia can call our own.  By moving to this new more populated location, we have the potential to increase our reach to over 420,000 visitors annually.     What We Need & What You Get
The total cost of our building project is 4.3 million dollars.  Our immediate need is 2 million dollars by August 2015 in order to have the property donated to us.  The full 2 million will go directly into the bricks and mortar of the building.  INK has already received $1 million in commitments.  
For the last five years, INK has been self sufficient with our day to day operations.  We have created means of revenue through a small admission fee, birthday party income, memberships, field trips, gift shop and pottery studio in order to cover our cost of rent, utilities, salaries and other costs.  We will be able to continue to cover those costs in the new facility.  In fact, if we can raise enough funds to pay for the total cost of the new building, the funds we were applying to our rent (1/3 of income) will be able to be used for more programming for our visitors. 
If we do not reach our goal of 2 million dollars for this location, we will continue to reserve these funds until a new location is found.   The Impact Your contribution will make a huge difference on each child that visits our museum. Children are able to experience and learn real life skills each time they walk through our doors at INK.  Our exhibits are set up to be mock businesses that are scaled down to a  child's size.  Each child no matter their ability has the opportunity to step into the world of many different careers that are located in our community and experience what it is like to be that person.  Great examples of roles the children can become are a doctor, pilot, fireman, policeman, grocery store clerk, dairy farmers and much more.  We focus on children ages 2-12 however we find that any age has a great time at INK. 
INK supports North Georgia's youngest learners by building essential early learning skills, teaching math, science and literacy concepts, fostering creativity, innovation and critical thinking, promoting good health and active play.  Many of the activities in each room line up with curriculum from the State of Georgia and Career Clusters that are used in many states across our nation.  
INK's positive creative learning concept helps create a love for life-long learning.  We also promote growing up to do what you love and have passion for your career. This can make a huge impact in everyone's future.  
INK is now beginning our 13th year of business.  We have had an average annual growth of 10%+.  In the beginning, INK was reaching just a few families in our community and now our reach spreads over 26+ counties and has become a great destination for visitors from all over the world!  Organized field trips have come from as far as 3+ hours away to experience our learning concept.  With serving 70,000+ visitors annually, we have reached our maximum capacity at our current location.  We need more space and a location closer to a more populated location in order to reach more children eager to learn and explore.  We have people calling very often wanting to know how to create a model in their community to make this concept available to needy children in their area.  As you can see, the need is there.  We need your help to make this project happen!
  Other Ways You Can Help We realize that not everyone can contribute financially, but EVERYONE can help us make a difference.  Please spread the word about INK's Campaign to everyone you know.  Share this information on your social media pages and your contacts.  Just a click of a button can help to change a child's life.  Commit day to help us reach our goal!

story:
Millions of kids in the United States never get the chance to fall in love with reading, because they grow up without books of their own.  First Book addresses this head on by distributing new books to the children needing them most - 125 million and counting.  That’s why First Book is thrilled to partner with @hotdudesreading to launch "Hot Dudes Reading For A Cause."

The Dude devouring Middlemarch across from you on the train? He was probably a boy who explored Middle-Earth with Bilbo Baggins, solved mysteries with Encyclopedia Brown, and learned to count with a certain hungry caterpillar. 

@hotdudesreading is asking for your help to spread the love of reading by making a donation to First Book.  If we are able to generate $50,000 for First Book the organization will provide 20,000 new books to children in need. Additionally, we’ll be collecting photos of hometown dudes from across the country with their heads in a book and sharing these. To submit a photo email it to submissions@hotdudesreading.com or post on Twitter or Instagram and use the hashtag #HotDudesReadingForACause. 

We will showcase our favorite dudes reading across the nation at www.hotdudesreading.com.

Join us in elevating the quality of education around America. 

Donate now.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, My wife and I head up a charity from home which has been going since 2000 .We are missionaries and have a project in Uganda which we visit once a year

  • My name is Gerry and  my background is one of poverty. I am the eldest of 9 children, my parents struggled to supply food for us. I have 3 adult children now and am  proud to say that I also have 14 healthy, happy grandchildren.
  • Because of my past I feel drawn to be whatever help I can to the  poor and so have joined with a pastor in Uganda and built 2 boarding and day schools,(nursery, primary and secondary combined) along with a medical centre and church. The schools need security and so we are building a wall around the whole complex to protect the children. 
  • Your help will enable us to protect our 460 children from undesirables and also wild animals. (In June 2014 ,a cheetah came into the school grounds and killed and ate the pastor's goat which was tethered in the school grounds)

What We Need & What You Get

  • You can have a hand in being part of a project that is helping transform underprivileged children's lives. To complete the wall we need another 1500 concrete blocks as well as cement, iron bars and labour, this will cost another £4000. There are photos of the wall and schools on my Facebook page (Gerry George) ( Brighton) as the work continues we will keep you posted on Facebook 
  • The Impact

 This is your opportunity to be part of an ongoing work that is shaping and improving children's lives even if you never get a chance to go to Africa you can still be a part by helping us financially. You can be sure that every penny donated will go to the work and any extra will go to buying school supplies. 

  • We have been building in Uganda since the year 2000 and to date we have built 2 school buildings, an admin block, a boys dormitory, a large dining hall, an orphanage, a medical centre and a church  as well as digging 2 borehole wells all this has been done as the funds have come in. Check out our website at www.advanceinternational.org.uk.

Risks & Challenges


  • We started going to Uganda in 1997 and then when we became a charity 3 years later  we began to build. It was quite a culture shock at first but as we got to know the people we found them to be very loving and trusting and also needy, which captured our hearts and so began our work out there and even though we live in UK we are still able to visit the work once a year and meet up with Pastor Dan who oversees it all.
  • Our main challenge is money obviously and while we have some sponsors it would be good to have more.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Even if you cannot give in to the work we respectfully ask you to consider sharing about what we do  with your friends, get the word out for us and still be a part of a happening.
  • You can  use the Indiegogo share tools which will be a great help.

story:
French message will follow

Welcome

I grew up with a love for video games and I believe that now is the time to play more seriously. With the help of a team that believes in the importance of such a project for our society, we have decided to design a game for children (ages 8 and up), based on financial education. Why choose this topic for a game? I grew up without receiving any financial education and it was the same case for my parents. Today, as an adult with significant family responsibilities, I quickly realized how important it is to know how to manage our often hard-earned money.


This game will enable young children, as well as older children to clearly understand the mechanisms necessary for managing personal finances.

We hope we can count on your help to carry out this project that is very important to us through Indiegogo.


Thank you very much for your support,

Windor


Tooniie Land, the game

Tooniie Land leads players into an idyllic world where they must help the King restore prosperity to the island called “Tooniie Land.” This game will help players become familiar with concepts related to:


  • Savings

  • Debt

  • Spending

  • Mutual aid

  • Entrepreneurship

  • Ethics


Studies show that when financial education is introduced to children at an early age, they develop reflexes that will very useful to them in adulthood.


How to play this game ?

First, players should become familiar with the king’s different weekly missions, then select a boat that will enable them to navigate to the selected islands. They will have to manage the craft and make sure to follow a budget enabling them to carry out the various missions. Each week (everyThursday), they will receive a virtual salary that they will have to manage in keeping with their upcoming journeys. Within the game, they will become familiar with concepts related to loans, budgeting, and taxes.




What will we do with your contribution?

We are looking for C$90,000. The funds raised will be used to develop the game, namely through:


  • Design (graphics, drawings)

  • Development (coding, animation)

  • Testing and piloting (quality assurance, detecting bugs)

  • Market release (marketing, presentation to the public)


If surplus funds are raised, we will use them to work on updates and improve graphics. We also intend for teachers to use the game as a learning tool in a classroom environment.


Moreover, we would like to work on a version adapted to young adults and thus reach an older demographic.


Timeline


The team




Frequently Asked Questions

Q:Why a project on financial management and youth?

A: Managing personal finances is a very important element in an individual’s life and when this topic is introduced early on, the individual becomes better equipped to make responsible financial decisions that will have a significant, lifelong impact. According to the National Report Card on Youth Financial Literacy, 93% of youth think it is important to learn about finances. According to the same source, 50% of high school graduates are already in debt. Thus we must not delay in educating future generations on this issue.

Q: Could this game really be educational for youth?

A: We are a very small team, but we are full of creative ideas to turn games into powerful learning tools. This game will help players discover the different aspects of managing personal finances, while being fun and entertaining.


Q: Will it be possible to play this game on multiple platforms?

A: The game will be offered on iPhones, iPads, Android devices, PCs, and laptops.

Q: Will there be interaction between players?

A: We hope to develop generosity between players. They will be able to make requests by simply clicking on icons.


Q: When will the project be ready?

A: At the end of the campaign and once we have reached our goal, development will take 90 to 100 days, approximately 3 months.



****************************************************************************


Bienvenue

J’ai grandi avec un grand amour pour les jeux vidéo et je crois qu’est maintenant venu le temps de jouer plus sérieusement. Aidés d’une équipe qui croit en l’importance d’un tel projet pour la société, nous avons décidé de concevoir un jeu basé sur l’éducation financière pour des joueurs âgés de  8 ans et plus. Pourquoi un tel sujet pour un jeu ? En fait, j’ai grandi sans recevoir une quelconque éducation financière et ce fut la même chose pour mes parents. Aujourd’hui, arrivé à l’âge adulte et avec des responsabilités familiales, j’ai vite constaté qu’il est important de savoir gérer ses sous qui ont très souvent été durement gagnés.


Ce jeu permettra aux jeunes enfants, mais aussi aux plus grands de bien comprendre les mécanismes liés à la gestion des finances personnelles.


Nous espérons pouvoir compter sur vous à travers IndieGoGo afin de réaliser ce projet que nous avons à coeur.


Merci infiniment pour votre support.


Windor


Tooniie Land, le jeu

Tooniie Land est une aventure conduisant les joueurs dans un monde paradisiaque où ils devront aider le roi à ramener la prospérité au sein de l’île nommée  «Tooniie Land». Ce jeu permettra aux joueurs de se familiariser aux concepts liés à :


  • L’épargne  

  • L’endettement

  • La consommation

  • L’entraide

  • L’entrepreneurship

  • L’éthique



Les études démontrent que lorsqu’on débute l’éducation financière très tôt chez un jeune enfant, celui-ci développe des réflexes qui lui seront très utiles dans sa vie d’adulte.

Comment jouer à ce jeu ?



Les joueurs devront d’abord prendre connaissance des différentes missions du roi pour la semaine et par la suite, choisir un bateau qui leur permettra de naviguer vers les îles sélectionnées. Ils devront gérer l’ensemble de l’embarcation et s’assurer de tenir un budget leur permettant d’effectuer les différentes traversées. À toutes les semaines (chaque jeudi), ils recevront un salaire virtuel qu’ils devront gérer en fonction des prochaines traversées qu’ils réaliseront. Au sein du jeu, ils pourront se familiariser avec les concepts liés à la taxation, aux emprunts, au budget ainsi qu’aux impôts.


Que ferons-nous de votre contribution ?

Nous sommes à la recherche de 90 000$ canadien. Les fonds amassés serviront à couvrir les frais du développement du jeu :


  • Design (recherche graphique, illustrations)

  • Développement (codage, animation)

  • Test et pilotage (assurance qualité, recherche de bogues)

  • Mise en marché (marketing, présentation grand public)



En cas où des surplus seraient amassés, nous utiliserions ces fonds supplémentaires afin de travailler sur des mises à jour et des améliorations au niveau graphique. Nous aimerions aussi permettre à des enseignants d’utiliser le jeu comme outil d’apprentissage dans un contexte scolaire.


Nous aimerions également travailler sur une version adaptée aux jeunes adultes et ainsi toucher les personnes plus âgées.

Le planning du projet 



L'équipe



Vos questions

Q :Pourquoi un projet visant la gestion financière et les jeunes ?

R : La gestion des finances personnelles est un élément très important dans la vie d’un individu et lorsque ce sujet est abordé très tôt, il est ainsi mieux outillé pour prendre des décisions financières responsables qui auront un impact significatif sur le reste de sa vie. De plus, selon le National Report Card on Youth Financial Literacy, 93% des jeunes pensent qu’il est important d’acquérir des connaissances sur les finances. Toujours, selon la même source, 50% des jeunes finissants du secondaire sont déjà endettés. Il faut donc faire vite afin d’instruire cette future génération sur cette question.


Q : Est-ce que ce jeu pourra réellement être éducatif pour les jeunes ?

R: Nous sommes une toute petite équipe, mais nous regorgeons de créativité afin de transformer les jeux en un puissant outil d’apprentissage. Ce jeu permettra de découvrir les différents aspects liés à la gestion des finances personnelles tout en étant amusant et en ajoutant une touche d’humour.


Q : Sera-t-il possible de jouer à ce jeu sur plusieurs plateformes ?

R: Le jeu sera disponible pour l’iPhone, l’iPad, les appareils Android, les PC et les ordinateurs portables.


Q : Y aura-t-il des interactions entre les joueurs ?

R: Nous souhaitons développer chez les joueurs la générosité et l’entraide. Ils pourront ainsi faire des requêtes à l’aide d’icônes seulement.


Q : Quand le projet sera-t-il prêt ?

R: Au terme de la campagne et une fois l’objectif atteint, le développement nécessitera de 90 à 100 jours de travail soit environ 3 mois.

story:
Short Summary

California Poets in the Schools (CPitS) empowers K-12 students throughout California to express their creativity, imagination, and intellectual curiosity through writing, performing and publishing their own poetry. We train and coordinate a multicultural network of published poets who bring their passion and craft to over 26,000 young people annually in public and private schools, juvenile halls, hospitals, libraries and other community settings.

Now, in our 51st year, we are striving to reach more students than ever before. April is National Poetry Month, and this year we invite you to celebrate by helping us bring the power of poetry education to every school in California. 


How You Can Help

For $75, a poet teacher can teach one classroom, exposing those students to the art of poetry, given the opportunity to learn from a published poet, and enabled to find their own inner voice to produce their own poems and share them with the world. While some schools are able to fund workshops with our poet teachers, tight budgets have put this resource in jeopardy for the students who might benefit the most. Your donations will go to expanding the reach of our poet teachers. Reaching our goal of $5,000 will help us reach schools in over 30 counties in California. That amounts to over a 1,000 students in classrooms, after-school programs, hospitals, and correctional facilities.


In exchange, we will bring a piece of the CPitS experience to you: a copy of our anthology with works from talented student poets, attendance at a writers workshop, or even a private poetry reading in your home. 


The Impact

California Poets in the Schools calls on a multitalented, multicultural, multilingual roster of over 125 published poets who are specially trained to bring their experience and love for their craft into classrooms in their own communities. In CPitS workshops, kids learn to read deeply, to write with confidence, to stand up in public and recite, and perhaps most deeply, to understand what they have to say has value in the world. The stories of poet teachers and students best convey how these experiences have shaped students' lives.

In Merced, the poet offers the third grade a lesson on the theme of hands. She begins by asking the children to trace the outline of their hands on the page. Partway through her intro she’s interrupted by the unscheduled arrival of a fifth-grader named Rosalie, who is being placed on time-out for acting out with a substitute. Rosalie is mad and sad when she comes in, and sulks with her head down. But soon she raises her glance, alertly following what the poet says. “Can I do it too?” At the end of the period, Rosalie insists on sharing what she has written: 
My hands made a poem for the first time.
My hands are small but do more things than I can imagine.
My hands help me to be a writer.
My hands help me be who I want to be.
My hands hold this poem to read it to many people…


Both the traditional educational system, with its concentration on isolated skills, and the Common Core, with its left-brained focus on critical thinking, problem-solving and analysis, seem to have a blind spot when it comes to the transformative power of poetry, the oldest Language Art. CPitS enlists the students’ own creativity through fun and empowering literacy activities that support both traditional standards and the objectives of the Common Core. Research has shown that CPitS fortifies students’ confidence and self-image as creative writers.

Driving up a winding mountain highway to begin a long day in an isolated school in the hills above Bear Valley that houses grades K-8 in just four rooms, the poet feels a little discouraged. He’s not sure the older classes really got last week’s lesson on haiku. He snaps on the radio, hoping to catch sports talk from the distant city. Instead, it’s kids from his class reading haiku poems:
I think that
everyone is tired
except the ants.


The Challenges We Face

California Poets in the Schools faces particular challenges as a grass-roots, community-based organization spread thin across a state larger than Germany. At times it’s been an uphill battle to provide the infrastructure that enables the poets’ extraordinary work. 

There are currently just 1.3 staff members in the CPitS office in San Francisco. Unpaid members of the CPitS Board have rallied to fill the gaps, and the enthusiasm and goodwill of the poets have carried us through. 

Their love and commitment has carried us so far, but we need your support to ensure that the intellectual and creative journey that we've taken students on for the past 5 decades will be available to students throughout the states for the next 50 years.  


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate, there are other invaluable ways you can still help us bring the gift of poetry to California schools

  • Share our campaign with your friends and family!
  • Find out more about becoming a poet-teacher or other ways to volunteer your time at http://www.cpits.org/background/get-involved.html.

Thanks for your support!


(All images: Photo by Jay R. Hart courtesy of the California Arts Council)

story:
Help an aspiring actress to participate in a life-changing La Mama Umbria international program in Italy.


****************************************************************************

La Mama Umbria- A non-profit cultural center and artists’ residence in Spoleto, Italy. La MaMa Umbria hosts the Spoleto Open Festival and is home to annual retreats for playwrights, actors and directors. Every summer La MaMa Umbria hosts artist residencies, and organizes workshops led by internationally renowned art professionals whose work is impacting the contemporary landscape of performative arts.

****************************************************************************

I was born and raised in Russia in an artistic family, my mother – a leading actress and operetta singer – inspired me to be an actress. I started my formal acting education in Vladivostok at Far Eastern State Academy of Art but after two years I felt I needed exposure to the international performing arts world. In 2010 I moved to Singapore and completed three years education at LaSalle College of the Arts.

Despite my enthusiasm and promising acting career in Singapore, I have realized how important my artistic development is. I feel reached a level of maturity, both personal and professional, that allows me to embrace the La Mama Umbria International Summer Program and to assimilate the new ideas that will be brought to me in this environment. 

One week ago I have been accepted into this program. And though I have managed to save money for the tickets, I do not have enough to pay for the program itself.

Therefore, I really hope for  your financial support to make this trip happen!

I am  currently seeking $1900 to cover the remaining expenses to participate in this program.  Your donations will pay for the following:

-  housing and meals in Spoleto (June 17 - 29)

- production costs for the show and participation in the Spoleto Festival

-  travel insurance

****************************************************************************

For many young actresess in Singapore, like myself, this is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to participate in such inspiring project and learn from masters of art.

I have dedicated my whole life to acting and this program can really help my career.  This trip is a reward for all of the hard work and an opportunity to take my commitment to the global level. 

Please, donate what you can.  Every dollar gets me closer to my dream. 

Thank you for reading this!

Bless YOU!!!

story:
Hello, My Name is Jimsworth The Space Turtle.  I am the mascot for the Montessori High School in Lexington Kentucky.  I really like my high school, and all the kids that go there...but they don’t always have all of the resources that they need.  That’s where I come in.  As a space turtle, I know all about technology, but they need help purchasing things that will make their art program as amazing as the rest of their school.

The Montessori High School has been in existence for four years now, though I only became their mascot this year (nobody is perfect after all).  They are on the cutting edge of what a high school can be, but being on the cutting edge takes money that isn't always available.  The money that they are asking for will be used to buy things like cameras, photography equipment, a 3-D printer, and a class set of 3Doodlers (that last one got me, but they are cool – you should look them up).

As high school students, they need these supplies because they are preparing to enter a world that is rapidly changing.  They need as many opportunities as possible to experience technology, and to learn how it can be used.  This is a challenge for us because technology is really expensive and not easy to get into their classrooms.

If you can’t help with a donation of money, then please spread the word.  I’ll do what I can with my rocket but, well, I am rather small and people tend not to notice when I do messages in the sky.

For those that can help with a donation we have a few special perks to bring a smile to your face.

story:
Youth Talk Movement

What we do

Youth Talk is a youth-centred social movement that seeks to empower young Jamaicans to achieve their full potential. There are several developmental challenges faced by young Jamaicans to include Drug Misuse, Teenage Pregnancy, Poverty, Crime and Violence, Unemployment...

Therefore, through the use of participatory radio, we invite members of our youth community and experts to discuss, illustrate and propose positive ways to address these challenges.

Programme Structure: Live Panel Discussions, Story-based Interview, Radio Drama, Live Poetry/Songs, Quiz

The radio show, on ROOTS 96.1 FM, applies a thematic approach to programme development with the first series. NO DRUG ZONE, focused on bringing awareness to young Jamaicans about the dangers of drug misuse.

The NO DRUG ZONE series launched on March 23, 2015 with a vibrant episode exploring the definition of a drug and dangers of marijuana smoking.

Each week, the show includes live discussions with young drug users or former drug addicts who share their unfortunate stories highlighting the dangers of drug misuse. Do you have a story to share? Join our conversation!

But the fun and excitement does not stop after the airing of our weekly radio show on ROOTS 96.1 FM, we continue the conversation in our Youth Talk WhatsApp Group and Youth Talk Facebook Page  .

Therefore, we say, Youth Talk isn’t just a radio programme but a Movement!

So join our movement today! KEEP THE CONVERSATION LIVE!

Who we are

We are a group of young volunteers living in inner city communities in Kingston and St. Andrew. We are driven by our passion to make a difference in the lives of our peers.

 Many have turned a blind eye to the talent, abilities and creative potential of inner city youth but we believe through this movement will re-energize inner city youth to achieve their full potential which will ultimately benefit community development.


As programme producers and presenters, we are already benefiting from this media training experience. We entered this process with NO MEDIA TRAINING…but through the assistance of Commonwealth of Learning/TCP-Caribbean we received training in basic broadcast media skills to enable the production of our radio show.

KEEP THE CONVERSATION ALIVE!

Our first radio series- NO DRUG ZONE (runs from March 23- May 25) is sponsored by the Commonwealth of Learning in partnership with TCP-Caribbean and ROOTS 96.1 FM. This sponsorship cover air time charges and stipends but it will expire at the end of our first series.

Your contribution will help to cover the cost of producing another 2-month series, which include:

·  Air time charges (Partial Subsidy)

·  Cost of earphones for volunteers

·  Stipends

·  Phone Credit

·  Transportation Cost (field interviews)

Help us to meet our funding goal by making a cash donation

You can help us by following our Youth Talk Facebook Page and provide feedback on the content shared from our weekly shows (Especially our radio dramas)

You can help us by telling your friends, family members to tune in to YOUTH TALK every Monday at 5:05-6pm on ROOTS 96.1 FM, you can stream us online at Mixlr.Com/roots-961fm

story:
"The powerful may appear great, but in reality they are not. Greatest of all are the ordinary people. If those in power lead lives of idle luxury it is because the people are silent. We have to speak out. With impassioned words, we need to resolutely attack abuses of power that cause people suffering. This is fighting on the side of justice. It is wrong to remain silent when confronted with injustice. Doing so is tantamount to supporting and condoning evil."-- Daisaku Ikeda

What does one learn from being imprisoned for doing something right? To never speak out again? Or that truth-telling is absolutely necessary.

How do you keep quiet when the country you love knowingly and willingly violates the very basis of its foundation beliefs and laws? And when you speak out, does the system support you? Or punish you for revealing the ugliness?

A recent article in The Washingtonian tells Kiriakou's story of this ordeal.

Whistleblowers Speak Out for Truth

There have been many whistleblowers accused of harming the United States by leaking information to our enemies that would cause damage to our government. In reality, that is simply not the case in almost all circumstances. Instead, using this false premise, what has happened is the deliberate attempt to ruin the lives of any whistleblower who speaks up as a way of discouraging those who see wrongdoing and want it stopped.

Why is this campaign so important? Because what John Kiriakou went though in simply telling the truth is an abomination to our personal rights as Americans. And the Whistleblower laws didn’t protect him at all. If you’re someone who expects government transparency and protection of your rights, you will understand John's frustration. John is now focused on making people aware of what needs to be changed in the America we all want to know again.

What will John Kiriakou do with the money? Let us be clear: this campaign is not going to make John a rich man, but hopefully, it will give him a modest living salary for the next six to eight months (after campaign expenses and seminar and speech expenses) until he is allowed to travel and fulfill his goals of presenting seminars, giving speeches and bringing awareness to Americans through many different media options. His goal is to inform people throughout the world how to take a more humanistic approach to life by refusing to condone torture, caring that the poor are given opportunities to become independent, and supporting a legal system that supports the law without denying the rights of anyone.

However at this time, his travel is quite confined by his parole restrictions and the required approvals. Until he is able to get beyond those restrictions, his ability to earn a living is also restricted. 

John Kiriakou is working at a think tank in Washington DC whose standards are very high and thus they will not take money from corporate interests or government. John is eager to speak for groups and activist organizations as well as colleges and universities where our future decision-makers can have another view of the world through John's eyes and experiences. If you know of an organization or university that would host him, please contact us.this way, they can speak their truth without worrying about offending contributors. 

Additionally, for John to be able to speak out to the nation and to the world, he must have an online presence. So far, his online website, www.johnkiriakou.com, has been managed without cost to him. Unfortunately, it is unrealistic to think that this can continue. John is working toward a time where his supporters become part of his team, not just a group of people who support his financial needs. For John, it is the honorable thing for him to become independent again and rebuild the life taken from him by the Justice Department.

John Kiriakou's Goals and Projects

This Indiegogo campaign is based on the need for John Kiriakou and his family to recover financially and personally from the retaliatory campaign by the Justice Department undertook to destroy him and to allow him to move forward with his plans to bring awareness and educate Americans through seminars, Op-Ed articles, broadcasting, speeches, books and reaching out in whatever way he can. The topics of his focus include:

• Whistleblower rights
• Prison Reform
• Transparency in Government
• Changing the practice of torture
• Protecting Privacy and Your Privacy Rights

John Kiriakou needs your support because he is in a unique position to speak out and be heard. His experience could be the experience of anyone who speaks out against wrongdoings by the government. Until his speeches and books and broadcast efforts begin to provide him a living salary and the ability to restructure his financial life, John is still at the mercy of the Justice Department and their destructive and retaliatory actions. His efforts to educate, inform and expand awareness require a salary and enough money to support his online presence to promote his good and valuable works.

In the end, John Kiriakou believes he can stretch the net campaign funds six to eight months or more and still accomplish his goals. In fact, one of his most important personal goals is to reach a financial stability that will allow him to stop taking donations on his website and create a donation portal for other whistleblowers like Jeffrey Sterling. Jeffrey is in the beginning days of his imprisonment and John knows how much help his family will need. John can help him with that burden.

Never forget...

As a whistleblower who suffered at the hands of the Justice Department working on behalf of the CIA to shut him up and shut him down, when John was released from prison he vowed to NEVER be silent on the wrongdoings of his country and its agencies.

We will never be truly free nor able to be proud of our great country again if we don't stop the wrongdoing and misconduct by those in the highest positions in the land.

Too many are directly suffering from the axiom: "Power corrupts, and absolute power corrupts absolutely." And too many suffer indirectly as the economy, the government, and our communities are irreparably damaged by those who simply do not care or care for their own gains more than for the American Way.

----

Check the Gallery for videos.  For more information on why John Kiriakou is on this Path of Change, visit his website:  www.johnkiriakou.com
