John Kiriakou needs your support because he is in a unique position to speak out and be heard. His experience could be the experience of anyone who speaks out against wrongdoings by the government. Until his speeches and books and broadcast efforts begin to provide him a living salary and the ability to restructure his financial life, John is still at the mercy of the Justice Department and their destructive and retaliatory actions. His efforts to educate, inform and expand awareness require a salary and enough money to support his online presence to promote his good and valuable works.

In the end, John Kiriakou believes he can stretch the net campaign funds six to eight months or more and still accomplish his goals. In fact, one of his most important personal goals is to reach a financial stability that will allow him to stop taking donations on his website and create a donation portal for other whistleblowers like Jeffrey Sterling. Jeffrey is in the beginning days of his imprisonment and John knows how much help his family will need. John can help him with that burden.

Never forget...
As a whistleblower who suffered at the hands of the Justice Department working on behalf of the CIA to shut him up and shut him down, when John was released from prison he vowed to NEVER be silent on the wrongdoings of his country and its agencies.
We will never be truly free nor able to be proud of our great country again if we don't stop the wrongdoing and misconduct by those in the highest positions in the land.

Too many are directly suffering from the axiom: "Power corrupts, and absolute power corrupts absolutely." And too many suffer indirectly as the economy, the government, and our communities are irreparably damaged by those who simply do not care or care for their own gains more than for the American Way.
----
Check the Gallery for videos.  For more information on why John Kiriakou is on this Path of Change, visit his website:  www.johnkiriakou.com

story:
We love the future of education!

Prolangco brings together individuals who share a common passion for learning, exploring and growing through language education and cultural understanding. We are dedicated to providing high quality online language classes while also creating opportunities to leave a lasting positive impact on classrooms and students throughout the world.

Prolangco already provides the flexibility to schedule your private language classes around work, school, friends and family commitments. Our teaching methods maximize student engagement, and we provide convenient tools for payment and scheduling. We match our students and language teachers based on their shared location, interests and experiences. Personal relationships, cultural exchanges, use of modern technology and flexibility distinguish Prolangco from other companies.

Education matters.

Prolangco has received class requests from students and classrooms all over the world. Growing global interest demonstrates the value of our classes. We would like to increase the number of paid classes we are able to provide and also offer our language classes to individuals who would benefit from them but cannot afford them. We are on a mission and need your help!

It's education beyond our borders.

With the funds from our Indiegogo campaign, we will not only develop a more robust, modern website, which will allow flexible scheduling, student access to online materials and notes, and customized areas of interaction between students, but we will be able to increase our online capabilities with upgraded office equipment, including at least one central server and an expanded high capacity wifi network, and rent a new office starting in August, 2015.  These important primary steps will allow us to incorporate free international large participation English class programs into our business model.

Why do we wish to expand our English language program beyond our borders?  We strongly believe that these types of classes will allow our students to learn from each other, network, interact, and work together while learning the English language, thereby providing positive change, compassion, empathy and understanding across multiple cultures.


Our Prolangco team in Germany has been providing general language and business english classes worldwide for more than three years now, which has allowed us to grow slowly but steadily.  We want to take further steps to continue our progress.  After all, our slogan is, "Progress with Prolangco."

Commencing in March, 2015, we began offering a free, one-hour online Business English seminar called "Connect-Interact-Network."  This webinar allows business entrepreneurs around the world the opportunity to discuss current business topics with each other and practice their English for free. We would like to expand this type of program to young students worldwide no later than January, 2016. 

Education is a powerful market for change.

Given our world's political climate, as well as specific requests from students and business people across the globe, we are embarking on a new, and we hope significant, step forward - creating MOOC's (see below for description) for young students throughout the world, as well as for entrepreneurs, who wish to connect with their international counterparts.  

As our communities continue to exhibit great diversity, the need for understanding and accepting the differences among all people has never been more important.  We strongly prescribe to the principle that, "Education is the most powerful weapon which you can use to change the world." - Nelson Mandela.

It's time to upend traditional methods of teaching.

What is an MOOC? Excellent question! A massive open online course (MOOC) is an online course aimed at unlimited participation and open access via the web. In addition to traditional course materials such as filmed lectures, readings, and problem sets, our MOOCs will provide interactive user forums to support community interactions between students and their coaches. Not only do we hope to get teachers, coaches, and professors from all 7 continents involved in our courses, but also, given the economic circumstances surrounding many of our anticipated young participants, we wish to make these MOOCs available to our students for free within the next six to eight months.

Our team is excited about these projects and their enthusiasm will inspire others to contribute to the nonprofit program. Our teachers will network with professionals throughout the world, make positive contributions to classrooms worldwide, and create a unique cultural immersion within our globe's dynamic entrepreneurial and scholastic communities.

Show the world, through your numbers, that you're out there!

Every single pledge brings us one step closer to successfully meeting our funding goal.  With your support, we will be able to efficiently provide classes for our growing user base and to create our first free worldwide educational MOOCs.

You will help us in our mission to create opportunities through education and to increase cultural understanding while leaving a lasting positive impact on worldwide communities. 

Great classes come from great students.

A series of short documentary films and updates will chronicle the expansion of Prolangco and our experiences building the free educational program.  We hope to highlight the personal stories of some of our students on our website. We will also include interviews with our teachers, students and other members of our team.

Please join us today and help us to reach international students who wish to communicate, interact and become involved in positive change through the power of language.

“Tell me and I forget, teach me and I may remember, involve me and I learn.” ― Benjamin Franklin

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, and that's okay.  Here's what you can do to help:

  • Get the word out about our campaign and goals by sharing our project with your friends, family, peers, and colleagues.  Every share is a HUGE help!!
  • Do you own a company or work at one that would be interested in partnering with us?  Drop us a line!  We answer emails in 24 hours or less: info@prolangco.eu.
  • Check out our website www.prolangco.com and consider getting involved!
  • Share our project page, our Facebook Prolangco FB, and our YouTube Channel with everyone you know! Prolangco's YouTube Channel
  • Thank you everyone!  Pat yourselves on the back, you are awesome!

Risks and challenges

Like all business endeavors, we fully expect this project to have its challenges. However, we have found that with enough hard work and dedication, everything is possible.

We are confident, given our history, teamwork and interest in our program, that our goals will be met by January, 2016. Our main challenge for this project is getting the word out so that we may start updating our website and technology and commence setting up our MOOC programs.

Donations will decide for us how much more we get to do and just how far we can reach!

story:
Dear Friends,

          It was with great sadness that we received the news about the disastrous earthquake which struck the Nepal yesterday which has claimed lot of lives, and razed houses, schools, roads, temples and heritage structure. We grief greatly for the loss of numerous of lives and the missing of numerous people due to the natural disaster. 

         It was heartening to know that people from all parts of world are bolstered up for helping the victims and theirs family. It is my earnest prayer and hope that these efforts will reduce the sufferings of the affected people. 

        As a Entrepreneur and my involvement in community services since a long span of years, I really felt I have to do something. The public relation I have developed through my  Employment agency since 10 years in my community is quite immense.  People are requesting me to initiate an effective relief work which could help all the victims and their family.

      In consultation with my peers I have decided to start this mission with dedication and with full transparency. In order to meet our mission and provide services in our community, we rely on the generosity of individuals and businesses for support. Without the assistance of community-minded individuals just like you, we wouldn't be able to serve those who are in need back home.

       All the collected funds will be utilized for medical treatment of the victims through Lake City Hospital and critical care unit, Pokhara and partial funds will be utilized for food and Miscellaneous expenses. Apart from the above my organization will be sending a container of cloths.

       Individuals and origanizations  are requested to donate generously. We will be accepting cloths and nonperishable food also, which will be sent through a container.

Requesting for immediate support.

Sincerely

Rudra Pun

718-205-9870

story:
Diversity in Antwerp City is a festival organized by young students. We find that colour, religious conviction, or cultural background do not matter and that we stand stronger together. Antwerp city is becoming less tolerant of diversity. We see more and more racism and discrimination and this goes hand in hand with more repressive measures. So as a group of young people from diverse backgrounds we came together to find a way to stop this development. The festival will take place on the 10th of May in Antwerp, Belgium. https://www.facebook.com/events/855036937894429... 

Our idea went viral in Belgium

Our idea was to have a small festival against racism and discrimination, but after putting the event on Facebook, it went viral in Belgium. We started with 0 euro because we tought only our friends and family would come. We were thinking about making our own food, asking people to play free music,... But now we need a big stage, a good music instalation and a technician, foodstands, musicians, banners, flyers,and so on! 

The Impact

We never realized that racism was such a big deal for people in Belgium, until we saw how many people responded on our project. We are proud to do this and to bring different cultures together in a festival that promotes diversity and we hope to see more initiatives like this in the near future to create more tolerance between cultures. 

Risks & Challenges

We will have to pay around 11000 euro's for our music stage (5000), installation, security, foodstands, flyers, tents,... And we figured out that we can earn money on the festival by selling softdrinks, our own desserts, our t-shirts and by asking a % to the people who have a foodstand on our festival. But there is no guarantee that we can reach the 11000 euro's of costs that we have right now and thats why we need to have a marge of (at least) 5000 euro's. (our stage is the main cost) 

Every Euro can help us to make sure we can spread the message of a world without racism and to promote diversity!

story:
Short Summary

Art by the Glass Studio is a paint and sip art studio.  You can bring your drinks and it supplies everything else, including instructions.  This has been my place of employment for the last six months, and it has been an incredible experience meeting awesome people and having fun, while recreating a painting each night.  Unfortunately, Art by the Glass taught its final class last week, but I was given the opportunity to keep it going under new ownership.

This is an incredible business that holds a lot of potential.  With a plan of action in place, new art, and new events to offer, Art by the Glass could be better than ever.

What's needed to make this possible:

The $5000 that is needed would go towards the cost of getting the business back up and running.  We already have a great team of instructors to offer exciting classes, and new and creative art classes in place.  All we need is the down payment to make this business a success!

While this is a local art studio, it's still such an amazing place to offer support to.  It has been the host to numerous fundraisers, and offered a relaxed and supportive environment to local artists, and those who just want to pursue something fun and creative.

Art by the Glass Studio is an incredible place to work, but it is also a fun place to go to unwind.  I have seen hundreds of people walk through those doors and leave with a smile on their face and a memento that they can be proud of under their arm.

Visit the gallery to see some of the most recent classes, and paintings that we have done.

I have had the opportunity to teach multiple classes ranging in what they have to offer.  We have painted wine bottles for a more crafty appeal, word art that people can hang on their walls, and full on recreations of paintings that look amazing.  Every painting comes out unique, and with the step-by-step instructions, everyone ends up proud of their work.


A little about me:

I have been drawing and painting for 14+ years now, and have a true passion for the arts.  As soon as I started working for Art by the Glass Studio I knew I had found my dream job.  I have always wanted to pursue my love of art and blend that with a career, and have met some incredible people while working here.  I have a four year old daughter who absolutely loves the art studio; she is part of the reason why I want this dream to continue on.

story:
Sierra Nevada of Santa Marta

The Sierra Nevada of Santa Marta rises up from the Caribbean beaches to the glacial peaks of Colón and Bolívar at 5,775 metres above sea level, the highest coastal range in the world.

It ascends through narrow valleys with rivers of crystal clear water, through deserts, rainforests, moorlands and perpetual snow. It is surrounded by the Caribbean Sea, the dry plains of La Guajira, and the grasslands that border the Magdalena and César rivers.

Four indigenous communities inhabit the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. They are the Wiwa (Arzario or Malaya), Kogui, Arhuaco and Kankuama. For these people the Sierra is the heart of the world. Their sacred sites, fountains of ancient knowledge must be respected and cared for. They call themselves the elder brother and their role is to look after the mother earth on which the whole universe depends.

Social organisation, clothing and language vary from group to group, but they share a common view of creation, the Law of Origin. This Law is written in every place in the Sierra and contains the principles and rules that govern the spiritual and material lives of the indigenous communities.

Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta

Desde las playas del caribe, la Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta se levanta hasta los picos Colón y Bolívar, a 5.775 metros sobre el nivel del mar.

Asciende por valles estrechos con ríos de aguas cristalinas, a través de desiertos, bosques húmedos, páramos y nieves perpetuas. La rodean el Mar Caribe, las secas planicies de La Guajira, y las sabanas del Río Magdalena y el Cesar.

Cuatroetnias indígenas habitan la Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, los pueblos Wiwa (Arzario o Malayo), Kogui, Arhuaco y Kankuamo, para los cuales la Sierra es el corazón del mundo. Un sitio sagrado, fuente de conocimiento que debe ser cuidado a través del respeto a la naturaleza y el trabajo espiritual. Su misión por la cual se autodenominan “hermanitos mayores” es la de cuidar a la madre tierra de cuya suerte depende la del universo entero.

La organización social, el vestido y la lengua varían entre los cuatro grupos, pero los une su visión de la creación, La Ley de Origen. Una ley escrita en cada lugar de la Sierra que guarda los principios y normas para la vida material y espiritual de los indígenas.

Project Architect, Patrick Fleming with Wiwa Mamo, Jose Martin

What We Need

Seiamake is one of six Wiwa communities in the municipality of Dibulla, in the northern face of the Sierra. In 2012 the Colombian government expropriated Finca Arimaca, a 600 hectare farm, from a convicted drug trafficker and gave it to the Wiwa community, who founded Seiamake. 32 Wiwa families live in Seiamake with about 180 inhabitants of which 64 are children under 15 years.

The farm buildings consist of 2 houses in need of repair, a garage without its roof, a dining area without its roof and some outhouses for animals.

They are looking for help to realise two very important projects:
  • Primary School
  • Meeting Hall

Lo que necesitamos

Seiamake es una de las seis comunidades Wiwa que habitan en Dibulla, un municipio ubicado en la cara norte de la Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, frente al mar caribe de Colombia.

La comunidad Wiwa Seiamake se organizó en el año 2012, gracias a la entrega por parte del Estado colombiano al Pueblo Wiwa, de una extensión de tierra de aproximadamente 600 hectáreas conocida en la región con el nombre de “Finca Arimaca”. Este lugar perteneció en el pasado a un traficante de drogas a quien el gobierno le extinguio el dominio de la tierra, entregandolo al Pueblo Wiwa para que lo habitara y aprovechara. En la actualidad en Seiamake habitan 32 familias, que constituyen alrededor de 180 habitantes, de los cuales 64 son niños menores de 15 años.

La Finca Arimaca tiene dos casas deterioradas que necesitan ser reparadas, un garaje sin techo y sin puertas, un comedor sin techo ni paredes y un establo para ganado.

La comunidad Wiwa de Seiamake esta buscando ayuda para hacer realidad dos proyectos muy importantes:

  • Construcción de la escuela primaria
  • Construcción de salón comunitario

Current State of the Buildings

The existing buildings of Seiamake are in a bad state of disrepair due to poor maintenance and theft. The roofs, doors, windows, sanitary fittings, electricity and water systems are all missing. The existing structures can be repaired and remodeled to suit the needs of the primary school and meeting hall.

Estado actual de las edificaciones

Las edificaciones que actualmente existen en Seiamake se encuentran en muy mal estado de conservación, debido a la ausencia de mantenimiento y al hurto de sus sanitarios, puertas, ventanas. Tampoco cuenta con servicio de electricidad ni agua potable. Las edificaciones existentes pueden ser reparadas y remodeladas para adecuarlas a las necesidades de la escuela primaria y el salón de reuniones que se quieren construir.

The Primary School

As in every culture, it is important for children to learn their native language. In Wiwa culture it is important that the children start their education under the guidance of the adults, who impart a collective way of seeing the world which helps to build the child's personality.

The objective of the primary school is that the Wiwa children of Seiamake, through Damana, their own language and culture have a space to learn which complies with a reasonable standard of materials and building with regard to space, hygiene, ventilation, lighting and comfort.

La escuela primaria

Así como en cada cultura es natural que los niños aprendan la lengua materna, entre los Wiwa, es necesario que se inicie el proceso de aprendizaje de la mano de los adultos, que los lleve a apropiarse de una forma colectiva de ver el mundo, y a construir su propia personalidad. La niñez es parte fundamental de la cultura Wiwa, ya que durante ella se aprende la que será su forma de vida, absorbiendo el conocimiento ancestral y prácticas tradicionales, así como su relación con la naturaleza, a partir de las cuales se construyen las bases para la supervivencia como individuo y comunidad, tratando de garantizar la permanencia de sus expresiones culturales.

Con este proyecto se busca que los niños de Seiamake realicen el proceso de aprendizaje de su lengua Damana y de su cultura tradicional en un lugar que respete su entorno propio y que a la vez esté dotado de las mínimas condiciones de espacio, higiene, ventilación y comodidad para ellos.

The Meeting Hall

The Wiwa people want this place, Seiamake to be the centre of their communities and have started to build a traditional village. The Mamos, the spiritual elders of the Wiwa, called this place “Seiamake”, which in their native language, Damana, means “the place of origin”, because they hope the six communities of Gomake, Seiamake, Coroal, Shebukumake, Parquesito and Casa Aluminio ( a total of 1418 inhabitants) will use this place as the focus of their community.

Salon comunitario para reuniones

El Pueblo Wiwa desea que Seiamake se convierta en el punto de reunión de las seis comunidades Wiwa que habitan en el municipio de Dibulla, llamadas Gomake, Seiamake, Coroal, Shebukumake, Parquesito y Casa Aluminio, las cuales en total agrupan una población de 1.418 indígenas Wiwa. Por esta razón los Mamos, autoridades tradicionales de la comunidad, llamaron a este territorio “Seiamake”, palabra Damana que significa “lugar donde se retorna a los orígenes”.

The Plans / Los planes

The Costs of the Work / Costos de la obra

Labour / Mano de obra.................................     12,000,000 cop - $4,600 US

Materials / Materiales....................................      9,500,000 cop - $3,700 US

Timber for the roof / Madera para el techo..     4,500,000 cop - $1.700 US

TOTAL..............................................................    26,000,000 cop - $10,000 US

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Further Information on the Sierra Nevada

From the Heart of the World - Documentary about the Kogi Indigenous
National Geographic - Article on the Indigenous of the Sierra Nevada
The Guardian - Audio Slideshow about the Sierra Nevada
story_txt:
Sierra Nevada of Santa Marta


 
The Sierra Nevada of Santa Marta rises up
from the Caribbean beaches to the glacial peaks of Colón and Bolívar at 5,775
metres above sea level, the highest coastal range in the world.
It ascends through narrow valleys with rivers
of crystal clear water, through deserts, rainforests, moorlands and perpetual
snow. It is surrounded by the Caribbean Sea, the dry plains of La Guajira, and
the grasslands that border the Magdalena and César rivers.
Four indigenous communities inhabit the
Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta. They are the Wiwa (Arzario or Malaya), Kogui,
Arhuaco and Kankuama. For these people the Sierra is the heart of the world.
Their sacred sites, fountains of ancient knowledge must be respected and cared
for. They call themselves the elder brother and their role is to look after the
mother earth on which the whole universe depends.

Social organisation, clothing and language
vary from group to group, but they share a common view of creation, the Law of
Origin. This Law is written in every place in the Sierra and contains the
principles and rules that govern the spiritual and material lives of the
indigenous communities.
Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta
Desde las playas del caribe, 
la Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta se levanta hasta los picos Colón y 
Bolívar, a 5.775 metros sobre el nivel del mar. 

Asciende
 por valles estrechos con ríos de aguas cristalinas, a través de 
desiertos, bosques húmedos, páramos y nieves perpetuas. La rodean el Mar
 Caribe, las secas planicies de La Guajira, y las sabanas del Río 
Magdalena y el Cesar.
Cuatroetnias
 indígenas habitan la Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, los pueblos Wiwa 
(Arzario o Malayo), Kogui, Arhuaco y Kankuamo, para los cuales la Sierra
 es el corazón del mundo. Un sitio sagrado, fuente de conocimiento que 
debe ser cuidado a través del respeto a la naturaleza y el trabajo 
espiritual. Su misión por la cual se
 autodenominan “hermanitos mayores” es la de cuidar a la madre tierra de
 cuya suerte depende la del universo entero. 
La
 organización social, el vestido y la lengua varían entre los cuatro 
grupos, pero los une su visión de la creación, La Ley de Origen. Una ley
 escrita en cada lugar de la Sierra que guarda los principios y normas 
para la vida material y espiritual de los indígenas.


Project Architect, Patrick Fleming with Wiwa Mamo, Jose Martin
What We Need

Seiamake is one of six Wiwa communities in
the municipality of Dibulla, in the northern face of the Sierra. In 2012 the
Colombian government expropriated Finca Arimaca, a 600 hectare farm, from a
convicted drug trafficker and gave it to the Wiwa community, who founded
Seiamake. 32 Wiwa families live in Seiamake with about 180 inhabitants of which
64 are children under 15 years.


The farm buildings consist of 2 houses in
need of repair, a garage without its roof, a dining area without its roof and
some outhouses for animals.They are looking for help to realise two very important projects:


Primary School


Meeting Hall


  
Lo que necesitamos

Seiamake es una de las seis 
comunidades Wiwa que habitan en Dibulla, un municipio ubicado en la cara
 norte de la Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, frente al mar caribe de 
Colombia. 
La
 comunidad Wiwa Seiamake se organizó en el año 2012, gracias a la 
entrega por parte del Estado colombiano al Pueblo Wiwa, de una extensión
 de tierra de aproximadamente 600 hectáreas conocida en la región con el
 nombre
 de “Finca Arimaca”. Este lugar perteneció en el pasado a un traficante 
de drogas a quien el gobierno le extinguio  el dominio de la tierra, 
entregandolo  al Pueblo Wiwa para que lo habitara y aprovechara. En la 
actualidad en Seiamake habitan 32 familias, que constituyen alrededor de
 180 habitantes, de los cuales 64 son niños menores de 15 años.
La
 Finca Arimaca tiene dos casas deterioradas que necesitan ser reparadas,
 un garaje sin techo y sin puertas, un comedor sin techo ni paredes y un
 establo para ganado.
La comunidad Wiwa de Seiamake esta buscando ayuda para hacer realidad dos proyectos muy importantes:

Construcción de la escuela primaria
Construcción de salón comunitario


Current State of the Buildings




The existing buildings of Seiamake are in a
bad state of disrepair due to poor maintenance and theft. The roofs, doors,
windows, sanitary fittings, electricity and water systems are all missing. The
existing structures can be repaired and remodeled to suit the needs of the
primary school and meeting hall. 
Estado actual de las edificaciones

Las edificaciones que 
actualmente existen en Seiamake se encuentran en muy mal estado de 
conservación, debido a la ausencia de mantenimiento y al hurto de sus 
sanitarios, puertas, ventanas. Tampoco cuenta con servicio de 
electricidad ni agua potable. Las
 edificaciones existentes pueden ser reparadas y remodeladas para 
adecuarlas a las necesidades de la escuela primaria y el salón de 
reuniones que se quieren construir.
The Primary School





 
As in every culture, it is important for
children to learn their native language. In Wiwa culture it is important that
the children start their education under the guidance of the adults, who impart
a collective way of seeing the world which helps to build the child's
personality. 


The objective of the primary school is that
the Wiwa children of Seiamake, through Damana, their own language and culture
have a space to learn which complies with a reasonable standard of materials
and building with regard to space, hygiene, ventilation, lighting and comfort.

La escuela primaria

Así como en cada cultura es 
natural que los niños aprendan la lengua materna, entre los Wiwa, es 
necesario que se inicie el proceso de aprendizaje de la mano de los 
adultos, que los lleve a apropiarse de una forma colectiva de ver el 
mundo, y a construir su propia personalidad. La niñez es parte 
fundamental de la cultura Wiwa, ya que
 durante ella se aprende la que será su forma de vida, absorbiendo el 
conocimiento ancestral y prácticas tradicionales, así como su relación 
con la naturaleza, a partir de las cuales se construyen las bases para 
la supervivencia como individuo y comunidad, tratando de garantizar la 
permanencia de sus expresiones culturales.
Con
 este proyecto se busca que los niños de Seiamake realicen el proceso de
 aprendizaje de su lengua Damana y de su cultura tradicional en un lugar
 que respete su entorno propio y que a la vez esté dotado de las mínimas
 condiciones de espacio, higiene, ventilación y comodidad para ellos.



The Meeting Hall





The Wiwa people want this place, Seiamake to
be the centre of their communities and have started to build a traditional
village. The Mamos, the spiritual elders of the Wiwa,
called this place “Seiamake”, which in their native language, Damana, means “the
place of origin”, because they hope the six communities of Gomake, Seiamake,
Coroal, Shebukumake, Parquesito and Casa Aluminio ( a total of 1418
inhabitants) will use this place as the focus of their community.
Salon comunitario para reuniones
El Pueblo Wiwa desea que Seiamake  se convierta en el punto de reunión 
de las seis comunidades Wiwa que habitan en el municipio de Dibulla, 
llamadas Gomake, Seiamake, Coroal,
 Shebukumake, Parquesito y Casa Aluminio, las cuales en total agrupan 
una población de 1.418 indígenas Wiwa. Por esta razón los Mamos, 
autoridades tradicionales de la comunidad, llamaron a este territorio 
“Seiamake”, palabra Damana que significa “lugar donde se retorna a los 
orígenes”.



The Plans / Los planes




The Costs of the Work / Costos de la obra



Labour / Mano de obra.................................     12,000,000 cop - $4,600 US
Materials / Materiales....................................      9,500,000 cop - $3,700 US
Timber for the roof / Madera para el techo..     4,500,000 cop - $1.700 US
TOTAL..............................................................    26,000,000 cop - $10,000 US 
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From the Heart of the World - Documentary about the Kogi IndigenousNational Geographic - Article on the Indigenous of the Sierra NevadaThe Guardian - Audio Slideshow about the Sierra Nevada

story:
(La descripción en español está más abajo)

Hello everyone,

a lot of people have been asking me the same stuff about my campaign over and over, so I made a list about this things that I failed to include in my first video.

PLUS I NEED TO TELL YOU ABOUT OUR NEW PERK.

1.- There’s some random Mexican guy in the internet who wants to go to Taiwan. What?
A lot of people want to know about the scholarship I got, and who am I. Don’t worry I’ll explain. I study Foreign Language Teaching with emphasis in Spanish at UNAM one of the biggest universities in the world. My yearly tuition is 50cents because it’s a public school and that’s why even though I’m kind of broke I can go to collage.
I speak Spanish, English, Japanese and Chinese. I am obsessed with asian cultures not only because I admire them but also because I think there is a lot of ancient wisdom in them that we could use in the western world. My scholarship comes from the Taiwanese Embassy in Mexico and it will pay for my tuition in Taiwán, housing and food. Just not the plane ticket.

2.-¿Why are you broke?
Well first of all I am a student, and even though I work teaching Spanish and piano, I spend that money on my weekly routine. I live with my parents and they do everything they can to support me, but right know they can’t get the kind of money I need for this trip.

3.- ¿Why do you speak English and why is your campaign in Canadian dollars?
I speak English because in Mexico City they make you study it since kindergarten but also because I lived in Canada for almost a year. My brother lives there, and I have a lot of friends there.
The campaign is in Canadian dollars because I knew from the beginning most of the donations would come from Canada. Indiegogo is not that famous in Mexico and Mexican people aren’t as used to using their credit or debit cards in the internet as Americans or Canadians. That doesn’t mean my Mexican friends and family aren’t donating, I am mostly receiving donations in cash from them.

4.-¿Music, songs? ¿What is that all about?
So a lot of people have gone for the personalised song perk and I’ve noticed that’s mainly people that know me personally, So I really need to explain to you guys that I am a composer and I play the piano, and trumpet and some other instruments as well. If you want to listen to some of my music go to https://soundcloud.com/don-requena. The idea behind this perk is to gather some information about you and write you your own song. By personalised I also mean you can choose what style you would like it to be: country, salsa, jazz, pop, metal, etc. So think about it, YOUR OWN SONG.

5.-¿What’s this new Perk?
One time my brother and I were walking in downtown Winnipeg, when we found an art studio and in there we met the most amazing person in the world: Wanda Luna. She is not only an artist, curator, writer and community activist but also an amazingly loving and supportive friend. If you want to know more about go to: http://www.wandaluna.com/
Now, the new perk is no less than one of her awesome pieces of art. So starting today you can get it by donating 510 dollars.

There are still 6 days left to make your donation, and there is no limit on the amount of perks I will give away so please consider donating!

Thank you so much.
LIKE… SO MUCH.
----------------------------------------
ORIGINAL CAMPAIGN STORY
I've been interested in Asian cultures for a long time. Two and a half years ago I started to learn Chinese and Japanese, but when college came along I had to drop one of my language courses. I decided to keep on studying Japanese since there were very few Chinese schools in Mexico, plus they were kind of new and didn't have a solid teaching system.

Then I learned about Taiwan and its history. I really admire that country, it's democracy and how they've preserved chinese culture. They write chinese characters the same way they were written 2000 years ago and that is pretty cool.

Some months ago I was looking for a traditional Chinese school in Mexico and I found a pretty sweet schollarship to study Chinese in Taiwan. I applied and since I have published an articule about Mexican Spanish pronunciation for native Mandarin speakers plus I am doing pretty well in collage, I got it!

The problem is I'm kind of broke and I cannot afford my plane ticket to get to Taiwan.

If I cannot buy this plane ticket I will lose my scholarship. Please help!

Of course you'll get perks. I'm a musician and I can give you access to my secret songs or even write you a personalized song. I can also write chinese characters so I can send you your chinese name via registered mail.

It doesn't matter if you only donate 5 dls you will still be helping me a lot!

That's my story. I hope you can help me out!

THANK YOU!!
________________________________________________
ESPAÑOL!

Desde hace un buen tiempo he estado interesado en las culturas e idiomas de Asia. Hace dos años y medio comencé a estudiar chino y japonés, pero luego empecé a ir a la universidad y tuve que abandonar un idioma.

Decidí dejar el chino porque no había muchas escuelas y las que había eran nuevas e inexpertas.

Después me enteré de la historia de Taiwán, un lugar magnífico. La primera democracia en Asia. Un lugar donde se conserva la cultura tradicional china. Aún hoy en día utilizan el mismo sistema de escritura de hace 2,000 años y eso está muy chido.

Hace algunos meses me dieron ganas de meterme a una escuela de chino tradicional e investigué si existían en México. De pronto me encontré una beca para estudiar chino en Taiwán. Inmediatamente hice la solicitud y como tengo un artículo publicado acerca de la pronunciación de México para hablantes nativos de mandarín, además de que tengo bueno promedio en la univeridad, me la dieron!

El problema es que no tengo suficiente dinero para pagar mi boleto de avión y si no lo consigo podría perder mi beca... ¡Auxilio!

Si me ayudas tendrás recompensas. Soy músico así que puedo darte acceso a mis composiciones de piano desconocidas o inclusive escribirte una canción para agradecerte. También puedo escribir tu nombre en chino tradicional y enviarlo a tu casa por correo. Checa el área de recompensas para ver qué premios podrías tener.

No importa si sólo donas 5dls (CAD) me estarás ayudando muchísimo!

Si no tienes trajeta para donar en este sitio o no te gustaría usar tu tarjeta de crédito o débito en internet, también puedes donar a la cuenta de HSBC número 6417168907 que está a mi nombre CESAR REQUENA RAMOS. Si depositas ahí, avísame para que te haga llegar tu(s) recompensa(s).

¡Espero que puedas ayudarme a ir a mi universidad en Taiwán!

¡GRACIAS!

story:
Project Overview

Hi! For 16 years I was a public school teacher (middle school, high school, and college), and I had the opportunity to work with intelligent, fun, and caring people.  It was a great time! In the summer of 2012 and the summer of 2013 I took two (different) groups of teens on educational trips abroad. While I am not teaching in the classroom anymore, it is still my passion to help teenagers see the world. Travel allows teens access to cultures and sights they've only heard and dreamed about.

Research shows that when young people travel, it increases their compassion, confidence, and open-mindedness--these are things we need our young people to possess!  My focus is aimed at students who cannot afford to travel on their own, but have the zeal and interest in learning about other cultures and countries.

My goal is to raise $60,000 so that I can take 20 deserving teens (who can't afford the trip on their own) on a paid travel excursion in the summer of 2016. Trips run approximately $3000 for two weeks (includes airfare, hotel, and most meals), and the students will be responsible for their own spending money and tip money.

Becoming a "global citizen" will allow these students the most opportunities in life, and travel is the first step.  This program will rely on donations and funds raised by participants for future participants.  This is the Pay it Forward aspect--students who are selected to travel will have one year to pay an agreed-upon amount to be put toward next year's participants. 


Here is how your generous donations will be used:

  • Trip costs (includes airfare, hotel, some meals, entrance to museums and parks) through EF Tours
  • Excursion costs when applicable (extra sightseeing or adventure opportunities in countries)

Here is what the students must do:

  • Cover their personal spending money
  • Cover tips for all travel and tour guides
  • Pledge and fulfill a specific amount of money toward next year's travel costs of other students
  • Get their passports and other travel documents sorted

Some Previous Students Share their Experiences...

Christina LaCasse: Traveling abroad changed me for the better, for sure. I never knew just how small and young we are here in the United States until I went overseas. You walked by the ruins of buildings built in the 1100's over there. Not only that, but I got to see my history books come to life. I got to see the Mona Lisa, not just look at a picture of her in a book. I got to walk the very same steps that Anne Frank did so many years ago. I got to experience history the way it was meant to be experienced - first hand and very close. Traveling abroad is so important for young adults. They can't just be told about these things in history, they need to breathe them, feel them, and experience them for themselves. Only then can they truly learn our world's history.

Conner Chase: Traveling abroad presented me with so many unique opportunities for personal growth. Not only is it exciting and captivating to experience surreal and incredible sights like Notre Dame or the Tower of London with a group of your peers, there are incredibly important educational benefits. Allowing students to experience a world beyond their own creates a sense of intrigue and wonder; this can generate a spark or interest for learning that is omnipresent. For myself, traveling showed the cultural diversity beyond my own small sphere, and getting the opportunity to peer into these other cultures is sometimes like looking into another world. Travel is exhilarating and has bolstered in me a sense of understanding and a lifelong desire for learning. In a sense, one can't really understand what a small world we live in until you experience just how massive it is. What I mean is that as you travel thousands upon thousands of miles, you can compile these factors that make up complete separate cultures and see just how similar they are. Never have I felt more one with myself, my peers, and the world around me than when I was staring at the expanse of the Dutch countryside. All students deserve the invaluable opportunities that I have received regarding travel. In the end, there is often more to learn outside of the classroom than there is to learn within it. The world is meant to be seen and experienced, especially by growing young minds. 


The Fine Print

For the first year, all students will be former students of mine; participants will be chosen based on temperament, need, and effort.  In subsequent years, the application process will be open to any students interested. Any funds raised will go toward the travel of a student. I will take a group as small as ten, but 20 (or more!) would be the optimal size. The trip chosen will depend on funds raised--the world is open to us!  Trips start at around $1500 for Central America. If I don't get enough to take a group with me, I will create a travel scholarship for students to go on a different excursion.

Get their passports and other travel documents sorted 

Some Previous Students Share their Experiences...

Christina LaCasse: Traveling abroad changed me for the better, for sure. I never knew just how small and young we are here in the United States until I went overseas. You walked by the ruins of buildings built in the 1100's over there. Not only that, but I got to see my history books come to life. I got to see the Mona Lisa, not just look at a picture of her in a book. I got to walk the very same steps that Anne Frank did so many years ago. I got to experience history the way it was meant to be experienced - first hand and very close. Traveling abroad is so important for young adults. They can't just be told about these things in history, they need to breathe them, feel them, and experience them for themselves. Only then can they truly learn our world's history.



Conner Chase: Traveling abroad presented me with so many unique opportunities for personal growth. Not only is it exciting and captivating to experience surreal and incredible sights like Notre Dame or the Tower of London with a group of your peers, there are incredibly important educational benefits. Allowing students to experience a world beyond their own creates a sense of intrigue and wonder; this can generate a spark or interest for learning that is omnipresent. For myself, traveling showed the cultural diversity beyond my own small sphere, and getting the opportunity to peer into these other cultures is sometimes like looking into another world. Travel is exhilarating and has bolstered in me a sense of understanding and a lifelong desire for learning. In a sense, one can't really understand what a small world we live in until you experience just how massive it is. What I mean is that as you travel thousands upon thousands of miles, you can compile these factors that make up complete separate cultures and see just how similar they are. Never have I felt more one with myself, my peers, and the world around me than when I was staring at the expanse of the Dutch countryside. All students deserve the invaluable opportunities that I have received regarding travel. In the end, there is often more to learn outside of the classroom than there is to learn within it. The world is meant to be seen and experienced, especially by growing young minds. 
   
The Fine Print For the first year, all students will be former students of mine; participants will be chosen based on temperament, need, and effort.  In subsequent years, the application process will be open to any students interested. Any funds raised will go toward the travel of a student. I will take a group as small as ten, but 20 (or more!) would be the optimal size. The trip chosen will depend on funds raised--the world is open to us!  Trips start at around $1500 for Central America. If I don't get enough to take a group with me, I will create a travel scholarship for students to go on a different excursion.

story:
Short Summary

The death toll of the 25 April 7.8 magnitude earthquake in Nepal has now surpassed 8500 with over half a million homes destroyed. The money we raise goes directly to our close contacts in Nepal who our international aid organization has worked with for the last decade. My friend and colleague Beni is the founder of a Nepali non-profit and women's cottage industry we have been working with for over nine years to help raise the standard of living, build businesses and provide education for women, children and families in Nepal. Beni came from a poor village in the Dhading district of Nepal and has dedicated her entire life including her own meager resources to help her people. Now many of these families including so many poor single mothers and their children are living outside completely cut off from aid by landslides.  

What We Need & What You Get

Beni has hired helicopters and using money from donors like us is buying food, tarps, mats and everything needed to survive the coming monsoon. She has emptied her foundation account to pay for the first round of helicopter rentals and is going in debt now to continue her desperately needed efforts. 

The Impact

The Nepalese government is just not doing enough and the hundreds of thousands of homeless need supplies to survive the rapidly approaching monsoon. We need to help people like Beni because she is moving fast using ingenuity to overcome supply shortages, organized a large team of volunteers to operate the supply chain of aid and to distribute to large numbers of people as long as she can keep paying for the helicopters and supplies!

For those of you that don't know me I have been working for the non-profit, Solace International, Inc, and often living in Kathmandu, Nepal for the last ten years. We have built two schools in Nepal as well as contributed to numerous biodynamic programs and orphanages. Our website solaceinternational.org will tell you all about us and indeed has taken many more donations for this project!

Risks & Challenges

We know how to get money to the right people to make the biggest impact. Our friends and colleagues in Nepal are helping as many others as humanly possible by moving supplies and volunteers quickly and efficiently. Nepal needs help from all quarters and you can be 100% certain your money is working hard to help as many Nepalese in need as possible. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign found on your preferred social media outlets. 

Image is Beni in the center back with the turquoise blue t-shirt and Tipling villagers receiving rice.

story:
On June 20, 2015, The Cardinal Nest Inc. will be hosting our 1st Annual Youth Empowerment Conference in East Cleveland, Ohio for approximately 120 high school students from Shaw High School, Glenville High School, Collinwood High School, and Euclid High School. The event will include inspirational speakers, raffles, food, and more. The overall purpose of the conference will be to uplift and empower students who are from under-served populations. We want to encourage them to build positive connections with others and to work hard to reach their goals. We are still in need of donations so that we can provide quality materials for the conference participants (i.e. refreshments, academic planners, ink pens, draw-string book bags, transportation to the event, t-shirts etc.). Our overall fundraising goal for the conference is $2500.00. All donations are tax-deductible.

Other Ways You Can Help

1) Become a Sponsor: If you are a business or organization, we invite you to become a sponsor for our event. The sponsorship levels are as follows:

  • $ 1,000.00+ – Your name, description, and logo on all marketing and website, 5 complementary tickets to event, large advertisement in our souvenir program booklet, and recognition at conference.
  • $750.00 - $999.00 - Your name and description on our marketing materials and website, 2 complementary tickets to event, medium size advertisement in our souvenir program booklet, and recognition at conference.
  • $500.00 - $749.00 – Your name and logo on marketing materials, small size advertisement in our souvenir program booklet, recognition at conference.
  • $200.00 - $499.00 – Your name and logo on marketing materials and website
  • <$200.00 – Name listed on patron list in souvenir booklet and website
2) Purchase and advertisement in our souvenir program booklet: Each conference attendee will receive a souvenir program booklet. If you are interested purchasing an advertisement, please visit this link: Youth Empowerment Conference Souvenir Program Booklet Request Form.
 

3) Make an In-Kind Donation: We are accepting donations for refreshments, raffle items, and give-aways for our souvenir bag. If you would like to make an in-kind donation, please email thecardinalnest@gmail.com

4) Spread the word about our organization, conference, and campaign. Please share this indigogo campaign or visit our website www.cnfonline.org to learn more about our organization.


 

The mission of our organization is to provide the students of Shaw High School with a sense of pride in their community, hope for their future, and the tools necessary to reach their goals. The purpose of our organization is to prepare the students of Shaw High School for their post-graduation endeavors so that they may reach optimum levels of success. This organization is a tax-exempt organization under 501(c)(3) as of February 17, 2105 (IRS tax exempt status determination letter available upon request). We would truly appreciate your support in helping us to change the lives of our students.

story:
Help Us To Provide School Tuition For All Students Of The Kikaaya High School And Ensure These Student's Right To A Meaningful Education !


                     **$5 Makes A Difference**


Our partnership with Uganda’s Kikaaya College and Vocatonal School is one driven by the conviction that every child, no matter where they live on earth is entitled to a high quality education. The idea of equal opportunity in our technologically driven age is not an ideal but a necessity. By providing up to date academic tools and institutional structures we can ensure that the students of Kikaaya College will be able to compete in and contribute to their community. Our relationship with the Kikaaya College and Vocational School is a durable one and we are passionately committed to its students, its faculty and its administration.

After living in Kikaaya and working with its high school students, Nation Foundation director Coby Schoffman became acutely aware of the school’s urgent needs. After compiling a detailed inventory of the necessary resources, the Nation Foundation has a clear goal and a precise budget for actualizing the Kikaaya project.


What We Need 


Phase 1: Student Tuition

The tuition at Kikaaya College School and Vocational School is $78.98 per child. Though that sum may seem insignificant to us, in Uganda it can represent a hardship. We would like to raise $27,643 so that each student can enjoy a full scholarship.


Phase 2: Library Reconstruction

In order to renovate the library at Kikaaya, we need to raise $60,540. With these funds, The Kikaaya College School and Vocational School will have a completely new, expanded and refurbished library large enough to accommodate all of the school’s students at once.


Phase 3: Desks, Classrooms, and Textbooks

$43,875 will purchase for the school 450 new desks, hundreds of vital up to date textbooks, whiteboards, notebooks, pencils and pens. In addition, we will need to refurbish all of the existing classrooms, restoring the infrastructure so that each student can take full advantage of the existing facilities.


Phase 4: Computers

For its 700 plus students, The Kikaaya College School has only 9 functioning Windows computers that it acquired in 2002. By raising $56,160 we will be able to purchase and ship 80 new computers with up to date operating systems and software for their new computer lab.


Phase 5: Vocational School Materials

The curriculum at Kikaaya’s Vocational School is a vital ingredient that prepares its students for full employment within Ugandan society. In order to ensure that they have equal access and equal opportunity the students must be furnished with all the relevant material. The Electrical Instillation and Electronics Department is in need of a series of tools from safety gloves to bell pushes. For this department we must raise $8,832.72. The Cosmetology Department is in need of all supplies from pressing combs to dressing mirrors. To equip the Cosmetology Department with its needs we need $7,371.39. The Motor Vehicle Department needs pressure pumps, wheel alignment and balancing apparatus, and an entire battery of tools and machinery calling for a total of $47,936.6. The Carpentry Department needs to either purchase or update basic equipment from sanding tools to band saws. This will cost $15,522.7. The Catering and Hotel Management Department needs icing sets, pressure cookers and a whole gamut of culinary necessities totaling at $4,551.24.

The total sum needed for the Kikaaya Vocational School reconstruction is $84,214.65. To find out how to assist by providing raw materials, contact cschoffman@nation-foundation.org.


Phase 6: School Bus

There’s nothing magic about this urgent requirement. As of now the Kikaaya College and Vocational School does not have a school bus. To provide the children with a school bus we must raise a total of $80,000.


Perks


With a donation of $150 you will receive a one of a kind Kikaaya soccer or basketball jersey. We have personally designed these jerseys for the students of the Kikaaya High School. 



The Impact

After living and volunteering at the Kikaaya College and Vocational School it is difficult to put in words the level of poverty these students live in. With over half of the students being orphaned, these students live within the schools compounds year round. In cramped conditions with an absence of plumbing (there are no toilets or showers) and electricity, these students exhibit great strength and resilience despite the conditions they live in. Their level of maturity and ability through all of this to remain focused on their studies is truly inspiring. 

The students of the Kikaaya College and Vocational School deserve way more then what they have been given. These students  have a work ethic that is indescribable. With school and vocational classes beginning at 6 am and not ending until 9 at night, these students truly define what it means to work hard.

Despite their unbelievable dedication to their studies, a large portion of the students struggle to pay their school fees. Equivicating to less then 80 US dollars a year, what may seem insignificant, represents a tremendous hardship for these students and their families. This is why the first phase of the Kikaaya project is to fund tuition for every student, ensuring that every child has the oppurtunity to complete their high school education. 


Our Mission

The Nation Foundation is an organization that provides schools in impoverished and developing countries with a series of essential scholastic resources that will ensure all students, regardless of their circumstances, have access to equal academic opportunities.


Our Vision

Our vision at The Nation Foundation is to select one school in a different part of the developing world each year and help provide the principal materials and critical infrastructure necessary for a quality education.


Other Ways You Can Help


Sponsor a Child

A donation of $80 dollars will help pay a student’s registration, tuition and board fees for one full year as well as provide for all their necessary academic materials.

Volunteer

We offer a variety of ways in which one can volunteer. Each year The Nation Foundation selects a small group of volunteers to work in one of our project schools throughout the developing world. We also offer a wide range of domestic volunteer programs where you can make a real difference within your own community.

Set Up a Drive

Mobilize your friends and neighbors by sponsoring your own fund drive! If you would like to open up your home, your community center, your school, work or house of worship to raise money to provide vital educational tools like computers, electronics, academic material, sports equipment and more, please contact us for details.

    Other Ways You Can Help

Volunteer
We offer a variety of ways in which one can volunteer. Each year The Nation Foundation selects a small group of volunteers to work in one of our project schools throughout the developing world. We also offer a wide range of domestic volunteer programs where you can make a real difference within your own community.
Set Up a Drive

story:
The Project

The 501(c)3 non-profit Libraries Without Borders has partnered with The New York Public Library and arts-education non-profit DreamYard to implement the Ideas Box in the South Bronx's Hayden Lord Park.
What?  A digital media and arts center in the South Bronx, complete with programming by trained facilitators, to close the summer achievement gap. 

Where? Hayden Lord Park, 1675 Andrews Avenue South, Bronx, NY

When? 1PM - 6PM, Tuesdays - Saturdays

What is the Ideas Box?


Called a "brilliant kit" by Fast Company and featured in the Wall Street Journal, the Ideas Box is a portable media center and digital classroom that provides various tools to strengthen community resilience through integrated education. It creates a public space for community members to gather and share ideas. The box itself unpacks and repacks in 20 minutes to allow for easy transportation and setup.

The Ideas Box at a Glance

  • A satellite Internet connection, 15 tablets, and four laptops.
  • A library with 250 paper books and thousands of e-books on e-readers
  • MOOCs and stand-along Internet educational digital content such as Khan Academy, Wikipedia, Codecademy, etc.
  • A cinema display monitor and film collection
  • Five HD cameras
  • Board games and video games
  • Arts and crafts materials, puppets and a theater workshop


The South Bronx

Our project takes place in the South Bronx's Community District 5, an under-served community in New York City.

  • Over 60% of residents on federal income assistance.*
  • Only 39% of the population holds a library card.*
  • Approximately 49% of households have an income below $12,000.*
  • Local Melrose Library reports that only 39% of patrons hold degrees of higher education.**
  • Local Hunt's Point Library reports that 61% of patrons speak a language other than English in their home.**

* Statistics taken from the New York City Government.

** Statistics reported by NYPL's Gesille Dixon.

Project Goals

Fostering Creativity

  • The Ideas Box is not just a toolkit. Libraries Without Borders trains facilitators and designs workshops. For example, in the Bronx, we'll be leading students through documentary filmmaking workshops, using video cameras from the Ideas Box to record footage of activities in the park, then using computers and tablets pre-installed with video editing software in the Ideas Box to edit the footage, and using the Internet provided by the Ideas Box to upload and share these videos.

  • Four or more trained facilitators will be on site at all times to guide users through how to use different pre-loaded applications, from Photoshop to Caustic (a DJing app) and 123D Sculpt+ (a 3D modeling app).

Expanding Access to Educational Tools

  • In partnership with local libraries and schools, Libraries Without Borders has curated and pre-loaded the Ideas Box with educational content that complements and supplements ongoing educational programs in the community.

  • The Ideas Box stays open when schools close — in the evening, on the weekend, and during summer vacation. 

Creating a New Collaborative Public Space

  • All are welcome: The Libraries Without Borders team conducts outreach throughout the community to invite individuals of different ages, genders, and ethnic backgrounds.

  • Collaboration across different organizations: The Libraries Without Borders team builds partnerships across local, national, and international organizations of private, public, and non-profit sectors. For example, in preparation for this project in the Bronx, Libraries Without Borders has developed partnerships with DreamYard, The New York Public Library, the International Rescue Committee, Bronx Pro, and Codecademy.



About the Ideas Box


The Ideas Box was developed in an international humanitarian context via partnerships with French designer Philippe Starck and the UNHCR. Libraries Without Borders first deployed the Ideas Box to refugee camps in Burundi, where it has been for over a year, already registering more than 30,000 visits, inspiring a camp-wide newspaper, and leading to a refugee-produced film that premiered at the International Human Rights Film Festival. Read a longer review of our project in the World Policy Journal.

After sharing this design and the results of our programs in UNHCR refugee camps at exhibitions and conferences, we were asked by members of various communities around the world to develop Ideas Box programs in their home contexts. Today, we have developed Ideas Box programs in 6 countries, from aboriginal communities in the Torres Straights of Australia to the public squares of Paris, France.
The program was originally conceived of as a way to expand access to educational materials in humanitarian crises contexts. The box being launched in Hayden Lord Park in the South Bronx marks an evolution in this concept as we recognized the need for access to these tools is universal and extends even to communities located in the middle of some of the most connected places in the world. The Ideas Box opening in Hayden Lord Park will foster enhanced educational opportunities, providing students tools and workshops to continue learning beyond the classroom.

Where Does the Money Go?

The $60,000 covers all costs associated with the construction of the Ideas Box and the purchase of all contents inside. Libraries Without Borders has developed partnerships with technology companies such as Sony to lower costs. In comparison, a standard bookmobile that provides a similar breadth of contents costs over $200,000. Please e-mail us directly (contact@librarieswithoutborders.org) if you are interested in learning more about the specific costs associated with the project. 

If we succeed, Libraries Without Borders and DreamYard will develop new programs to permanently keep the Ideas Box in the South Bronx. Any money we raise over $60,000 will go directly towards the development of additional Ideas Box programs in the South Bronx. 

If we fail to reach our goal, Libraries Without Borders and DreamYard will not have the financial capacity to permanently keep the Ideas Box in the Bronx. Any funds raised in the campaign would then be used to support other short-term Ideas Box programs in the Bronx. 


Our Team

  • Jesica Brandon: The Bronx, NY. DreamYard. 
  • Allister Chang: Washington, DC. Harvard Kennedy.
  • Karen Delacruz: The Bronx, NY. SUNY Plattsburgh.
  • Matthew Ender-Silberman: New York City, NY. Tufts University.
  • Jeremy Fox: Chapel Hill, NC. Duke University. 
  • Hillary Kolos: Brooklyn, NY. Media Comparative Media Studies.
  • Chris Lindblom: SLC, UT. University of Utah 
  • Jessica Marshall: San Francisco, CA. Harvard University.
  • Ramona Naddaff: Berkeley, CA. Professor at UC Berkeley.
  • Madeline Ochi: Sacramento, CA. Tufts University.
  • Victor Otero: Manhattan, NY. New York City College.
  • Pauline Rolland: Paris, France. From Libraries Without Borders' Paris office. 
  • Peter Sahlins: Berkeley, CA. Professor at UC Berkeley.
  • Patrick Weil: New York City, NY. Professor at Yale Law.

New Territory: Challenges in the U.S.

As a team of Americans, we are interested in pulling our experiences from international development back home to our communities in the US. Because this is our first project in the U.S., we anticipate hurdles we didn’t face abroad:

Challenges:

  • Engaging a diverse range of users from the local community

  • Ensuring that the Ideas Box supplements and complements ongoing community programs

How we will face them:

Our challenges are in line with our goals. Libraries Without Borders has been working closely with DreamYard and the local Sedgwick branch of The New York Public Library, organizations that have worked with families in the South Bronx community for over two decades. Together, we have been customizing all content, training facilitators, designing workshops built specifically for individuals and families in the South Bronx, and conducting outreach through low-income housing communities and public schools. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Volunteer with us on site. We welcome you to join us on site to run a workshop, teach a new skill, give a performance, or play games. Please e-mail our volunteer coordinator Chris Lindblom at clindblom@librarieswithoutborders.org with when and how you may be interested in getting engaged at Hayden Lord Park.

  • Donate items. Do you have extra books, computers, and board games that you would like to share? E-mail our donation coordinator Madeline Ochi at madeline@librarieswithoutborders.org.

  • Share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter using Indiegogo’s share tools. Include a personalized message — if you care about our cause, let your friends know why.

  • Tell your friends and family personally about the Ideas Box, Libraries Without Borders, and our program in the South Bronx.

  • Come meet our team! E-mail our program coordinator Matthew Silberman at msilberman@librarieswithoutborders.org to schedule a time to meet the team and see the Ideas Box in action. Or, just come by 1675 Andrews Ave South anytime between 1PM and 6PM, Tuesdays through Saturdays, from July 15th to September 5th.
story_txt:
The Project

The 501(c)3 non-profit Libraries Without Borders has partnered with The New York Public Library and arts-education non-profit DreamYard to implement the Ideas Box in the South Bronx's Hayden Lord Park.
What?  A digital media and arts center in the South Bronx, complete with programming by trained facilitators, to close the summer achievement gap. 
Where? Hayden Lord Park, 1675 Andrews Avenue South, Bronx, NY
When? 1PM - 6PM, Tuesdays - Saturdays

What is the Ideas Box?


Called a "brilliant kit" by Fast Company and featured in the Wall Street Journal, the Ideas Box is a portable media center and digital classroom that provides various tools to strengthen community resilience through integrated education. It creates a public space for community members to gather and share ideas. The box itself unpacks and repacks in 20 minutes to allow for easy transportation and setup.

The Ideas Box at a Glance





A satellite Internet connection, 15 tablets, and four laptops.

A library with 250 paper books and thousands of e-books on e-readers

MOOCs and stand-along Internet educational digital content such as Khan Academy, Wikipedia, Codecademy, etc.

A cinema display monitor and film collection


Five HD cameras


Board games and video games


Arts and crafts materials, puppets and a theater workshop










    

The South Bronx


Our project takes place in the South Bronx's Community District 5, an under-served community in New York City.

Over 60% of residents on federal income assistance.*
Only 39% of the population holds a library card.*
Approximately 49% of households have an income below $12,000.*
Local Melrose Library reports that only 39% of patrons hold degrees of higher education.**
Local Hunt's Point Library reports that 61% of patrons speak a language other than English in their home.**

* Statistics taken from the New York City Government.
** Statistics reported by NYPL's Gesille Dixon.
Project Goals

Fostering Creativity



The Ideas Box is not just a toolkit. Libraries Without Borders trains facilitators and designs workshops. For example, in the Bronx, we'll be leading students through documentary filmmaking workshops, using video cameras from the Ideas Box to record footage of activities in the park, then using computers and tablets pre-installed with video editing software in the Ideas Box to edit the footage, and using the Internet provided by the Ideas Box to upload and share these videos.
Four or more trained facilitators will be on site at all times to guide users through how to use different pre-loaded applications, from Photoshop to Caustic (a DJing app) and 123D Sculpt+ (a 3D modeling app).


Expanding Access to Educational Tools




In partnership with local libraries and schools, Libraries Without Borders has curated and pre-loaded the Ideas Box with educational content that complements and supplements ongoing educational programs in the community.
The Ideas Box stays open when schools close — in the evening, on the weekend, and during summer vacation. 







Creating a New Collaborative Public Space




All are welcome: The Libraries Without Borders team conducts outreach throughout the community to invite individuals of different ages, genders, and ethnic backgrounds.
Collaboration across different organizations: The Libraries Without Borders team builds partnerships across local, national, and international organizations of private, public, and non-profit sectors. For example, in preparation for this project in the Bronx, Libraries Without Borders has developed partnerships with DreamYard, The New York Public Library, the International Rescue Committee, Bronx Pro, and Codecademy.










About the Ideas Box




The Ideas Box was developed in an international humanitarian context via partnerships with French designer Philippe Starck and the UNHCR. Libraries Without Borders first deployed the Ideas Box to refugee camps in Burundi, where it has been for over a year, already registering more than 30,000 visits, inspiring a camp-wide newspaper, and leading to a refugee-produced film that premiered at the International Human Rights Film Festival. Read a longer review of our project in the World Policy Journal.


After sharing this design and the results of our programs in UNHCR refugee camps at exhibitions and conferences, we were asked by members of various communities around the world to develop Ideas Box programs in their home contexts. Today, we have developed Ideas Box programs in 6 countries, from aboriginal communities in the Torres Straights of Australia to the public squares of Paris, France.

The program was originally conceived of as a way to expand access to educational materials in humanitarian crises contexts. The box being launched in Hayden Lord Park in the South Bronx marks an evolution in this concept as we recognized the need for access to these tools is universal and extends even to communities located in the middle of some of the most connected places in the world. The Ideas Box opening in Hayden Lord Park will foster enhanced educational opportunities, providing students tools and workshops to continue learning beyond the classroom.

Where Does the Money Go?
The $60,000 covers all costs associated with the construction of the Ideas Box and the purchase of all contents inside. Libraries Without Borders has developed partnerships with technology companies such as Sony to lower costs. In comparison, a standard bookmobile that provides a similar breadth of contents costs over $200,000. Please e-mail us directly (contact@librarieswithoutborders.org) if you are interested in learning more about the specific costs associated with the project. 

If we succeed, Libraries Without Borders and DreamYard will develop new programs to permanently keep the Ideas Box in the South Bronx. Any money we raise over $60,000 will go directly towards the development of additional Ideas Box programs in the South Bronx. 

If we fail to reach our goal, Libraries Without Borders and DreamYard will not have the financial capacity to permanently keep the Ideas Box in the Bronx. Any funds raised in the campaign would then be used to support other short-term Ideas Box programs in the Bronx. 









Our Team


Jesica Brandon: The Bronx, NY. DreamYard. 

Allister Chang: Washington, DC. Harvard Kennedy.

Karen Delacruz: The Bronx, NY. SUNY Plattsburgh.

Matthew Ender-Silberman: New York City, NY. Tufts University.

Jeremy Fox: Chapel Hill, NC. Duke University. 

Hillary Kolos: Brooklyn, NY. Media Comparative Media Studies.

Chris Lindblom: SLC, UT. University of Utah 

Jessica Marshall: San Francisco, CA. Harvard University.

Ramona Naddaff: Berkeley, CA. Professor at UC Berkeley.

Madeline Ochi: Sacramento, CA. Tufts University.

Victor Otero: Manhattan, NY. New York City College.

Pauline Rolland: Paris, France. From Libraries Without Borders' Paris office. 

Peter Sahlins: Berkeley, CA. Professor at UC Berkeley.

Patrick Weil: New York City, NY. Professor at Yale Law.

New Territory: Challenges in the U.S.


As a team of Americans, we are interested in pulling our experiences from international development back home to our communities in the US. Because this is our first project in the U.S., we anticipate hurdles we didn’t face abroad:


Challenges:

Engaging a diverse range of users from the local community
Ensuring that the Ideas Box supplements and complements ongoing community programs

How we will face them:
Our challenges are in line with our goals. Libraries Without Borders has been working closely with DreamYard and the local Sedgwick branch of The New York Public Library, organizations that have worked with families in the South Bronx community for over two decades. Together, we have been customizing all content, training facilitators, designing workshops built specifically for individuals and families in the South Bronx, and conducting outreach through low-income housing communities and public schools. 


 
  Other Ways You Can Help

Volunteer with us on site. We welcome you to join us on site to run a workshop, teach a new skill, give a performance, or play games. Please e-mail our volunteer coordinator Chris Lindblom at clindblom@librarieswithoutborders.org with when and how you may be interested in getting engaged at Hayden Lord Park.
Donate items. Do you have extra books, computers, and board games that you would like to share? E-mail our donation coordinator Madeline Ochi at madeline@librarieswithoutborders.org.
Share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter using Indiegogo’s share tools. Include a personalized message — if you care about our cause, let your friends know why.
Tell your friends and family personally about the Ideas Box, Libraries Without Borders, and our program in the South Bronx.

Come meet our team! E-mail our program coordinator Matthew Silberman at msilberman@librarieswithoutborders.org to schedule a time to meet the team and see the Ideas Box in action. Or, just come by 1675 Andrews Ave South anytime between 1PM and 6PM, Tuesdays through Saturdays, from July 15th to September 5th.
