story:
Our Story

BreakAway was conceived as a vital community hub for gathering, creativity, art appreciation and education, collaboration, and good food and drink.  The café, which was the final step toward the vision of feeding the body as well as the soul, opened in late October 2016.

Located at the foot of the iconic Hastings Bridge and just one block from Hastings’ historic downtown, our 8500 square foot building, erected as a bank in 1957, is a wonderful example of mid-century architecture, ideally suited for our unique array of activities.

The café is already establishing itself as a destination for meeting and dining, and a hot spot for open mic music and poetry, author readings, rotating exhibits, improv and other performances.  We welcome facility reservations for special events, weddings/receptions, parties and large meetings.

Fitness Center Business Model

We decided to do something never done quite like this before by taking the fitness center business model and applying it to the arts with a café twist. So, just as you might join a fitness center to go exercise your body (and enjoy the juice bar after your work-out), we say, "why not join a fitness center to exercise your creativity (and enjoy the coffee and cocktail bar during your work-out)?!" 

Clinical evidence now proves that exercising your creativity is just as important as exercising your body. In fact, exercising one’s creativity is good for the mind, body and the soul by helping:

  • Reduce depression, boredom and anxiety
  • Encourage playfulness and sense of humor
  • Improve mental acuity and dexterity
  • Offer sensory stimulation and socialization
  • Increase self-esteem & nurture spirituality

We encourage people to be members, because it’s a mutual investment and commitment.  When you’re a member, you’re committing to yourself and the organization, just like at the gym.  Benefits both ways.  So, for a small monthly fee, members enjoy great benefits: 

  • Studio space & equipment (eg. soldering irons, glass cutters, sewing machines, die cutters, many materials)
  • Discounts on classes, workshops, and certain retreats & events.
  • Discounts on food and beverages in the café
  • Belonging – you are always welcome here
  • Being an important part of a vital, supportive, creative community
  • The great satisfaction of investing in a worthy cause

Big Vision/Big Building

Our VISION IS BIG - Feeding the body as well as the soul, requires big space for multiple endeavors. We were fortunate to find the perfect building in the perfect location: 35,000 cars drive by daily (great for a café), we are easy to find, and parking is plentiful. We are only two blocks from the mighty Mississippi River (in good weather, you can enjoy the river view while sipping coffee or something stronger on our outdoor patio) and one block from our historic downtown where, believe it or not, there was no high-end coffee shop until we opened one!  And while we believe no one should edit their dreams, we can easily acknowledge that few new arts organizations start by purchasing a building this big and refurbishing most of it.  It’s the perfect space.  And its cost is something we’d like help with from the community that benefits from it.

A side note on green intention:  While our building may be big, we intend to maintain a small footprint. We care deeply about the environment and plan to use biodegradable and compostable cups, plastics and take-out containers, as well as earth-friendly paper goods and supplies. 

Vendors have been chosen with care. For instance, we have chosen a local, small specialty coffee roaster: True Stone Coffee Roasters of St. Paul. Certified by the Specialty Coffee Association of America, they specialize in new-wave coffees and single-sourced beans. Their green-buying team sources exclusively from the world's finest small farms and cooperatives, allowing them to trace varietals, processing methods, labor conditions and unique ecological characteristics of every coffee they provide to us.

Also on our agenda is promoting re-use/recycling and repurposing as a goal in making art.  We have been blessed by donations of many supplies from manufacturers as well as private individuals; the stuff gets used here!  In the future, we plan to look for ways to support re-purpose artists as instructors and in a dedicated retail/e-commerce venture.

Key Players

Behind this vision is one bright, determined woman and a fabulous cadre of committed artists and community members, as well as organizational partners who help us share our purposeful work with target groups and other segments of the community. The owner of BreakAway Arts, Mecca Page, has tremendous passion and has worked tirelessly for the arts, sharing creative experiences and helping to build community. Since the conception of BreakAway Arts, Mecca has poured enormous energy and effort, not to mention her life-savings, into this vision.  

Studio Level Arts School   

The lower Studio Level at BreakAway provides over 30 artist instructors with 6 different workshop/studio spaces. Classes and workshops are offered to adults, youth, and seniors in our community and include a wide variety of media such as painting, drawing, photography, digital art, fused & stained glass, mosaics, fiber arts, jewelry-making, handmade paper, paper maché clay, pottery, creative writing, and much more! 

A year ago, a registered Art Therapist joined our staff to design programs for caregivers, seniors and people with developmental disabilities. We are currently reaching out to nursing homes, assisted living facilities and senior centers as well as collaborating with our local Veterans Home.  

We have also started a Meetup Group called The Creative Crones of BreakAway Arts. This group of wise women gather regularly to encourage learning and sharing through self-discovery and empowerment.  They have a drumming circle and meet bi-weekly to “Stitch, Bitch & Wine” (yes, spelled like that).

 

Help Us Stay the Course!

Paying Off the Big Bills of Building Upgrades

Renovations to the building included adding a commercial kitchen, creating a cafe'/art gallery dining space, building 5 workshop spaces in the studio level, adding a patio for outdoor seating, painting some exterior surfaces and adding exterior signage. While we pinched pennies every step of the way and did much of the work ourselves, these amazing transformations still cost over $300,000.

The architectural drawing shows the kitchen design and café/art gallery layout as well as the outdoor café patio and existing administrative offices. Transforming an old bank lobby into a beautiful, bistro-style café with a commercial kitchen took great imagination, way too many plumbers and electricians, enormous effort and more time than anticipated. (Our plumbing bid was nearly double our initial estimate because of the amazing depth of the concrete floor). Delays have eaten away at much of the funds designated for these final expenses.  It also left a notable trail of debt in its wake.

Construction delays (aren’t there always?), costs substantially higher than original bids, and kitchen design and equipment changes, added a pile of money to the project and held up the café opening by over six months.  And then? all the hoop-jumping necessitated by city and regional government regulations, and the associated fees/assessments added even more to the bill. The result?  We find ourselves in need of reaching out beyond our inner circle to ask for financial support to keep moving forward.

Replacing the Front Doors, Already!

This is good news!  We have had over 6000 visitors since the café opened, and the old rotunda doors at the entrance of the café have literally worn out their hinges.  Replacing them will have a big price tag – in the neighborhood of $10,000 – but it’s necessary for safety and security, as well as for an important Minnesota factor: climate control.  We don’t want to waste money heating or cooling the street corner. We've managed to find a local machinist willing to rebuild the doors for about $1,500. But this is only a temporary fix.

Completing the Ceramic Studio

Pottery classes are in hot demand.  Our first year, we rented studio time from a local potter.  This was a challenge in terms of schedule conflicts both for class time and kiln time.  We are ready to convert one of our studios to include a pottery wheel, and to retro-fit our utility area with a modest kiln.  This will enable us to put our pottery instructors to work, and allow them to keep the process in-house, which excites all of us!  We have several potential opportunities to share this resource with at-risk kids, but must first make it a reality.  The basic cost of this is close to $10,000.  Any contribution that off-sets this expense brings us closer to having an active ceramics program for everyone!

Next Steps

We’ve learned so much!  BreakAway’s studio/educational facility has been in operation for 18 months now.  It started with a core community of instructors and interested people and a whirlwind of classes and activities. Over the past summer, the focus of the organization and its staff turned to opening the café.  This stalled some program development, and substantially interrupted the calendar of classes, due to heavy construction interference and noise.  Yet, while course offerings and attendance were heavily reduced, there was a great deal of planning going on.  The internal think tank chugged away on ideas for senior programming, other opportunities for target groups, the pros & cons of non-profit status, and creating a green initiative for environmentally-conscious artists.  We also reached out to numerous organizations in the community and forged new partnerships. 

Happily, our class calendar is ramping back up, including classes offered off-site on contract with the local YMCA and the local public library, and special sessions with seniors at a variety of venues.  With those things humming along, we’re ready to look at new ventures, focus on new class opportunities including series classes for more advanced skill-building, and collaborations that take us beyond visual arts and into performance, personal and group development, and community projects.

Reaching Beyond Our Community

Helping to settle the expenses of our building improvements will ensure that BreakAway Arts not only continues to serve our community well, but has a chance to broaden its impact beyond this community.  As we said before, we are breaking new ground by taking the fitness center business model and applying it to the arts.  Our unique combination of services: an arts school, art gallery and café bring together all the essential elements to provide the perfect place to feed the body as well as the soul.  There is nothing like it. But more importantly, we hope that our Center for Creativity becomes a model for other communities and that we help Hastings become a magnet for the arts.

What You Can Do

Contribute to this campaign.  Share your love of arts and community by supporting BreakAway with a capital contribution, large or small.   Every donation helps.

  • Help us defray the background debt of bringing this great multi-faceted resource to the neighborhood.  Be part of what helps us shine as a gathering place that offers excellent fare, as well as a venue that celebrates art and musical/literary/theatrical performance.
  • See that we get those new front doors hung; you can be proud every time you open them and see them close properly behind you.  Simple, critical stuff we can’t do without.
  • Support the equipment purchases and venting that bring the clay studio to life as a core component of our class offerings.  [Alternatively, if you have a quality pottery wheel or modern electric kiln set-up, we’d be happy to accept a donation in kind!]  Getting this accomplished will make our lower level studio feel truly complete.
  • Spread the word.  If you’re nearby, tell your friends and colleagues about BreakAway.  Forward the link to this campaign to all your contacts!  Invite people for lunch or happy hour, or a Saturday morning coffee/visit to the Bloody Mary bar.  Bring friends and take a class.  Bring your current art project and hang about in the open studio.
  • Join us!  Become a member, participate, thrive, belong.

   

Share the LOVE!

Eat, Drink, Be Merry

Learn, Grow, Thrive

Be Part of Our Community

Create & Feel Great

It's All Here

Thank YOU for Your Support
story_txt:
Our StoryBreakAway was conceived as a vital community hub for gathering, creativity, art appreciation and education, collaboration, and good food and drink.  The café, which was the final step toward the vision of feeding the body as well as the soul, opened in late October 2016.Located at the foot of the iconic Hastings Bridge and just one block from Hastings’ historic downtown, our 8500 square foot building, erected as a bank in 1957, is a wonderful example of mid-century architecture, ideally suited for our unique array of activities.The café is already establishing itself as a destination for meeting and dining, and a hot spot for open mic music and poetry, author readings, rotating exhibits, improv and other performances.  We welcome facility reservations for special events, weddings/receptions, parties and large meetings.Fitness Center Business ModelWe decided to do something never done quite like this before by taking the fitness center business model and applying it to the arts with a café twist. So, just as you might join a fitness center to go exercise your body (and enjoy the juice bar after your work-out), we say, "why not join a fitness center to exercise your creativity (and enjoy the coffee and cocktail bar during your work-out)?!" Clinical evidence now proves that exercising your creativity is just as important as exercising your body. In fact, exercising one’s creativity is good for the mind, body and the soul by helping:
Reduce depression, boredom and anxiety
Encourage playfulness and sense of humor
Improve mental acuity and dexterity
Offer sensory stimulation and socialization
Increase self-esteem & nurture spirituality
We encourage people to be members, because it’s a mutual investment and commitment.  When you’re a member, you’re committing to yourself and the organization, just like at the gym.  Benefits both ways.  So, for a small monthly fee, members enjoy great benefits: 
Studio space & equipment (eg. soldering irons, glass cutters, sewing machines, die cutters, many materials)
Discounts on classes, workshops, and certain retreats & events.
Discounts on food and beverages in the café
Belonging – you are always welcome here
Being an important part of a vital, supportive, creative community
The great satisfaction of investing in a worthy cause
Big Vision/Big BuildingOur VISION IS BIG - Feeding the body as well as the soul, requires big space for multiple endeavors. We were fortunate to find the perfect building in the perfect location: 35,000 cars drive by daily (great for a café), we are easy to find, and parking is plentiful. We are only two blocks from the mighty Mississippi River (in good weather, you can enjoy the river view while sipping coffee or something stronger on our outdoor patio) and one block from our historic downtown where, believe it or not, there was no high-end coffee shop until we opened one!  And while we believe no one should edit their dreams, we can easily acknowledge that few new arts organizations start by purchasing a building this big and refurbishing most of it.  It’s the perfect space.  And its cost is something we’d like help with from the community that benefits from it.A side note on green intention:  While our building may be big, we intend to maintain a small footprint. We care deeply about the environment and plan to use biodegradable and compostable cups, plastics and take-out containers, as well as earth-friendly paper goods and supplies. Vendors have been chosen with care. For instance, we have chosen a local, small specialty coffee roaster: True Stone Coffee Roasters of St. Paul. Certified by the Specialty Coffee Association of America, they specialize in new-wave coffees and single-sourced beans. Their green-buying team sources exclusively from the world's finest small farms and cooperatives, allowing them to trace varietals, processing methods, labor conditions and unique ecological characteristics of every coffee they provide to us.Also on our agenda is promoting re-use/recycling and repurposing as a goal in making art.  We have been blessed by donations of many supplies from manufacturers as well as private individuals; the stuff gets used here!  In the future, we plan to look for ways to support re-purpose artists as instructors and in a dedicated retail/e-commerce venture.Key PlayersBehind this vision is one bright, determined woman and a fabulous cadre of committed artists and community members, as well as organizational partners who help us share our purposeful work with target groups and other segments of the community. The owner of BreakAway Arts, Mecca Page, has tremendous passion and has worked tirelessly for the arts, sharing creative experiences and helping to build community. Since the conception of BreakAway Arts, Mecca has poured enormous energy and effort, not to mention her life-savings, into this vision.  
Studio Level Arts School   The lower Studio Level at BreakAway provides over 30 artist instructors with 6 different workshop/studio spaces. Classes and workshops are offered to adults, youth, and seniors in our community and include a wide variety of media such as painting, drawing, photography, digital art, fused & stained glass, mosaics, fiber arts, jewelry-making, handmade paper, paper maché clay, pottery, creative writing, and much more! A year ago, a registered Art Therapist joined our staff to design programs for caregivers, seniors and people with developmental disabilities. We are currently reaching out to nursing homes, assisted living facilities and senior centers as well as collaborating with our local Veterans Home.  We have also started a Meetup Group called The Creative Crones of BreakAway Arts. This group of wise women gather regularly to encourage learning and sharing through self-discovery and empowerment.  They have a drumming circle and meet bi-weekly to “Stitch, Bitch & Wine” (yes, spelled like that). Help Us Stay the Course!Paying Off the Big Bills of Building UpgradesRenovations to the building included adding a commercial kitchen, creating a cafe'/art gallery dining space, building 5 workshop spaces in the studio level, adding a patio for outdoor seating, painting some exterior surfaces and adding exterior signage. While we pinched pennies every step of the way and did much of the work ourselves, these amazing transformations still cost over $300,000.The architectural drawing shows the kitchen design and café/art gallery layout as well as the outdoor café patio and existing administrative offices. Transforming an old bank lobby into a beautiful, bistro-style café with a commercial kitchen took great imagination, way too many plumbers and electricians, enormous effort and more time than anticipated. (Our plumbing bid was nearly double our initial estimate because of the amazing depth of the concrete floor). Delays have eaten away at much of the funds designated for these final expenses.  It also left a notable trail of debt in its wake.Construction delays (aren’t there always?), costs substantially higher than original bids, and kitchen design and equipment changes, added a pile of money to the project and held up the café opening by over six months.  And then? all the hoop-jumping necessitated by city and regional government regulations, and the associated fees/assessments added even more to the bill. The result?  We find ourselves in need of reaching out beyond our inner circle to ask for financial support to keep moving forward.Replacing the Front Doors, Already!This is good news!  We have had over 6000 visitors since the café opened, and the old rotunda doors at the entrance of the café have literally worn out their hinges.  Replacing them will have a big price tag – in the neighborhood of $10,000 – but it’s necessary for safety and security, as well as for an important Minnesota factor: climate control.  We don’t want to waste money heating or cooling the street corner. We've managed to find a local machinist willing to rebuild the doors for about $1,500. But this is only a temporary fix.Completing the Ceramic StudioPottery classes are in hot demand.  Our first year, we rented studio time from a local potter.  This was a challenge in terms of schedule conflicts both for class time and kiln time.  We are ready to convert one of our studios to include a pottery wheel, and to retro-fit our utility area with a modest kiln.  This will enable us to put our pottery instructors to work, and allow them to keep the process in-house, which excites all of us!  We have several potential opportunities to share this resource with at-risk kids, but must first make it a reality.  The basic cost of this is close to $10,000.  Any contribution that off-sets this expense brings us closer to having an active ceramics program for everyone!Next StepsWe’ve learned so much!  BreakAway’s studio/educational facility has been in operation for 18 months now.  It started with a core community of instructors and interested people and a whirlwind of classes and activities. Over the past summer, the focus of the organization and its staff turned to opening the café.  This stalled some program development, and substantially interrupted the calendar of classes, due to heavy construction interference and noise.  Yet, while course offerings and attendance were heavily reduced, there was a great deal of planning going on.  The internal think tank chugged away on ideas for senior programming, other opportunities for target groups, the pros & cons of non-profit status, and creating a green initiative for environmentally-conscious artists.  We also reached out to numerous organizations in the community and forged new partnerships. Happily, our class calendar is ramping back up, including classes offered off-site on contract with the local YMCA and the local public library, and special sessions with seniors at a variety of venues.  With those things humming along, we’re ready to look at new ventures, focus on new class opportunities including series classes for more advanced skill-building, and collaborations that take us beyond visual arts and into performance, personal and group development, and community projects.Reaching Beyond Our CommunityHelping to settle the expenses of our building improvements will ensure that BreakAway Arts not only continues to serve our community well, but has a chance to broaden its impact beyond this community.  As we said before, we are breaking new ground by taking the fitness center business model and applying it to the arts.  Our unique combination of services: an arts school, art gallery and café bring together all the essential elements to provide the perfect place to feed the body as well as the soul.  There is nothing like it. But more importantly, we hope that our Center for Creativity becomes a model for other communities and that we help Hastings become a magnet for the arts.What You Can DoContribute to this campaign.  Share your love of arts and community by supporting BreakAway with a capital contribution, large or small.   Every donation helps.
Help us defray the background debt of bringing this great multi-faceted resource to the neighborhood.  Be part of what helps us shine as a gathering place that offers excellent fare, as well as a venue that celebrates art and musical/literary/theatrical performance.
See that we get those new front doors hung; you can be proud every time you open them and see them close properly behind you.  Simple, critical stuff we can’t do without.
Support the equipment purchases and venting that bring the clay studio to life as a core component of our class offerings.  [Alternatively, if you have a quality pottery wheel or modern electric kiln set-up, we’d be happy to accept a donation in kind!]  Getting this accomplished will make our lower level studio feel truly complete.
Spread the word.  If you’re nearby, tell your friends and colleagues about BreakAway.  Forward the link to this campaign to all your contacts!  Invite people for lunch or happy hour, or a Saturday morning coffee/visit to the Bloody Mary bar.  Bring friends and take a class.  Bring your current art project and hang about in the open studio.
Join us!  Become a member, participate, thrive, belong.

   

Share the LOVE!
Eat, Drink, Be Merry
Learn, Grow, Thrive
Be Part of Our Community
Create & Feel Great
It's All Here
Thank YOU for Your Support

story:
Why? Because the history and culture of literature among young people is vast and beautiful, and goes largely uncelebrated. And because the future of literacy depends on it.

We can’t win the fight for readers without celebrating, supporting, and advancing the culture that nourishes them. Without it, the joy and wonder of books are diminished, and reading becomes a compulsory act.

The Rabbit hOle is a visionary nonprofit center for the children’s book chartered to create new and extraordinary encounters with literature that will revitalize the culture of reading for generations to come. 

With your help, we can open up new worlds and create greater access to literature by building a new kind of portal that embraces readers and non-readers alike, and provides a new way for children and adults to rediscover the joy and wonder of books, together.


FROM REPTILE TO RABBIT HOLE: The Rabbit hOle is the brainchild of Pete Cowdin and Debbie Pettid, artists and operators of Kansas City’s beloved Reading Reptile, a celebrated children’s bookstore and cultural center of 28 years. As founders and directors of The Rabbit hOle, they bring with them a wealth of knowledge, experience and many friends, both local and national, uniquely suited to the project. 

  

The Rabbit hOle is working directly with local partners and the publishing industry to realize its vision. A legion of award-winning authors and illustrators have committed to help in any way they can - and many already are. Our current national advisory board includes some of the most distinguished writers and illustrators in the world.


www.rabbitholekc.org/indiegogo-illustrations


OUR IMMEDIATE GOAL - Finding (y)Our voice:

The $150,000 will be used in support of our current operating budget, allowing us to continue building the capacity and infrastructure we need to advance our planning and prepare for a successful capital campaign. This sounds dreadfully boring and uninspired, but actually represents a critical step in the emergent life cycle of a growing nonprofit.

We’re in the delicate stage between planning and programming that can sometimes be a no-man’s land in the world of fundraising. Funders want results, but are hesitant to fund the infrastructure that produces them. Your contributions will not only help us bridge that gap between planning and programming, but help us demonstrate a broad-based support for the project, both local and national. 

That’s the real power of crowd-funding - it’s not just about the money; it’s about the voices behind it. And collectively, your voices will have an enormous impact on our ongoing fundraising efforts.

OUR LONG TERM GOALS...

Today, the Rabbit hOle is busy developing design prototypes and modeling programs to help demonstrate the many facets of our forthcoming vision so that foundations and donors and the public can better understand what we’re planning, and what it is we’re talking about when we say “the world’s first ExploraStorium”. To accomplish this, we have to build the organization at the same time, so we spend a lot of our time cultivating and fundraising as well. We're building the plane and flying it at the same time...

Meanwhile, we’re actively searching for a permanent home, a building in Kansas City at a scale between 50,000 and 80,000 square feet. The acquisition of that building will signal the beginning of our capital phase, and implementation of the full vision.

So in the long run, we’re really talking about millions of dollars, and something like a three-year plan to realize the Rabbit hOle’s full measure. We could have set our Indiegogo goal in the millions, and maybe we should have. But again, the Indiegogo is about more than just money. It’s about building the vision from the ground up.

There’s nothing quite like the Rabbit hOle anywhere in the world. And the fact is, if you want to give us more money - you can! And we want you to! We have stretch goals that stretch from Kansas City to New York and back again, and they’re very specific. If we crest the $150,000 mark, we’ll roll them out for you with gusto. And if there’s anyone out there who would like to foot the entire bill and get this thing rolling on the fast-track, please note our $12 million perk. (Paul Allen, we know you’re out there...)


  

Story is the foundation upon which all culture relies. Reading and writing are the tools that enable us to access, share, and advance the stories that shape our culture. The better we are at using these tools, the more effective we are as human beings.

The Rabbit hOle is in the business of facilitating more effective human beings...

...as a radical POINT OF ENTRY into literature that provides equal access to the culture of books to both readers and non-readers alike;

...as an enduring PLATFORM for educators that consistently provides new opportunities to support standards and scaffold academic growth;

...as a collaborative PARTNER with area libraries, schools, and a host of arts organizations both local and national;

...as an ADVOCATE , a SANCTUARY and a MEGAPHONE for literacy concerns both local and national;

...as a critical POINT OF CONTACT between young people and authors that will inspire countless children to find their own voices and stories;

...as a CURATOR, reconnecting contemporary and historical practices so that the legacy of the children’s book as an art form can be more widely understood and advanced above and beyond its status as a commodity.

Even as we build and test the vision of the Rabbit hOle, we're already creating value in the community and bringing books to kids and adults in new ways...


Learn more about these and other Rabbit hOle projects by viewing our Indiegogo gallery, or by visiting rabbitholekc.org




Our "Undie-gogo" Indiegogo launch party was a fantastic success! 

Thanks to Dav Pikey, our guest of honor, and everyone who came out. The VHS stacks were monumental, the toilet tossing was on point, the dog poo cookies were delicious and the generosity was overwhelming! If you missed the event, keep your eye on our Indiegogo page. You might still be able to score an elusive Dav Pilkey signed underwear pillow!

story:
Jana's Story

Jana was born in the Czech Republic. Since her mother is a piano teacher and her father is a great lover of music, they instilled a love of music in her at a young age. Jana has played the piano since she was a chid. She studied piano at the Czech Conservatory of P. J. Vejvanovského Kroměříž (http://www.konzkm.cz/info.aspx Note: website in Czech) She studied there from the age of 16 until her graduation in 2011 at age 21.

She came to the United States originally on a work visa but was able to switch to her dream of studying Music Business while continuing to study piano. Jana ultimately wants to build a cultural bridge between Europe and the United States with regard to music and to expose each country to talents from the other to which they have not been previously exposed in the hope of contributing to each country's culture.

As Jana is transitioning from community college to a four-year university she does not have the funds to continue studying and pursuing her dreams. In this campaign we are trying to raise funds to aid in her tuition to close the gap between scholarships and the full cost. She has currently received a talent scholarship when she was admitted to her university with an audition, but this only covers about a fifth of what she needs for the yearly tuition. We are seeking to try to raise the remainder so that she can continue.

What We Need

As Jana is transitioning from community college to a four-year university she does not have the funds to continue studying and pursuing her dreams. In this campaign we are trying to raise funds to aid in her tuition to close the gap between scholarships and the full cost. She has currently received a talent scholarship when she was admitted to her university with an audition, but this only covers about a fifth of what she needs for the yearly tuition. We are seeking to try to raise the remainder so that she can continue.

Risks & Challenges

We are relying on the kindness and generosity of others to make this happen. We set the goal lower than the actual amount needed in hopes of further scholarships being found and this campaign being fully funded.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help, please share her story to help us make Jana's dreams come true,

And that's all there is to it. =)

story:
The Skill Gap

There are 5 job openings for every software developer in the United States. Africa, meanwhile, has the youngest, fastest-growing population on earth, with more people joining the labor force over the next 20 years than the rest of the world combined. At Codulab, we believe that education, careers, and opportunities in technology should not be limited to any one demographic or sector. We want to ensure that anyone who is willing to work hard and follow their passions has a chance at a meaningful career pursuing work they love. Codulab provides a bridge to close the talent gap while investing in the smartest, most creative minds in software development.

Story so far...

Last year, we were able to train 60 students in 3 Nigerian universities to acquire web development skills through our free GeekClass program, below are the images of the GeekClass programs.


This year, we want to train another set of 60 youths to acquire world class web development skills, then pair them with projects from companies as full time, distributed team members, hence the - Developers Academy.

About the Academy

The Codulab Web Development Fellowship is a 12 Weeks intensive training program designed to equip talents in Africa with the skills necessary to launch careers in web development. 

We're not just another code bootcamp, we're a tuition-free program that includes a three-month on-campus training, real life project work, and connection to jobs in technology.   By the end of 2016, we would have trained 60 students (40 males & 20 females) to be world class web application developers. 

We will teach them a detailed curriculum that covers HTML, CSS, Javascript, REST APIs, Git & Source Control, Gulp, Server Side Programming (Ruby on Rails, PHP), Jquery, NodeJs, Angular JS,  and SQL.  We will also introducing them to the greater world of technology through company visits, guest speakers, and professional demos. 

Our Progress And Timeline

  • January - March 15 - Application open for students to register
  • March 15 - March 25 - Shortlisting of first batch of 20 students
  • April 1 - June 30 - Immersion programme for first batch  

What We Need  

Our Indiegogo fundraising goal of $25,000 will allow us to establish our digital lab & training centre. Here is what we can cover with your support:

  • The cost of a space for the entire year
  • Furniture equipment for the digital space (i.e chairs, desks, stationery)
  • Super speed WiFi network.
  • Generator for power supply.

Any funds we raise beyond that will allow us to start paying our teaching staff and mentors, and to pay our graduates for the work that they do.  

What You Get
From our Thank You perk to Premier Sponsor perk, we have a lot of gratitude to offer. Kindly check them out, thank you.

The Impact

Your support will change the lives of 20 untapped talents in Africa every 6 months and potentially 50,000 in the next 5 years. 

Our ethos

We believe in diversity. We aim to have a balance of men and women on our courses and encourage applicants from different backgrounds. There are no formal educational requirements; our selections are made on aptitude, work ethic and desire to make a positive impact on the world.

Join Us & Invest in the future!

Donate, Share & Get 5 Friends to do the same

  • Tweet this campaign to your followers
  • Post and share this on Faecbook
  • Email to your friends
  • Forward this campaign to friends and family
  • Ask your company if they would support you in this cause. Contact stanley@codulab.com for more information.

About the perks

Tell me about the 12-week coding bootcamp

Please head over to our website for more information.

What You Get
From our Thank You perk to Premier Sponsor perk, we have a lot of gratitude to offer. Kindly check them out, thank you.

  The Impact
Your support will change the lives of 20 untapped talents in Africa every 6 months and potentially 50,000 in the next 5 years. 

Our ethosWe believe in diversity. We aim to have a balance of men and women on our courses and encourage applicants from different backgrounds. There are no formal educational requirements; our selections are made on aptitude, work ethic and desire to make a positive impact on the world.

    
Join Us & Invest in the future!
Donate, Share & Get 5 Friends to do the same




Tweet this campaign to your followers
Post and share this on Faecbook

Email to your friends


Forward this campaign to friends and family

Ask your company if they would support you in this cause. Contact stanley@codulab.com for more information.


About the perks
Tell me about the 12-week coding bootcamp
Please head over to our website for more information.

story:
Who are we?

We're a group of passionate and talented athletes that have come together from all across Alberta for one thing and one thing only. To play Dodgeball. We've been selected to represent Alberta in the National Tournament in Toronto on April 30th, 2016. Team Alberta consists of one men's team and one women’s team, and we are ready to show the rest of Canada that we can compete at a national level and on the world's biggest Dodgeball stage. 

MEN'S TEAM

  • Chris Berry
  • Clayton Foster
  • Dwayne Hoppenbrouwers
  • Jason Hennessey
  • Michael Waddell
  • Paul Laking
  • Shawn Tse
  • Xaysana Jack Phavone

WOMEN'S TEAM

  • Amanda Hoppenbrouwers
  • Erica Spitzmacher
  • Jessica Shmigelsky
  • Laine Bowers
  • Lindsay Oulton
  • Lisa Papirnik
  • Shadae Berkley
  • Sherri Mendys

Why should you support us?

We are passionate about Dodgeball and want to pass that love for the game on a local, national and international level. This experience in Toronto will not only add to the credibility of Dodgeball, it will contribute to the growth of this amazing sport and community. This was only a dream to most of us a few months ago, and now our dream has come true! We love the sport more than we did in school and can’t wait to make our city, province and country proud.

What we need

Any amount of donation is greatly appreciated, and will go to travel and accommodations.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that's okay! Please spread the word and make some noise about our campaign and Dodgeball in Canada!

story:
We need your help to publish an illustrated print and e-book of children’s stories created by and for children!

What do magic wolves with supersonic hearing, flying book people and a Medusa whose hair of slithering, signing, snakes all have in common?  

They were created in our collaborative storytelling workshop with first, second and third graders from PS 347 The ASL and English Lower School.  PS 347 serves deaf and CODA (Children of Deaf Adults) students from diverse cultural and socio-economic backgrounds. Every day, these children navigate visual, spoken and written language and as such have a unique relationship to literature and literacy.   For three days teaching artists, performers, documentarians and teachers worked together to ignite students’ imaginations, to validate their creativity and to show them, through action, how much their ideas matter. 

The free workshop was only the first of three components for our collaboration with PS 347. The second is to create an original piece - inspired by the students' stories to be performed on the High Line on April 23rd.  The third is to create both a companion print book and e-book (with ASL embedded in the storytelling),  filled with the students' stories illustrated by professional theater designers and Deaf artists. 

Why a book?

We all know books play a crucial and vital role in a child’s development and never more so than when that child is bilingual.  

As beloved First Grade teacher, Dr. Gary Wellbrock said:

 “It is incredible to witness the way children shine with a self-confident glow when they see themselves reflected in the books they read.  It helps them forge connections between the story narrative and their own lives in a way that grabs their attention and inspires them to read. When they heard that their stories would be published, in a book, the room erupted with cheers of glee.  What an amazing gift Our Voices is giving them!”

Imagine the burst of pride these children will feel when they hold and see stories they created, transformed and dancing across the pages of a book illustrated by Broadway designers. Upon the book's completion, each student will receive a free copy of the book, and in an instant they will have concrete proof that their stories matter, that they matter. Copies of the book will also be donated to PS347 to provide inspiration to future generations of students, storytellers, and artists.

Our hope is students will see how a seed of an idea can grow into something magnificent, taking on multiple forms and return home richer for the experience of collaboration.

There are several ways you can help us:

*Please note that to have your name in our book, we need to hear from you by APRIL 1, 2016.
Bookmark (15+) A special thank you in the book.
Booklight (25+) A special thank you in the book and one copy.

Little Librarian (50+) A special thank you in the book and two copies.

Librarian (100+) A special thank you in the book and four copies to share with friends!

Bookworm (250+) A special thank you in the book, eight copies to share with friends and an illustrated thank you card from a PS347 student.

Editor (500+) A special thank you in the book, ten copies to share with friends and an original, illustrated story from one student beautifully framed.

Publisher (1000+) A special thank you in the book, ten copies to share with friends and an original, illustrated story from one student beautifully framed PLUS an ASL lesson with one of our amazing teaching artists and your own personalized ASL sign name.

From all of us at OUR VOICES, Twelfth House Productions LLC and PS 347...
THANK YOU!

story:
Design Your Book with Me

Many authors dream of the day they can hold a print edition of their novel in their hands, but for many independent (self-published) authors, the dream is out of reach. The costs of publishing an ebook can reach thousands of dollars after editing, cover design, and marketing. Adding in the cost of print layout design, which often exceeds $600, is beyond the average author's means. 

I'm a print designer by trade, but I'm also a self-published author. I know how difficult and expensive it is to acquire print design skills, and how easy it could be for indie authors to DIY their print novel layouts if they had the right guidance. 

Help me create the e-course Design Your Book with Me, a video-based course of step-by-step instructions for creating a novel layout using the industry standard software: InDesign. 

Design Your Book with Me is at once an introduction to InDesign and a tour of the design conventions that guide the appearance of a polished, professionally-designed novel. Students will learn the skills they need to produce a layout for an average-length novel in 30 days or less. 

Why 30 days? Adobe offers a 30-day free trial of its software, which would allow students who do not wish to purchase the software outright to participate in the course risk-free. 

Course Platform 

Design Your Book with Me will be delivered via Teachable, an online e-course platform with built-in tools to help students get the most out of the program. This includes course-specific forums, closed captioning for hearing impaired students, and the option to download course resources. 

Teachable also has a built-in affiliate platform, open to those interested in helping to promote Design Your Book with Me. 

You can view the course website and the enrollment page. 

Course Launch & Availability 

My goal is to launch Design Your Book with Me by the end of July 2016, with a pre-sale campaign commencing in mid-June. Introductory pricing for the course will be $147, to be scaled according to demand and student feedback. 

The cost of the course is a one-time fee. Students will never be asked to purchase the course again or pay a fee for continued access to course materials. One payment = lifetime access. 

Budget & Costs

My fundraising goal is all about what I need to purchase relevant software for the creation of quality course materials and to launch the course effectively. Below is a breakdown of the software I plan to utilize and the costs associated with each item.

Note that costs only reflect two months of use for each item. I'm looking for help with the startup phase of this course, not funding for an entire quarter or year.

  • Screen casting software: $80  
  • Website Hosting and URL (billed yearly): $60 
  • Adobe Creative Cloud: $100 
  • Logo: $30 
  • ActiveCampaign: $18 
  • LeadPages: $50 
  • Teachable: $39

Total: $317

You’ll notice that my goal of $500 exceeds the projected costs of launching the course. We did this for two reasons. One, because small unforseen expenses pop up, and different states/countries tax their services at different rates. Second, it's the minimum goal Indiegogo will allow campaigns to set. The surplus funds, if any, will allow me to invest in paid marketing initiatives for Design Your Book with Me. 

If you have any other questions about how I plan to use campaign funds, send us a message. I am committed to being totally transparent during this process.

Risks & Challenges

I have experience teaching print design with InDesign to students in one-on-one sessions, but never in video format. My timeline for producing these videos may be overambitious, as this is new territory for me. Scripts and outlines for each lesson are already complete, which should speed the process.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to contribute but dig the concept of this course, you can still help out.

  • Spread the word about our campaign. Make as much noise as you can on social media.
  • Join our mailing list and stay up to date with the launch of Design Your Book with Me.

story:
Jeannette Ginslov wants your help to set up

         Ginslov Media Studio

Online Coaching & Academy For Screendance & Digital Media 

Jeannette Ginslov is a specialist in Dance on Video: for Screen, AR (Augmented Reality) and the Internet, with 25 years experience in live performance, dance education, digital media and online industries, having facilitated Screendance and AR workshops internationally.  She has an MSc in Media Arts & Imaging from Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art & Design (Distinction) and an MA Drama & Choreography, Rhodes University. 

Her works have been screened internationally at the British Film Institute, Danish Film Institute, BBC Big Screens Outdoors, Edinburgh Festival, Lincoln Centre NYC and RedCat Theatre Los Angeles amongst others. She is a Director and Curator of Screendance Africa (Pty) Ltd, Associate Producer of www.dance-tech.net, Producer for MoveStream & Coordinator  60secondsdance.dk (2011-14).  Currently Part-time Dance & Technology lecturer at The Space - Scottish School of Contemporary Dance.

She now needs your help to set up an online academy for screendance and media practitioners:

with one on one coaching, mentoring & masterclasses

Ginslov Media Studio provides easily accessible global online learning. It is designed for digital media, dance and film practitioners, who wish to learn about making dance for screen, using AR and interactive media. The courses and masterclasses offer a rigorous exploration of dance for camera, the use of key media tools including cameras, editing software, lighting, sound, special effects, interactive media tools (max/msp or Isadora) and DVD production.

With webinars and face to face sessions, students receive expert tuition with specialist digital media practitioners, who will share their skills and knowledge about creating professional digital media outcomes for performances, online, promotional or marketing purposes.

What She Needs 

  • She needs at least £2,500 to set up this academy 
  • This amount will cover the creation of teaching modules, website development, marketing, promotions, advertising, media creation and two month's rent.   
  • Work done to http://www.ginslovmediastudio.com/

What You Get

  • Your name and/or company logo will appear in the credit roll of the Intro video and on the website. 

  • You will be internationally recognised as supporting: a unique educational platform, a medium that is growing across the globe, its spread to remote areas across the globe.

  • A thank you on social media and a personal email

  • A 1 minute dance video inspired by the creation of this academy

  • If she does not reach her entire goal she will persevere none the less and seek alternative means or collaborators to launch the academy

The Impact

The aim is to use the internet for global reach and informed impact.

Since 2009 Jeannette Ginslov has taught Screendance and AR workshops internationally: USA, UK, Germany, Sweden, Denmark, Portugal, Hong Kong, South America, Lithuania, Rwanda and South Africa. She had to raise funds to travel to all these places, sometimes for very little payment or no fees for the workshops. 

However Ginslov is passionate about sharing the art form globally and wishes to use the internet to reach places like Tunisia for example, where interest is growing in the screendance medium and where local artists cannot afford to pay for her flights and accommodation, let alone her fees for the workshops.

So accessibility is a big issue! In general Screendance and related digital media subjects, such as AR and interactive media are taught at tertiary level institutions or at exclusive one off workshops in major city centres. At Ginslov Media Studio one can learn from home or a studio, from a portable laptop or personal computer. As a long distance platform it provides learning opportunities to students and professionals living in far away places, giving them access to information when they cannot afford to travel to workshops, let alone afford the costs of the workshop. 

With arts funding drying up, teaching online seems the logical solution. Ginslov will create: 

  • Private one on one live mentoring and coaching sessions
  • Webinars on choreographing for, filming and editing screendance 
  • Webinars on interactive media, animation and post production
  • Tailor made live-streaming screendance workshops and webinars
  • Masterclasses with world renowned specialists in screendance & digital media
  • Open Feedback Sessions 
  • Online Screening Room 
  • Dance Video Archive
  • Screendance and Digital Media Laboratory 
  • Hangout sessions with open/public feedback sessions 
  • Networking Page to facilitate networking and job creation
  • Links to University Departments teaching screendance & digital media
  • Library page - books, online articles, links
  • FAQ page
Risks and Challenges 

Screendance and interactive performance are niche events for small audiences, but with expanding online presence, digital media art forms are reaching more audiences than ever before. 

With your help I can grow the medium from the bottom up, from the niche to the mainstream.

I have the grit and passion for long-term goals. These have given me the ability to push through adversity, challenges and setbacks to find new solutions and a pathway to success. I welcome challenges and initiate problem solving solutions. Having being in the arts industry for over 30 years I have experience in making things work.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to help financially please help spread the campaign using the  Indiegogo share tools and/or your social media pages. 

Big thank you to Stuart Tait for logo design, animation and audio supplied by Irvine Cruickshank!

story:
Hello

For 16 years e'Pap has been helping feed the most nutrient deprived people in Africa. We are  social entrepreneurs and believe that a nutrient replete person has the best chance at life and our aim is to give people that opportunity. 

The Challenge

Modern foods lack nutrients – and now one in three people worldwide suffer from micronutrient deficiencies,  malnutrition  or what is known as ‘hidden hunger’ (Type B Malnutrition). The problem is more prevalent in least developed countries and at-risk populations.

The Solution

To deliver the missing micronutrients in a whole food that is affordable to everyone. e’Pap does exactly this, addressing ‘hidden hunger’ and restoring ‘nutrient repleteness’ so that both brain and body can perform optimally, as nature designed it.

The Difference

e’Pap contains a precise balance of 28 important nutrients that are formulated to be more easily absorbed by the body – unlike many commercially processed foods which often only contain nutrients in a chemical form that have low bio-availability and are therefore ineffective in helping to create a nutrient replete human being.

The Results

Vastly improved health known as the ’10-Day e’Pap effect’ – as experienced by thousands of people from communities and vulnerable populations across Africa, from children to the elderly, convalescents, company workforces, HIV and TB patients and even sportspeople.

This campaign

Currently we have communities all over the world reaching out for e'Pap supplies often finding us through NGO's. In this project we are hoping to feed 250 million meal portions to the children of Ndumo. Once this has been achieved we would like to respond to a plea from an orphanage in war torn Congo. Our funds are prioritised by absolute needs

We would be focusing on

1) $10 will deliver 50 meal portions

2) $50 will deliver 250 meal portions

3) $70 will deliver one bale ( our preferred method of distribution) 

which will provide 400 meal portions, 

4) $100 will deliver 500 meal operations

5) $500 will deliver 2500 meal portions

6) $1000 will deliver 5000 meal portions

Testimonials. 

There are many testimonial and appreciation letters. This is an excerpt from the doctors of Benin who were extremely impressed by the immediate results of e'Pap

This study has the task of assessing the effectiveness of this enriched e'Pap flour in improving the nutritional status of children aged 6 months  to 5 years. The results of this study revealed that the use of flour e'Pap as a dietary supplement is effective for improving the nutritional status of the children . On admission , 87.34 % of children presented a nutritional problem of which 32.02% were severe. After the 4th control , the trend was reversed with 88.68 % became normal  from a nutritional perspective and no children had severe acute malnutrition.
story_txt:
Hello
For
16 years e'Pap has been helping feed the most nutrient deprived people in
Africa. We are  social entrepreneurs and believe that a nutrient
replete person has the best chance at life and our aim is to give people
that opportunity. 
The
Challenge
Modern
foods lack nutrients – and now one in three people worldwide suffer
from micronutrient deficiencies,  malnutrition  or what is known as
‘hidden hunger’ (Type B Malnutrition). The problem is more prevalent in least
developed countries and at-risk populations.
The
Solution
To
deliver the missing micronutrients in a whole food that is affordable to
everyone. e’Pap does exactly this, addressing ‘hidden hunger’ and restoring
‘nutrient repleteness’ so that both brain and body can perform optimally, as
nature designed it.
The
Differencee’Pap contains a precise balance of 28 important nutrients that are formulated to be more easily absorbed by the body – unlike many commercially processed foods which often only contain nutrients in a chemical form that have low bio-availability and are therefore ineffective in helping to create a nutrient replete human being.
The
Results
Vastly
improved health known as the ’10-Day e’Pap effect’ – as
experienced by thousands of people from communities and vulnerable populations
across Africa, from children to the elderly, convalescents, company workforces,
HIV and TB patients and even sportspeople.
This
campaignCurrently we have communities all over the world reaching out for e'Pap supplies often finding us through NGO's. In this project we are hoping to feed 250 million meal portions to the children of Ndumo. Once this has been achieved we would like to respond to a plea from an orphanage in war torn Congo. Our funds are prioritised by absolute needs
We
would be focusing on
1)
$10 will deliver 50 meal portions
2)
$50 will deliver 250 meal portions3) $70 will deliver one bale ( our preferred method of distribution) which will provide 400 meal portions, 4) $100 will deliver 500 meal operations5) $500 will deliver 2500 meal portions6) $1000 will deliver 5000 meal portionsTestimonials. There are many testimonial and appreciation letters. This is an excerpt from the doctors of Benin who were extremely impressed by the immediate results of e'PapThis study has the task of assessing the effectiveness of this enriched e'Pap flour in improving the nutritional status of children aged 6 months  to 5 years. The results of this study revealed that the use of flour e'Pap as a dietary supplement is effective for improving the nutritional status of the children . On admission , 87.34 % of children presented a nutritional problem of which 32.02% were severe. After the 4th control , the trend was reversed with 88.68 % became normal  from a nutritional perspective and no children had severe acute malnutrition.

story:
What We Are About

The Victoria Academy of Creative Learning will be an amazing new elementary school in Victoria in which children will:

  • Make decisions about what they learn about and how to do so
  • Be challenged academically and meet those challenges due to their excitement and motivation
  • Learn actively by building things, creating works of art, writing computer code, doing inquiry-based research, solving problems, using technology, working on projects and much, much more

Visit our website, VACL.CA, for more details. Or you can watch the video.

Our Hope

We hope to raise $40 000 to cover startup costs. These are just a few of our startup costs:

  • Furniture and office supplies
  • Books and hands-on materials
  • Tablets and various other supplies for students
  • Signage, logos, branding, etc.

Why should you support the school?

These are a few of the (many) reasons we hope for your support:

  • We know that school doesn't work for many children. But what if it could work for all of them?
  • Children will benefit directly as a result of your contribution.
  • We plan to work with others schools to help start a revolution in education.

Risks & Challenges

There are many obstacles to opening an alternative school. Obviously the biggest challenge is the cost. There are others:

  • Finding a suitable location with the correct zoning and all the needs a school community has
  • Convincing people that kids can and should enjoy learning
  • Reinventing the wheel - Finding new ways to report on learning, to making writing and math relevant and helping teachers adjust to their new roles
  • Helping families to be able to afford sending their child to an independent school

Many Ways to Help

Don't feel bad if you are unable to contribute financially to the project. That doesn't mean you can't help us out. 

  • Please email your friends a link to our campaign's Indiegogo page. 
  • Tell people about our campaign.
  • Rent an airplane to skywrite an aerial message over Victoria (kidding!).
  • Email us and help out in other practical ways.

Thanks for your time and consideration

story:
Help T.I.M.E. for Real Science continue into 2016-17!

My name is Abby Williams and I have been a student scientist in the T.I.M.E. for Real Science program for 4 years. I have conducted research on a new invasive stink bug that is wreaking havoc on the southeastern United States by devastating soybean crops and invading homes in the winter.  My partner and I worked to find an effective environmentally friendly way to control this pest because they continue to re-infest crops and become resistant to the pesticide chemicals. We wanted to find the chemical components of their pheromone (chemicals used for communication within a species) that would be effective in a trap . We had to problem solve and create our own assays and became the first to discover an active chemical in their pheromone. We went to international competitions and won prizes! These experiences were inspirational to me and helped make me who I am today.

 

         

The TIME 4 Real Science Program is a unique grassroots STEM initiative that turns the preparation of tomorrow’s scientists upside down.  Traditionally, students learn science concepts in high school, learn more science concepts in college and then finally get to do real science in graduate school.  Most students never find out what it is to do real science, and opportunities are lost.  In the TIME program, twenty-four 9th - 12th graders spend over 250 hours during the school day, after school and in the summer conducting real research into questions of their own choosing that matter to them and our community as they contribute to the greater scientific knowledge base.  In the process they are supported by teachers and volunteer scientists as they learn techniques and content necessary to answer their questions.  They develop critical thinking and problem solving skills, learn to create, innovate, plan, communicate, use their resources and persist in their work.  The TIME program develops scientific entrepreneurs with a love for their community.

     

Over the past 7 years, 95 high school students have conducted innovative, authentic research on local topics including kudzu bug control, chestnut tree restoration, isolation of endophytes from local medicinal plants, and identification of endophytes that produce biofuels.  Scientists say that student work is on par with that of graduate students. Over the years, 21 TIME students have been awarded all expenses paid trips to represent North Carolina in national and international science competitions.  The TIME program has been essential in connecting students from successful elementary and middle school STEM programs to the greater STEM pipeline that spans high school and into college, keeping kids interested in science as a career.  A recent study of NC 9th graders found that only 4% go on to study STEM after high school.  In the TIME program, 70% of the students pursue STEM majors in college and careers after college.  

  

As a T.I.M.E. program graduate, I want to give other kids in my area the chance to experience what I have. Coming from a small town public school and competing with the school of math and science in our state is a big deal. We have been funded by a large grant from the Burroughs Wellcome Fund but that grant has run out. In order to keep this program going we must have funds for equipment, supplies and transportation. Your contributions will allow high school students in a public high school the chance to reach beyond a typical educational experience. They are able to find their own important questions and solve those problems on their own.

 


What We Need & What You Get

The TIME for Real Science Program is a partnership between Transylvania County Schools and North Carolina Cooperative Extension (4H Youth Development). 

It is our belief that if students are given adequate Time to engage in true Inquiry into their own questions, and find that they and their new findings Matter to others, they will continue to Explore more opportunities in science. --The T.I.M.E. Partnership

The T.I.M.E. program was first funded in 2007 by a three year $180,000 Student Science Enrichment Program grant from the Burroughs Wellcome Fund awarded to TIME program co-director Mary Arnaudin, 4H Youth Development.  From 2010-2015, the program was again supported by Burroughs Wellcome, this time through the $175,000 Career Award for Science and Math Teachers awarded to TIME program co-director Jennifer Williams.  

     

Eight years of consistent funding was undoubtedly a huge contributing factor in the success of the T.I.M.E. program.  The bottom line is that doing and communicating real science is expensive.  However, students, alumni, parents, scientists, educators and the community all agree: this proven innovative program must be sustained not only for Transylvania County, but for its potential to be replicated in other schools.  It is a model of what education should be.

The 2015-2016 program year is currently funded by Transylvania County Schools and a generous $15,000 grant from the Duke Energy Foundation.  Additional donations over the years from multiple community organizations and individuals have helped to make this program year possible.  

                                                                                                                

The application period for the 2016-2017 program year will begin soon.  We currently have a $12,000 budget gap for 2016-2017 and are looking to fill this gap by getting the word out to our supporters.  Do you value this program?  Do you want to see it continue?  If so, please donate and encourage your friends and family to donate!

While our primary goal for this Indiegogo campaign is to raise the money necessary for the program to continue into 2016-2017, we also have the following stretch goals.  Additional funds raised over and above $12,000 will be used to:

  • fund the budget gap for future program years
  • invite in teachers from other schools to learn about our research program
  • support other teachers in implementing the program
  • build an endowment to fund the current budget gap into the future
  • purchase specialized equipment (see examples in the photos below) necessary for unique student research ideas to become feasible projects

             

We need to raise $12,000 to keep the program going in 2016-2017. If you contribute $1000 or more you will be “funding a student.” You will get updates on a student's project! You will be able to see who you have helped.

What we need to do is secure remaining funds needed for 2016-2017.  After that we will build an endowment that will fund the annual budget gap for many, many years to come. If we don't reach our entire goal, the money raised here will still have a significant impact on raising funds for the program!

The Impact

Your contribution to this campaign will give you the chance to help a high school student get ahead in their life and possibly career track. This program has helped me significantly to build many skills that may not be developed in typical high school classrooms. It will also give you the opportunity to donate to students who may not have all of the privileges of kids conducting research in private schools.


We do topnotch, locally important projects in the T.I.M.E. program.  See the list of our past projects below.  This is REAL research that is adding knowledge to the greater scientific community!

TIME 4 Real Science Research Projects (2007 – 2015)

Bell, J.M., Folkomer, L., Compton, P. and Thompson, A. (2010) Domestic plants and invasive competitors:  A comparative analysis of American holly and privet

Branagan, S. and Cali, C. (2015) The search for Pityophthorus juglandis and associatedGeosmithia morbida in Transylvania County, NC*

Brinkley, C. (2014) Basis for bidirectional transmission of data and energy between inductive coils

Burrows, B., Burrows, J., Travers, M. and Jones-Herbst, L. (2009) Detection ofBatrachochytrium dendrobatidis in salamander populations of Transylvania County*

Capps, M., Compton, C. and Tolppi, S. (2011) Preferred habitat of the invasive wormAmynthas gracilis

Cook, M. (2013) Investigation of soil and water chemistry in Cedar Mountain Bog

Coye, J. (2014) Isolation and identification of endophytes from Chinese chestnut trees and their inhibitory effect on the blight fungus

Coye, J. (2013) The Isolation and identification of endophytes in American and Chinese chestnut trees

Darcey, C. (2012) The psychological and physiological effects of head massage

Davis, H. and Owen, R. (2009) Characterization of green salamander habitat

Dierolf, Y., Morgan, R., Williams, E. and Jenkins, A. (2010) Effect of the hemlock woolly adelgid on sasi beetle egg production*

Duscio, L. and Joseph, E. (2014) Antioxidant and anti-tumor effects of the berries from Elaeagnus umbellata andLindera benzoin**

Elliott, B., Hoover, F. and Goden, A. (2010) Can hellbenders be trapped safely?  A study in trap design

Farrar, S., Smith, E. and McCathern, C. (2015) The evaluation of Stevia rebaudiana for the presence of estrogen like compounds

Findlay, I., Lemel, H. and Neumann, A. (2015) Evaluation of honey bee health in Transylvania County: An assessment of Varroa destructor and Nosema levels

Graham, A., Miller, M., Russell, J. and Dorner, J. (2008) Characterization of hellbender habitat

Holland, R. and Field, H. (2015) Screening local lignicolous fungi for lignin degrading enzymes****

Jacobsen, G. (2008) Effect of temperature on crayfish growth rate

Johnson, C. and Mullen, T. (2008) Effect of an impervious surface on water quality in Nicholson Creek

Johnson, E., Smith, E. and McCathern, C. (2014) A comparison of the anticancer potential of extracts from Trifolium pratense, Pueraria lobata and Plantago major

Johnson, E., McCathern, C. and Smith, E. (2013) Evaluation of antibiotic and antioxidant extracts from Trifolium pratense and Pueraria lobata

Johnson, L., Farrar, C. and Rudd, E. (2013) Evaluating the efficacy of the Jumping Branch Wetland

Johnson, S. (2012) Anti-Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis bacterial symbionts on Aneides aeneus epidermal tissue*

Johnson, S., Suess, M. and Smith, A. (2011) The importance of riparian buffers to the biota and water quality of lotic environments in Transylvania County

Jones, D. and McCall, T. (2011) Water quality tolerance ranges for the Eastern Hellbender

Kicklighter, S. and LaForenza, D. (2014) Development and evaluation of solar collectors constructed from recycled materials

Knights, S., Good, J., Knights, A., and Compton, P. (2008) Effect of urbanization on water quality in Kings Creek

Lawing, R., Stephenson, W., Harris, A., Camby, P. and Roberts, C. (2009) Burrowing capabilities of codling moth larvae in various fruits

Lemel, S. and Spradlin, B. (2015) Adapting Lamp Assay and Culturing Methods for use in DetectingPseudoperonospora humuli in Hops and Pseudoperonospora cubensis in Cucumbers

Lupo, C. (2013) Development of an effective electrolysis system powered by hydroelectric generators to obtain hydrogen***

McCleod, E. and Williams, A. (2011) Effect of the invasive worm Amynthas gracilis on soil nitrogen levels

McCreery, K. (2013) Investigation of motility and adhesion of Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis zoospores

McCreery, K. (2012) Investigation of the germination of Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis zoospores at low cell densities**

McCreery, K. (2011) Investigation of the growth and viability of Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis

McCreery, K., Morgan, A. and Martinez, R. (2010) Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis presence in green salamander populations of Transylvania County

Moore, E. and Miller, T. (2014) Medicinal properties of the Cherokee medicinal plants Sanguinaria canadensis andVaccinium corymbosum

Newell, F., Voris, J. and Cammack, S. (2009) Effect of temperature on the respiration rate of diploid and triploid trout

Newell, M. and Lenze, M. (2012) Effect of soil type on the repellence of soybeans to the bean plataspid

Newell, M and Hollifield, B. (2010) The effect of light variation on ozone-exposed snap beans

Nichols, C. (2015) Agrobacterium-mediated stable transformation of Coleus X Hybridus in planta using the floral dip method

Nicholson, C., McGaha, N., Gravely, C. and Fisher, L. (2008) Effect of a new water treatment plant on water quality in the French Broad River

Owen, A. and Wynn, X. (2010) Hellbender bait preference: a preliminary study

Pressley, M. Ehlbert, J. and Morgan, J. (2009) Phototaxic response of tardigrades

Reece, A. and DuBreuil, L. (2015) The effect of antibiotics on the mortality of the hemlock woolly adelgid (Adelges tsugae)

Roberts, J., Witherspoon, E., and Tooley, L. (2015) Evaluation of VOC producing Diaporthe species for enzyme production**

Roberts, J., Witherspoon, E. and Tooley, L. (2014) Screening for VOC producing endophytes in an effort to target biofuel producing fungi****/*****

Roberts, J. (2013) Antibiotic and antioxidant extracts of endophytes from Juglans nigra and Liquidambar styraciflua

Roberts, J. and Coye, J. (2012) Endophytes from antibiotic/antiseptic plants

Shuler, I. and Tibbles, R. (2011) Measuring outdoor radon levels in Transylvania County

Spradlin, A. and Park, R. (2015) Identification and heavy metal remediation potential of fungi isolated from Duke Energy’s 1964 Asheville coal ash pond

Thompson, I. (2014)  Comparison of methods used to prepare freshwater diatoms for identification using optical microscopy

Tingle, J. and Compton, J. (2008) Effect of pH on crayfish growth rate

Tynch, W., Farrar, S. and Graham, N. (2014) Evaluation of oils for the production of biodiesel

West, M. (2012) Photo-identification of green salamanders

Williams, A. and Onnink, C. (2015) Electroantennogram assays to determine Megacopta cribraria response to [E]-2-hexenal, tridecane, and [E]-2-decenal*/**

Williams, A. and Onnink, C. (2014) Olfactometer and GC/MS evidence for (E)-2-Hexenal as a semiochemical in the defensive secretions of the kudzu bug, Megacopta cribraria*

Williams, A. and Onnink, C. (2013) Olfactometer assays to determine an effective pheromone trap bait for the bean plataspid, Megacopta cribraria**

Williams, E., Tooley, M. and Petterson, J. (2012) Isolation, identification and characterization of endophytes from Cherokee medicinal plants*/**

*Represented North Carolina in the Intel International Science and Engineering Fair

**Represented North Carolina at the American Association for the Advancement of Science Conference

***Represented North Carolina in the Genius Olympiad, an international environmental competition

****Represented North Carolina in the National Junior Science and Humanities Symposium

*****Represented North Carolina in the International Sustainable World Project Olympiad

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate or want to contribute in additional ways, it would be a Tremendous help to advertise this campaign on social media. Let your friends and family see the important program you are supporting!
